<title>Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na0.67[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study | Chemistry of Materials</title>

        <link rel="schema.DC" href="http://purl.org/DC/elements/1.0/"><meta name="citation_journal_title" content="Chemistry of Materials"><meta name="dc.Title" content="Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na0.67[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study"><meta name="dc.Creator" content="Euan N.  Bassey"><meta name="dc.Creator" content="Philip J.  Reeves"><meta name="dc.Creator" content="Michael A.  Jones"><meta name="dc.Creator" content="Jeongjae  Lee"><meta name="dc.Creator" content="Ieuan D.  Seymour"><meta name="dc.Creator" content="Giannantonio  Cibin"><meta name="dc.Creator" content="Clare P.  Grey"><meta name="dc.Description" content="P2-layered sodium-ion battery (NIB) cathodes are a promising class of Na-ion electrode materials with high Na+ mobility and relatively high capacities. In this work, we report the structural change..."><meta name="dc.Publisher" content="American Chemical Society"><meta name="dc.Date" scheme="WTN8601" content="June 21, 2021"><meta name="dc.Type" content="research-article"><meta name="dc.Format" content="text/HTML"><meta name="dc.Identifier" scheme="doi" content="10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248"><meta name="dc.Language" content="en"><meta name="dc.Coverage" content="world"><meta name="dc.Rights" content="© 2021 The Authors.             <link rel="meta" type="application/atom+xml" href="https://doi.org/10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248">

    <meta name="publication_doi" content="10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248">







    






    
        <meta property="og:url" content="https://pubs.acs.org/doi/full/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248"><meta property="og:title" content="Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na0.67[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study"><meta property="og:image" content="https://pubs.acs.org/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/acs.chemmater.1c00248.social.jpeg_v03"><meta property="og:description" content="P2-layered sodium-ion battery (NIB) cathodes are a promising class of Na-ion electrode materials with high Na+ mobility and relatively high capacities. In this work, we report the structural changes that take place in P2–Na0.67[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2. Using ex situ X-ray diffraction, Mn K-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure, and 23Na NMR spectroscopy, we identify the bulk phase changes along the first electrochemical charge–discharge cycle—including the formation of a high-voltage “Z phase”, an intergrowth of the OP4 and O2 phases. Our ab initio transition state searches reveal that reversible Mg2+ migration in the Z phase is both kinetically and thermodynamically favorable at high voltages. We propose that Mg2+ migration is a significant contributor to the observed voltage hysteresis in Na0.67[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 and identify qualitative changes in the Na+ ion mobility."><meta property="og:type" content="Article"><meta property="og:site_name" content="ACS Publications"><meta name="twitter:card" content="summary_large_image"><meta name="twitter:site" content="@ACSPublications"><meta name="twitter:image" content="https://pubs.acs.org/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/acs.chemmater.1c00248.social.jpeg_v03">

                <link rel="canonical" href="https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248">
            
        
    






<!-- loading Javascript for using the persistence Service -->
    <script src="/wro/1122814~thiss-ds.js" async="" nonce="93187cd67a9f0762-MAN"></script>

    <script type="text/javascript" nonce="93187cd67a9f0762-MAN">

        var SeamlessAccessService = {
            spUrl: "/action/ssostart",
            returnURL: window.location.href,
            my_context: 'seamlessaccess.org',
            timeout: 5000,

            getWAYFLessUrl: function (entityId) {
                return this.spUrl + "?idp=" + encodeURIComponent(entityId)
                    + "&redirectUri=" + encodeURIComponent(this.returnURL);
            },
            retrieveEntity: function (ms) {
                var self = this;
                var persistService = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                if (ms == undefined || ms === '') {
                    ms = this.timeout;
                }

                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    persistService.entities(self.my_context)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            return resolve(res.data);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            reject('failed to retrieve entity from local storage: ' + err);
                        });
                    // Set up the timeout
                    setTimeout(function () {
                        reject('Promise timed out ' + ms + ' ms');
                    }, ms);
                });
            },
            updateEntity: function (entitydata) {
                var self = this;
                var persistService = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                var jsonObj = {};
                try {
                    //try to parse it, if it is a json string
                    jsonObj = JSON.parse(entitydata.val());
                } catch (e) {
                    jsonObj = entitydata;
                }
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    persistService.update(self.my_context, jsonObj)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            // Process the results
                            var ssoInstitutions = res.data;
                            return resolve(ssoInstitutions);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to update the local storage due to: ' + err);
                            reject(err);
                        });
                })
            },
            removeEntity: function (entityId) {
                var self = this;
                var persistService = new thiss.PersistenceService('https://service.seamlessaccess.org/ps/');

                return new Promise(function (resolve) {
                    persistService.remove(self.my_context, entityId)
                        .then(function (res) {
                            return resolve(res);
                        }, function (err) {
                            // failed
                            console.log('failed to remove from local storage duo to: ' + err);
                        });
                })
            },
            getAccessibleEntityStatus: function (doi, entityId, entityTitle) {
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    $.ajax({
                        type: 'POST',
                        url: '/action/seamlessAccess',
                        accept: {
                            text: "application/json"
                        },
                        data: {
                            doi: doi,
                            entityid: entityId,
                            entityTitle: entityTitle,
                            eventGroupKey: '7a3b33ef-1c5f-4892-8f30-e0c6be5a904c'
                        }

                    }).done(function (status) {
                        return resolve(status);
                    }).fail(function (status) {
                        return reject(status);
                    });
                });
            },
            getEntitiesWithAllInfo: function (doi) {
                let self = this,
                    arrayOfPromises = [];
                return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) {
                    self.retrieveEntity().then(function (res) {
                        let allSsoInstitutions = res;
                        for (i = 0; i < allSsoInstitutions.length; i++) {
                            let ssoInstitution = allSsoInstitutions[i];
                            arrayOfPromises.push(new Promise(function (resolve) {
                                self.getAccessibleEntityStatus(doi, ssoInstitution.entity.entityID, ssoInstitution.entity.title)
                                    .then(function (entityStatus) {
                                        resolve({
                                            entityID: ssoInstitution.entity.entityID,
                                            entityTitle: ssoInstitution.entity.title,
                                            entityStatusObj: entityStatus,
                                            entitySsoUrl: self.getWAYFLessUrl(ssoInstitution.entity.entityID)
                                        });
                                    }, function (err) {
                                        console.log('failed to get the entity status: ' + ssoInstitution.entity.entityID,err);
                                    });
                            }));
                        }
                        if(allSsoInstitutions.length === 0 && true){
                            self.getAccessibleEntityStatus(doi, null, null)
                                .then(function () {
                                    console.log('No Entity found');
                                }, function (err) {
                                    console.log('failed to get the none entity status' ,err);
                                });
                        }
                        Promise.all(arrayOfPromises)
                            .then(function (finalResponse) {
                                resolve(finalResponse);
                            }).catch(function (err) {
                                reject(err);
                            });

                    }).catch(function (err) {
                        reject(err);
                    })
                });
            }
        };

        window.addEventListener('load', function () {
            document.querySelectorAll(".sso-institution").forEach(function (institution) {
                var entityId = institution.getAttribute('data-entityid');
                var entityName = institution.getAttribute('data-name');
                var entitydata = {
                    entityID: entityId,
                    title: entityName
                };
                institution.addEventListener("click", function (e) {
                    e.preventDefault();

                    if ($('.institution-preference-userconsent-checkbox').length > 0) {
                        let institutionPreferenceUserConsentCheckbox = $('.institution-preference-userconsent-checkbox').get(0);
                        if (!$(institutionPreferenceUserConsentCheckbox).is(":checked")) {
                            return;
                        }
                    }

                    var self = this;
                    SeamlessAccessService.updateEntity(entitydata).then(function (res) {
                        console.log(res);
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    }).catch(function (err) {
                        window.location.href = self.href;
                    });
                });
            });
        });

    </script>

        (function() {
            function isBrowserChrome() {
                return /Chrome/.test(navigator.userAgent) && /Google Inc/.test(navigator.vendor);
            }

            if (isBrowserChrome()) {
                const originTrialToken = 'AqvyZOCDq6W6Q9D+To+LSEOSztQgEaIZ1WW13TtcGHR/lf3NbAMwKFLfXztN1v4QV99Tfn7iC630Z90KBcZV9QIAAAB+eyJvcmlnaW4iOiJodHRwczovL3B1YnMuYWNzLm9yZzo0NDMiLCJmZWF0dXJlIjoiRGlzYWJsZVRoaXJkUGFydHlTdG9yYWdlUGFydGl0aW9uaW5nMyIsImV4cGlyeSI6MTc1Nzk4MDgwMCwiaXNTdWJkb21haW4iOnRydWV9';
                const originTrialMetaTag = document.createElement('meta');
                originTrialMetaTag.httpEquiv = 'origin-trial';
                originTrialMetaTag.content = originTrialToken;
                document.head.append(originTrialMetaTag);
            }
        })();

        <script async="" type="text/javascript" src="https://www.googletagservices.com/tag/js/gpt.js" rel="preconnect" nonce="93187cd67a9f0762-MAN"></script>

<script type="text/javascript" nonce="93187cd67a9f0762-MAN">
var dfpReady = false;
$(document).ready(function() {
    // var journalTitle = 'chemistry_materials';
    var taxonomyKeywords = $('.article_header-taxonomy');
    var articleKeyword = $('meta[name="keywords"]');
    var articleTitle = $('meta[name="dc.Title"]');
    var articleDescription = $('meta[name="dc.Description"]');
    var abstractKeyword = $('p.articleBody_abstractText:contains("Keywords: ")');
    var searchTerms = [];

    if (taxonomyKeywords.length > 0) {
        $(taxonomyKeywords).children(".rlist--inline").children("li").each(function() {
            searchTerms.push($(this).text());
        });
    }
    else if (articleKeyword.length > 0) { 
        searchTerms = searchTerms.concat(articleKeyword.prop('content').split(', '));
    }
    else if (abstractKeyword.length > 0) {
        searchTerms = searchTerms.concat(abstractKeyword.text().split("Keywords: ")[1].split('; '));
    }
    else if (articleDescription.length > 0) {
        $(articleDescription).each(function() {
            articleDescriptionKeywords = $(this).prop('content');
            articleDescriptionKeywords = articleDescriptionKeywords.replace(/.,/g,"");
            articleDescriptionKeywords = articleDescriptionKeywords.replace(/\s{2,}/g," ");
            searchTerms = searchTerms.concat(articleDescriptionKeywords.split(' '));
        });
    }

    if (articleTitle.length > 0) {
        searchTerms = searchTerms.concat(articleTitle.prop('content').split(' '));
    }

    googletag.cmd.push(function() {
        var mappingLeader = googletag.sizeMapping().
        addSize([750, 200], [728, 90]). 
        addSize([0, 0], [320, 50]).
        build();
        //leaderboard
        googletag.defineSlot('/8868/journal/chemistry_materials/article', [728, 90], 'dfp-journal-article-leaderboard').defineSizeMapping(mappingLeader).setTargeting('location', 'leaderboard1').setTargeting('Keyword', searchTerms).addService(googletag.pubads());
        //recommend
        googletag.defineSlot("/8868/journal/chemistry_materials/article", [1, 1], "dfp-journal-article-recommend").setTargeting("ntvPlacement", ["1100167"]).setTargeting("location", "recommend").setTargeting('Keyword', searchTerms).addService(googletag.pubads());
        //googletag.pubads().enableSingleRequest();
        googletag.pubads().collapseEmptyDivs();
        googletag.pubads().setTargeting('inst',dartInstitutionType).setTargeting('memb',dartMember);
        googletag.pubads().addEventListener("slotRenderEnded", function(event) {
            console.log(event.slot.getSlotElementId() + " isEmpty: " + event.isEmpty + " | creative id: " + event.creativeId + " " + event.size[0] + "x" + event.size[1]);
            if((event.isEmpty === false) && (event.slot.getSlotElementId() != "dfp-journal-article-recommend")) {
                $("#" + event.slot.getSlotElementId()).parents(".advertisement").slideDown();
                console.log("ad display: " + event.creativeId + " " + event.size[0] + "x" + event.size[1]);
            }
            // else {
            //     console.log("no ad found");
            // }
        });
        googletag.enableServices();
        dfpReady = true;
    });
});
</script>

<style>

  margin: -25px auto 25px auto;
}
.show-recommended .sponsoredContent { display: none; }
.show-recommended__wrapper .sponsoredContent { display: none; }
</style>

</div></div></div>
</div>




        
        <div class="header_content header_content_container"><div class="header_content_main"><div class="header_content_row article__header__content--row"><div class="header_content_left pull-left"><a href="/" title="ACS Publications. Most Trusted. Most Cited. Most Read"><img width="205" height="35" id="" alt="ACS Publications. Most Trusted. Most Cited. Most Read" src="/pb-assets/ux3/pubs-logo-481x82-1523435513963.png"></a><div class="pj-badge"></div><a href="/journal/cmatex" title="Chemistry of Materials" class="header_article-logo"><img src="/cms/10.1021/cmatex/asset/16ad6c68-bc16-d6c6-3bc1-ad6c683bc16a/title.png" alt="Chemistry of Materials"></a></div><div class="header_article-separator"></div><div class="header_content_center"><div class="header_contnav"><div class="header_contnav-row"><div class="header_contnav-title"><span class="hlFld-Title"><span class="hlFld-Title" property="headline">Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study</span></span></div></div></div></div><div class="header_article-separator"></div><div class="header_content_right pull-right"><div class="header_article-share">

        <main data-widget-id="28284a6d-730d-4a56-93ad-909787c5ac1b" id="" class="content article"><article data-getftr-enabled="data-getFTR-enabled" data-getftr-references-enabled="data-getFTR-references-enabled" data-getftr-reference-url="/action/CitationEntitlement" data-getftr-citedby-enabled="data-getFTR-citedBy-enabled" data-getftr-citedby-url="/action/CitedByEntitlement" data-getftr-links-count="10" data-getftr-request-source="FULL_TEXT" data-getftr-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248" data-figures="https://pubs.acs.org/action/ajaxShowFigures?doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;ajax=true" data-references="https://pubs.acs.org/action/ajaxShowEnhancedAbstract?doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;ajax=true" data-enable-mathjax="true" vocab="http://schema.org/" typeof="ScholarlyArticle" class="article--latest"><div class="figure-viewer"><div class="figure-viewer_row"><div class="figure-viewer_col loop-trap"><div aria-live="polite" aria-atomic="true" class="figure-viewer_modal"><a href="#" title="Close" aria-label="close" tabindex="0" class="figure-viewer_close icon-close"></a><h2 class="figure-viewer_label"><span class="figure-viewer_current"></span></h2><div class="figure-viewer_image"><a href="#" title="Next" class="figure-viewer_next icon-angle-right"></a><a href="#" title="Previous" class="figure-viewer_prev icon-angle-left"></a><div class="figure-viewer_image-content"><img src="" alt="Figure 1" class="fv-img"><img src="/specs/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/loading/loading-018624cffd023ad5641b8e99931a80e6.gif" alt="Loading Img" class="loading-img"></div></div><div class="figure-viewer_links"><a href="#" title="Download Hi-Res Image" target="_blank" class="figure-viewer_hi-res-link"><i class="icon-file-image-o"></i><span>Download Hi-Res Image</span></a><span class="fv-separator"></span><a href="#" title="Download to MS-PowerPoint" class="figure-viewer_ms-p-link"><i class="icon-file-powerpoint-o"></i><span>Download to MS-PowerPoint</span></a><span class="cit-this-container"><a href="/action/showCitFormats?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;href=/doi/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248" title="Cite This" class="figure-viewer-cite-this-link"><i class="icon-check-circle"></i><span><strong>Cite This:</strong></span></a><span class="article_header-cite-this figure-viewer-cite-this"><span class="cit-fg-title"><i>Chem. Mater.</i></span><span class="cit-fg-year"> 2021</span><span class="cit-fg-volume">, 33</span><span class="cit-fg-issue">, 13</span><span class="cit-fg-pageRange">, 4890-4906</span></span></span></div></div></div></div></div><input type="hidden" name="cmatex" id="copyRights" value="/pb-assets/json/journal-info-1744387780883.json"><div class="articleHeaderDropzone5" data-pb-dropzone="articleHeaderDropzone5"><!-- Article Refresh Event Tracking -->
<script nonce="93187cd67a9f0762-MAN">
$(function() {
    var serialCode = "cmatex";
    var books = ["reagents", "symposium", "advances", "medichemreviews", "styleguide"]
    if(books.includes(serialCode) === false) {
        // default click action
        $("[data-id]").on("mousedown", function(e) {
            var currentClickID = $(this).attr("data-id");

            if(currentClickID.includes("_hover") === false) {
                if(currentClickID.match("^article_") && !currentClickID.match("^article_abstract_CC")) {   
                    gtag('event', "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": $(this).attr("data-id") });
                }
            }
        });
        
        // Access Management icons hover
        var articleAccessManagementIconHover = false;
        var articleAccessManagementIconHoverEvent = false;
        $("[data-id='article_access_icon']").on("mouseenter", function(e) {
            if(articleAccessManagementIconHoverEvent === false) {
                articleAccessManagementIconHover = true;
                var articleAccessManagementHover =  $(this).attr("data-id") + "_hover";
                
                setTimeout(function() { 
                    if(articleAccessManagementIconHover === true) {
                        gtag("event", "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": articleAccessManagementHover });
    
                        articleAccessManagementIconHoverEvent = true;
                    }
                }, 1000);
            }
        });
        $("[data-id='article_access_icon']").on("mouseleave", function(e) {
            articleAccessManagementIconHover = false;
        });
    
        // articleRightsPermissionsLink hover
        var articleRightsPermissionsLinkHover = false;
        var articleRightsPermissionsLinkHoverEvent = false;
        $("[data-id='article_rights_permissions']").on("mouseenter", function(e) {
            if(articleRightsPermissionsLinkHoverEvent === false) {
                articleRightsPermissionsLinkHover = true;
                var articleRightsHover =  $(this).attr("data-id") + "_hover";
                
                setTimeout(function() { 
                    if(articleRightsPermissionsLinkHover === true) {
                        gtag("event", "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": articleRightsHover });
    
                        articleRightsPermissionsLinkHoverEvent = true;
                    }
                }, 1000);
            }
        });
        $("[data-id='article_rights_permissions']").on("mouseleave", function(e) {
            articleRightsPermissionsLinkHover = false;
        });
    
        // Author hover
        var articleAuthorHover = false
        var articleAuthorHoverEvent = false
        $("[data-id='article_author_info']").on("mouseenter", function(e) {
            if((articleAuthorHoverEvent === false) && ($(this).parent().hasClass("view-affs") === false)) {
                articleAuthorHover = true;
                var authorInfoHover =  $(this).attr("data-id") + "_hover";
                
                setTimeout(function() { 
                    if((articleAuthorHover === true) && (articleAuthorHoverEvent === false)) {
                        gtag("event", "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": authorInfoHover });
    
                        articleAuthorHoverEvent = true;
                    }
                }, 1000);
            }
        });
        $("[data-id='article_author_info']").on("mouseleave", function(e) {
            articleAuthorHover = false;
        });
    
        // CC License hover
        var articleAbstractCCHover = false
        var articleAbstractCCHoverEvent = false
        var articleDrawerCCHover = false
        var articleDrawerCCHoverEvent = false
        $(".article__cc-license__inter a").on("mouseenter", function(e) {
            if($(this).attr("data-id")) {
                if(($(this).attr("data-id") === "article_drawer_CC-License") && (articleDrawerCCHoverEvent === false)) {
                    articleDrawerCCHover = true;
                    
                    setTimeout(function() { 
                        if((articleDrawerCCHover === true) && (articleDrawerCCHoverEvent === false)) {
                            gtag("event", "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": "article_drawer_CC-License_hover" });
    
                            articleDrawerCCHoverEvent = true;
                        }
                    }, 1000);
                }
                else if(($(this).attr("data-id").match("^article_abstract_CC")) && (articleAbstractCCHoverEvent === false)) {
                    articleAbstractCCHover = true;
    
                    setTimeout(function() { 
                        if((articleAbstractCCHover === true) && (articleAbstractCCHoverEvent === false)) {
                            gtag("event", "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": "article_abstract_CC_hover" });
    
                            articleAbstractCCHoverEvent = true;
                        }
                    }, 1000);
                }
            }
            else if(($(this).hasClass("article__cc-license__link")) && (articleAbstractCCHoverEvent === false)) {
                articleAbstractCCHover = true;
                
                setTimeout(function() { 
                    if((articleAbstractCCHover === true) && (articleAbstractCCHoverEvent === false)) {
                        gtag("event", "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": "article_abstract_CC_hover" });
    
                        articleAbstractCCHoverEvent = true;
                    }
                }, 1000);
            }
        });
        $(".article__cc-license__inter a").on("mouseleave", function(e) {
            if(articleAbstractCCHover === true) {
                articleAbstractCCHover = false;
            }
            if(articleDrawerCCHover = true) {
                articleDrawerCCHover = false;
            }
        });
        
        // show recommeneded click delay
        var intervalCount = 0;
        var showRecommendedInterval = setInterval(function() {
            intervalCount += 100;
            if($(".show-recommended__wrapper .show-recommended").length > 0) {
                clearInterval(showRecommendedInterval);
                $("[data-id='article_drawer_RecommendedShowMore']").on("mousedown", function(e) {
                    gtag('event', "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": $(this).attr("data-id") });
                });
                $("[data-id='article_drawer_RecommendedShowLess']").on("mousedown", function(e) {
                    gtag('event', "Journal Article", { "Article_Title": "Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na&lt;sub&gt;0.67&lt;/sub&gt;[Mg&lt;sub&gt;0.28&lt;/sub&gt;Mn&lt;sub&gt;0.72&lt;/sub&gt;]O&lt;sub&gt;2&lt;/sub&gt;: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study", "Article_DOI": "10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248", "Article_Element": $(this).attr("data-id") });
                });
            }
        }, 100);
    }
});
</script>

                <a title="Conclusions" class="article__jump__link internalNav" href="#_i26" data-id="article_header_JumpTo_Conclusions">
                   <span>Conclusions</span>

            </li>
            <li>
                <a title="Supporting Information" class="article__jump__link internalNav" href="#_i27" data-id="article_header_JumpTo_Supporting%20Information">
                   <span>Supporting Information</span>

            </li>
            <li>
                <a title="Author Information" class="article__jump__link internalNav" href="#authorInformationSection" data-id="article_header_JumpTo_Author%20Information">
                   <span>Author Information</span>

            </li>
            <li>
                <a title="Acknowledgments" class="article__jump__link internalNav" href="#_i28" data-id="article_header_JumpTo_Acknowledgments">

        </div></div><div class="article__pubdate"><span>Article</span><time datetime="2021-06-21">June 21, 2021</time></div><h1 class="article_header-title" tabindex="0"><span class="hlFld-Title" property="headline">Structural Origins of Voltage Hysteresis in the Na-Ion Cathode P2–Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>: A Combined Spectroscopic and Density Functional Theory Study</span><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy article link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Article link copied!</span></div></h1><ul class="loa"><li><span><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor" tabindex="0" data-id="article_author_info" property="author">Euan N.                         </p><div class="article__cc-license__inter"><div class="article__cc-license--hoverable"><a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/" aria-describedby="tooltip-cc-text-header" class="link--bold" data-id="article_drawer_CC-License">CC-BY 4.0

                                <div role="tooltip" id="tooltip-cc-text-header" class="article__hover"><div class="article__tooltip" data-id="article_drawer_CC-Tooltip"><h3>License Summary*</h3><p>You are free to <span class="bold">share </span>(copy and redistribute) this article in any medium or format and to <span class="bold">adapt </span>(remix, transform, and build upon) the material for any purpose, even commercially within the parameters below:</p><ul><li><img src="/specs/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/cc-license/cc.svg" alt="cc licence" width="22" height="22"><p>Creative Commons (CC): This is a Creative Commons license.</p></li><li><img src="/specs/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/cc-license/by.svg" alt="ny licence" width="22" height="22"><p>Attribution (BY): Credit must be given to the creator.</p></li></ul><a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/" class="bold" data-id="article_drawer_CC-License_Tooltip_Link">View full license</a><div class="disclaimer"><p class="bold">*Disclaimer</p><p>This summary highlights only some of the key features and terms of the
                                                actual license. It is not a license and has no legal value. Carefully
                                                review the actual license before using these materials.
                                            </p></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></div><div class="article_header-metrics-dropzone" data-pb-dropzone="article_header-metrics-dropzone"><!-- Empty dropzone --></div></div></div></div><div class="article_abstract"><div class="article_abstract-title" id="Abstract" tabindex="0"><h2>Abstract</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div><div class="article_abstract-content hlFld-Abstract" id="abstractBox" property="description"><figure id="_i1" data-index="0" class="article__inlineFigure article_abstract-img"><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img class="inline-fig internalNav" src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0010.gif" alt="" id="tgr1" property="image" style="width:405px; height:275px"></button><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0010.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=_i1"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><p class="articleBody_abstractText">P2-layered sodium-ion battery (NIB) cathodes are a promising class of Na-ion electrode materials with high Na<sup>+</sup> mobility and relatively high capacities. In this work, we report the structural changes that take place in P2–Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>. Using <i>ex situ</i> X-ray diffraction, Mn <i>K</i>-edge extended X-ray absorption fine structure, and <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectroscopy, we identify the bulk phase changes along the first electrochemical charge–discharge cycle—including the formation of a high-voltage “<i>Z</i> phase”, an intergrowth of the OP4 and O2 phases. Our <i>ab initio</i> transition state searches reveal that reversible Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration in the <i>Z</i> phase is both kinetically and thermodynamically favorable at high voltages. We propose that Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration is a significant contributor to the observed voltage hysteresis in Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> and identify qualitative changes in the Na<sup>+</sup> ion mobility.</p></div><div class="article__cc-license"><div class="article__cc-license__body"><p class="article__cc-license__para">This publication is licensed under</p><div class="article__cc-license__inter"><div class="article__cc-license--hoverable"><a href="https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/" aria-describedby="tooltip-cc-text" class="link--bold" data-id="article_abstract_CC-License">CC-BY 4.0
                                    <span class="arrow"></span></a>
                                .

                                            article in any medium or format and to <span class="bold">adapt</span>(remix,
                                            transform, and build upon) the material for any purpose, even commercially
                                            within the parameters below:
                                        </p><ul><li><img src="/specs/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/cc-license/cc.svg" alt="cc licence" width="22" height="22"><p>Creative Commons (CC): This is a Creative Commons license.

Published by American Chemical Society</div><div class="article_header-footer-right"><div class="articleHeaderDropzone7" data-pb-dropzone="articleHeaderDropzone7"><!-- Empty dropzone --></div><div class="article__tags article__tags--subjects"><div class="article__tags__container"><header class="article__tags__header"><h3 class="article__tags__heading">Subjects</h3><div tabindex="0" class="article__tags__tooltip"><div aria-describedby="tooltip-subjects" class="article__tags__icon"><i class="icon-info-circle-outline"></i><span class="sr-only">what are subjects</span></div><p id="tooltip-subjects" role="tooltip" class="article__tags__diff">
                                        Article subjects are automatically applied from the ACS Subject Taxonomy and describe the scientific concepts and themes of the article.</p></div></header><ul class="article__tags__list"><li class="article__tags__item"><a class="article__tags__link" href="/action/doSearch?ConceptID=291484&amp;ref=fulltext" title="Diffraction"> Diffraction </a></li><li class="article__tags__item"><a class="article__tags__link" href="/action/doSearch?ConceptID=290667&amp;ref=fulltext" title="Ions"> Ions </a></li><li class="article__tags__item"><a class="article__tags__link" href="/action/doSearch?ConceptID=292200&amp;ref=fulltext" title="Layers"> Layers </a></li><li class="article__tags__item"><a class="article__tags__link" href="/action/doSearch?ConceptID=290776&amp;ref=fulltext" title="Phase transitions"> Phase transitions </a></li><li class="article__tags__item"><a class="article__tags__link" href="/action/doSearch?ConceptID=292316&amp;ref=fulltext" title="Transition metals"> Transition metals </a></li></ul></div></div></div></div><div class="article_content"><div class="article_content-table hlFld-FullText"><div class="article_content-row"><div class="article_content-left" property="articleBody"><div id="sec1" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i2">Introduction</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><div class="NLM_p">Sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) are a more sustainable and significantly cheaper energy storage alternative to lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and as such are poised to play a vital role in future grid-based energy storage. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref1 ref2 ref3 ref4" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref1 ref2 ref3 ref4" aria-label="reference 1 to 4">(1−4)</a> To date, the capacities of NIBs—limited by the cathode—are too low for many real-world applications, and the sources of NIB degradation have not received the attention that LIBs have. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref1 ref5 ref6" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref1 ref5 ref6" aria-label="reference 1, 5 and 6">(1,5,6)</a> If we are to address the energy storage problem and improve the electrochemical performance of NIB cathodes, we need to understand the sources of these capacity losses in terms of the structural changes these cathodes undergo during charge and discharge.</div><div class="NLM_p">Many studies have focused on layered transition metal (TM) oxides, Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>, as cathodes due to their high volumetric capacities and energy densities. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref7" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref7" aria-label="reference 7">(7)</a> The structures adopted by Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> may be described using Delmas et al.’s notation, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref8" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref8" aria-label="reference 8">(8)</a> where a letter denotes the local coordination environment of Na<sup>+</sup> ions (typically P or O for prismatic or octahedral coordination, respectively) and a number describes the number of TMO<sub>2</sub> or Na<sup>+</sup> layers per unit cell. Among the different structure types, the P2 structure is perhaps the most promising for cathodes: <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref7" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref7" aria-label="reference 7">(7)</a> the prismatic Na<sup>+</sup> sites—known as P(2d), where sites share edges with the TMO<sub>6</sub> octahedra, and P(2b), for sites which share faces with TMO<sub>6</sub> octahedra (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">1</a>a)—are separated by large, open faces, leading to low energy barriers for Na<sup>+</sup> hopping and enabling higher-rate cycling as compared to that of O-type compounds. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref5" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref5" aria-label="reference 5">(5)</a> Such O-type phases generally have a larger number of Na<sup>+</sup> sites but a lower Na<sup>+</sup> mobility due to the high-energy tetrahedral transition state (TS) associated with Na<sup>+</sup> hopping [<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">1</a>b]. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref5 ref9" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref5 ref9" aria-label="reference 5 and 9">(5,9)</a></div><figure id="fig1" data-index="1" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 1</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0002.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0002.jpeg" id="gr1" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 1. Structure of layered Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> cathode materials. (a) Structure of P2 cathodes, with the local coordination environment of the P(2b) and P(2d) Na<sup>+</sup> sites indicated, (b) structure adopted by O2 cathodes, and (c) structure adopted by OP4 cathodes. For the P2 and O2 materials, the local prismatic and octahedral Na<sup>+</sup> coordination environments are shown, respectively, as well as the route taken by Na<sup>+</sup> as it hops between adjacent sites. The TS for each Na<sup>+</sup> hopping route is highlighted with a black outline.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0002.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig1"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">On desodiating (charging) Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>TMO<sub>2</sub>, the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers undergo layer gliding to minimize electrostatic repulsion between the eclipsed O<sup>2–</sup> ions in adjacent layers and to stabilize Na<sup>+</sup> vacancies. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref10 ref11 ref12" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref10 ref11 ref12" aria-label="reference 10 to 12">(10−12)</a> For example, P2 materials can undergo layer shearing to produce an O2 structure by shearing every layer (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">1</a>b), or an OP4 structure can be formed by shearing alternate layers (giving alternating P-type and O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layers) (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig1" id="" class=" internalNav">1</a>c).</div><div class="NLM_p">To ensure long-term cyclability, Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> should ideally either undergo fully reversible phase transformations or should not undergo phase transformations at all during cycling. Several studies have therefore focused on increasing the composition range over which the pristine structure is retained, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref13 ref14 ref15 ref16 ref17" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref13 ref14 ref15 ref16 ref17" aria-label="reference 13 to 17">(13−17)</a> particularly in the promising P2-type Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> materials. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref18 ref19 ref20 ref21" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref18 ref19 ref20 ref21" aria-label="reference 18 to 21">(18−21)</a> An effective method is to dope the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer with the electrochemically inactive species such as Li, Zn, and Mg, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref22 ref23 ref24 ref25" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref22 ref23 ref24 ref25" aria-label="reference 22 to 25">(22−25)</a> which replace some of the Jahn–Teller-active Mn<sup>3+</sup> centers known to cause several of the phase transformations in P2-type Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref26" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref26" aria-label="reference 26">(26)</a> As a result, smoother electrochemical profiles, longer lifetimes, and higher rate capabilities are observed. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref25" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref25" aria-label="reference 25">(25)</a> Inspired by the successes of these doped materials, we examined Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> (henceforth termed NMMO), a high-capacity P2 NIB cathode material.</div><div class="NLM_p">Previous studies have shown that the phase behavior of the Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub><i>y</i></sub>Mn<sub>1–<i>y</i></sub>]O<sub>2</sub> family during cycling depends on the concentration of Mg<sup>2+</sup>. At low Mg<sup>2+</sup> concentrations (<i>y</i> = 0.05 and 0.10), Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions are distributed randomly over the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer. The same transformation from P2 to OP4, as reported for Na<sub>0.67</sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref24" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref24" aria-label="reference 24">(24)</a> was observed, but Mg<sup>2+</sup> doping improved the reversibility of this transformation, resulting in increased cyclability, greater capacity retention, and a smoother voltage profile. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref24 ref25" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref24 ref25" aria-label="reference 24 and 25">(24,25)</a> At higher Mg<sup>2+</sup> concentrations (<i>i.e.</i>, <i>y</i> = 0.28 for NMMO), Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions undergo partial honeycomb ordering over the pristine material’s TM sublattice (as described in more detail below), and a P2-to-O2 phase transformation during charge was reported. In addition, a large reversible capacity was seen at high voltages (beyond 4.2 V vs Na<sup>0/+</sup>), which was attributed to oxygen redox. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref27 ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref27 ref28" aria-label="reference 27 and 28">(27,28)</a> As with other O-redox-active cathode materials, NMMO is also plagued with a large voltage hysteresis, whose origin has yet to be explained. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref28" aria-label="reference 28">(28)</a></div><div class="NLM_p last">In this work, we show using X-ray diffraction (XRD) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) that at high states of charge, NMMO undergoes a phase transformation from P2 to a mixture of OP4 and O2. We suggest that the mixture of OP4 and O2 phases may be described as a “<i>Z</i>-phase”: <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref29 ref30" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref29 ref30" aria-label="reference 29 and 30">(29,30)</a> an intergrowth of OP4 and O2 phases, with little long-range order over neighboring Na<sup>+</sup> and TMO<sub>2</sub> layers. Using first principles calculations, we identify an energetically favorable process involving Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration to the tetrahedral sites in the O-type layers in the OP4 and O2 phases. We calculate the Mg<sup>2+</sup> diffusion pathway and activation energy barriers through single-ended TS searches and identify this migration as a source of the observed voltage hysteresis. The evolution of the local structure of NMMO is revealed through <i>ex situ</i><sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectroscopy, and we assign these spectra using <i>ab initio</i> calculations of the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR shifts. Finally, a description of the evolution of the structure of NMMO during charge and discharge, which is consistent with the bulk and local structural investigations, is presented.</div></div><div id="sec2" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i3">Experimental Section</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><div id="sec2_1" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i4" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i4"> Synthesis</h3><div class="NLM_p">The synthetic route used was broadly similar to the previously reported routes (see the <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a> for more details). <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref27 ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref27 ref28" aria-label="reference 27 and 28">(27,28)</a> NMMO was synthesized in 1–2 g batches <i>via</i> a high-temperature solid-state reaction (10 h at 1073 K under flowing O<sub>2</sub> gas, followed by a second step where the sample is heated to 973 K under flowing Ar and immediately quenched) between Na<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>, MgO, and Mn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref28" aria-label="reference 28">(28)</a> All batches were synthesized using the same initial mixture of precursors. The final product is moisture-sensitive and must be stored in a dry atmosphere.</div><div class="NLM_p">Electrodes of NMMO were made inside an Ar-filled glovebox by casting a slurry of NMMO, carbon super P (TIMCAL), and a PVDF binder (Kynar homopolymer) dispersed in <i>N</i>-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (Sigma-Aldrich, anhydrous, 99.5%) using an active material/carbon/binder mass ratio of 8:1:1 and an active material loading of 1.5–9.5 mg cm<sup>–2</sup>. Circular electrodes (13 mm diameter) were punched out and subsequently dried at 120 °C for 12 h under dynamic vacuum.</div><div class="NLM_p last">The electrolyte used throughout this work was 1.0 M NaPF<sub>6</sub> (Acros Organics, 98.5+%; dried at 120 °C for 12 h under dynamic vacuum) dissolved in propylene carbonate (Solvionic, anhydrous). All cells in this work were half cells, with Na metal discs as anodes; these discs were punched from the Na metal (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.0%). All procedures described below (sample preparation, coin cell assembly and disassembly, and packing of NMR, XRD, and EXAFS samples) were performed in an Ar-filled glovebox with water and oxygen levels below 1 ppm.</div></div><div id="sec2_2" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i5" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i5"> Electrochemistry</h3><div class="NLM_p">All electrochemical measurements were conducted using NMMO/Na half cells in 2032 stainless-steel coin cells. One cathode (13 mm diameter), one glass fiber separator (GF/B, Whatman; 16 mm diameter) soaked with 150 μL of the electrolyte, and one Na metal disc (13 mm diameter) were stacked and assembled into the cell.</div><div class="NLM_p last">A galvanostat/potentiostat (BioLogic) with EC laboratory software was used to perform electrochemical experiments for electrochemical assessment, <i>ex situ</i> NMR spectroscopy, and <i>ex situ</i> XRD. For <i>ex situ</i> Mn <i>K</i>-edge EXAFS samples, electrochemical experiments were carried out using an Arbin galvanostat/potentiostat. All half cells were cycled at a rate of 10 mA g<sup>–1</sup>, corresponding to approximately <i>C</i>/19, for a theoretical <i>C</i> rate relative to that of the pristine material, where this C rate has been calculated by assuming that <i>x</i> is 0.67 in the as-synthesized material Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> and that <i>x</i> can vary between 0 and 1 on cycling. The actual (experimentally determined) values of <i>x</i> at different states of charge are then calculated from the time elapsed and current applied, assuming that no parasitic reactions occur and that all material is equally desodiated—<i>i.e.</i>, no Na<sup>+</sup> ion concentration gradients build up.</div></div><div id="sec2_3" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i6" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i6"> Powder X-ray Diffraction</h3><div class="NLM_p last">In all cases, laboratory powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were recorded using a PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.541 Å). The samples were either sealed in a borosilicate glass capillary tube (for the pristine powder) or in air-tight sample holders (for <i>ex situ</i> cathodes) during the experiment. For the pristine material, 14 diffraction patterns over the range 2θ = 5–90° were collected and then summed, while patterns for <i>ex situ</i> samples were recorded over the range 2θ = 5–80°. In both cases, the step size was 0.02° and the scanning speed 0.02° s<sup>–1</sup>. All Rietveld <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref31 ref32" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref31 ref32" aria-label="reference 31 and 32">(31,32)</a> refinements and analysis of XRD data reported in this article were carried out using the TOPAS Academic 6 structure refinement software package. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref33 ref34" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref33 ref34" aria-label="reference 33 and 34">(33,34)</a></div></div><div id="sec2_4" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i7" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i7"> Scanning Electron Microscopy</h3><div class="NLM_p last">Samples were loaded onto the scanning electron microscopy (SEM) stage of the transfer module (Kammrath and Weiss, type CT0) under an inert atmosphere without exposure to air. SEM images were acquired with a Tescan MIRA3 FEG-SEM instrument at an acceleration voltage of 2.0 kV.</div></div><div id="sec2_5" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i8" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i8"> <i>Ex Situ</i> Sample Preparation</h3><div class="NLM_p last">All <i>ex situ</i> samples were prepared by cycling a cathode to a given cutoff voltage and allowing the cell to rest for at least 1 h; see the <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a> for the open circuit voltages recorded after the rest period (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Table S1</a>). The cell was opened inside an Ar-filled glovebox and the cathode extracted, washed in dimethyl carbonate (approximately 1 cm; <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref3" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref3" aria-label="reference 3">(3)</a> Sigma-Aldrich, 99%, anhydrous), and dried <i>in vacuo</i> for at least 20 min. The cathode was then either scraped off the Al foil current collector and cut up (for NMR measurements) or peeled off the Al foil current collector intact (for XRD and EXAFS).</div></div><div id="sec2_6" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i9" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i9"> <i>Operando</i> X-ray Diffraction</h3><div class="NLM_p last"><i>Operando</i> XRD measurements were carried out using a PANalytical Empyrean diffractometer (Cu Kα radiation, λ = 1.541 Å). The diffraction patterns were recorded at ambient temperature in the Bragg–Brentano geometry. All experiments were performed using an in-house <i>operando</i> cell. One cathode (with the Al foil peeled from the back), one glass microfiber separator (19 mm diameter, Whatman, Grade GF/B) soaked in the electrolyte (150 μL; despite the larger separator size than that of the coin cells, the electrolyte still wetted the separator adequately), and one Na metal disc (13 mm diameter) were stacked and assembled into the cell. The cell was left to rest for at least 1 h before beginning measurements. Diffraction patterns were recorded over the range 2θ = 5–50°, with a step size of 0.02° and a scanning speed of 0.02° s<sup>–1</sup>.</div></div><div id="sec2_7" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i10" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i10"> Mn <i>K</i>-Edge Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure</h3><div class="NLM_p last"><i>Ex situ</i> EXAFS was performed at beamline B18 at the Diamond Light Source. Mn <i>K</i>-edge data were recorded at ambient temperature in the transmission mode above and below the absorption edge of 6539 eV. Samples were loaded into an in-house (Diamond) transfer chamber with transparent polyimide (Kapton) film windows. Three spectral scans were recorded for each sample; no changes were observed for any sample between the first and last measurements. To fit the EXAFS data, Feff in the Artemis software package was used to calculate the contributions of different scattering paths to the observed data, with these paths fit using the in-built fitting algorithm in Artemis. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref35 ref36" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref35 ref36" aria-label="reference 35 and 36">(35,36)</a></div></div><div id="sec2_8" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i11" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i11"> Nuclear Magnetic Resonance</h3><div class="NLM_p last"><i>Ex situ</i> cycled cathodes were packed into 1.3 mm diameter ZrO<sub>2</sub> magic angle spinning (MAS) rotors in an Ar-filled glovebox; no rotor spent longer than 10 min outside of the glovebox before being inserted into the magnet under a protective atmosphere of flushing nitrogen gas. <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra were referenced to solid NaCl at 7.21 ppm. NMR spectra were acquired on a Bruker AVANCE III (11.7 T) using a Bruker 1.3 mm MAS probe, an MAS frequency of 60 kHz, and an effective π/2 pulse length of 0.59 μs (this corresponds to π/6, which is longer than the selective π/8 pulse to ensure that all quadrupolar <sup>23</sup>Na centers are in the quadrupolar liquid limit; <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref37" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref37" aria-label="reference 37">(37)</a> we therefore selected a compromise between the linear quadrupolar regime and maximizing the signal intensity). A rotor-synchronized Hahn-echo pulse sequence (90° – τ–180° – τ-acquire) was used. Spectra were scaled according to the mass of the sample and the number of residuals recorded. The recycle delay (25 ms; at least 5T<sub>1</sub>) was set such that the bulk, paramagnetically shifted signal was recorded quantitatively, while the diamagnetic signal due to electrolyte decomposition products was suppressed. Projection magic angle turning phase-adjusted sideband separation (pjMATPASS) experiments were also recorded to separate the isotropic resonances from the overlapping spinning sideband manifold. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref38" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref38" aria-label="reference 38">(38)</a></div></div><div id="sec2_9" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i12" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i12"> First-Principles Calculations of NMR Hyperfine and Quadrupolar Shifts</h3><div class="NLM_p">To simplify calculations and account for the partial Na occupancies in NMMO, a model system, P2–Na<sub>2/3</sub>[Mg<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>, was constructed to determine the approximate <sup>23</sup>Na shifts expected for NMMO. Throughout these calculations, (2 × 1 × 2) supercells were used to account for both inter- and intralayer magnetic exchange interactions between Mn centers.</div><div class="NLM_p">The <sup>23</sup>Na shifts of each Na site were calculated using methods described previously. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref39 ref40 ref41 ref42" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref39 ref40 ref41 ref42" aria-label="reference 39 to 42">(39−42)</a> An initial geometry optimization was performed using the VASP code, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref43 ref44 ref45" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref43 ref44 ref45" aria-label="reference 43 to 45">(43−45)</a> employing the projector-augmented wave method. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref46 ref47" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref46 ref47" aria-label="reference 46 and 47">(46,47)</a> These calculations used the spin-polarized Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof exchange–correlation functionals, applying the Hubbard <i>U</i> model <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref48 ref49" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref48 ref49" aria-label="reference 48 and 49">(48,49)</a> within the rotationally invariant formalism proposed by Liechstenstein et al., <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref50" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref50" aria-label="reference 50">(50)</a> to correct for known deficiencies of pure functionals for highly localized 3<i>d</i> states. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref51" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref51" aria-label="reference 51">(51)</a> The plane-wave energy cutoff was set to 520 eV, and an effective Hubbard <i>U</i> parameter for Mn, <i>U</i><sub>eff</sub> = <i>U</i> – <i>J</i> = 3.9 eV, where <i>U</i> and <i>J</i> are the effective on-site Coulomb and exchange parameters (<i>J</i> = 1 eV), respectively, was chosen, in line with the previous work on the parent material, Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>MnO<sub>2</sub>. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref93" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref93" aria-label="reference 93">(93)</a> SCF cycles were converged with an energy tolerance of 10<sup>–5</sup> eV. The Brillouin zone was sampled with a Monkhorst–Pack <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref52" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref52" aria-label="reference 52">(52)</a><i>k</i>-point mesh with a mesh density of &lt;0.5 Å<sup>–1</sup>.</div><div class="NLM_p">Periodic spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations of the hyperfine and quadrupole-induced shifts were performed in CRYSTAL. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref53" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref53" aria-label="reference 53">(53)</a> Hyperfine parameters were calculated with B3LYP <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref54 ref55" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref54 ref55" aria-label="reference 54 and 55">(54,55)</a> and a modified B3LYP hybrid functional containing 20 and 35% Hartree–Fock exchange, referred to as Hyb20 and Hyb35, respectively. These weights were chosen based on the success of these functionals in calculating the properties of TM compounds and have been previously reported to provide upper and lower bounds on experimental shifts. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref39 ref40 ref41" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref39 ref40 ref41" aria-label="reference 39 to 41">(39−41)</a></div><div class="NLM_p last">The calculations employed two basis sets: a smaller basis set for geometry optimizations (denoted BS-I) and a more extended set for the single-point hyperfine calculations (BS-II). The BS-I sets were taken—without modification—from solid-state studies by Catti et al., <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref56 ref57 ref58 ref59" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref56 ref57 ref58 ref59" aria-label="reference 56 to 59">(56−59)</a> while the BS-II sets comprised bases from the Ahlrichs set for metal ions <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref60" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref60" aria-label="reference 60">(60)</a> and the IGLO-III basis set for O. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref61" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref61" aria-label="reference 61">(61)</a> Additional computational details, including the number of Gaussian primitives and the contraction scheme used for each basis set, alongside details of convergence criteria used, are provided in the <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a>. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref62" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref62" aria-label="reference 62">(62)</a></div></div><div id="sec2_10" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i13" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i13"> Mg<sup>2+</sup> Migration Energy Barrier Calculation and TS Searching</h3><div class="NLM_p">The searches were carried out using a method similar to that in refs  <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref58" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref58" aria-label="reference 58">(58)</a> and  <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref59" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref59" aria-label="reference 59">(59)</a>. The migration of Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions from the octahedrally coordinated TM layers to tetrahedral sites in the (vacant) Na<sup>+</sup> layers was investigated using a hybrid eigenvector-following approach in the OPTIM code, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref64 ref65 ref66" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref64 ref65 ref66" aria-label="reference 64 to 66">(64−66)</a> with energies and gradients taken from an interface with VASP. The convergence parameters used in the minimization of the Rayleigh–Ritz ratio and tangent space minimization were the same as those found in ref  <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref63" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref63" aria-label="reference 63">(63)</a>. To initiate the TS search, the geometry-optimized structures of each system (containing octahedrally coordinated Mg<sup>2+</sup>) were modified by moving Mg<sup>2+</sup> into the same plane as that of the O<sup>2–</sup> ligands between the octahedral and tetrahedral sites.</div><div class="NLM_p">The initial geometry optimization of the reactant structure (<i>i.e.</i>, Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the octahedral site in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer) was carried out in VASP. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref43 ref44 ref45" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref43 ref44 ref45" aria-label="reference 43 to 45">(43−45)</a> The migrating Mg<sup>2+</sup> center was then displaced so that it was coplanar with the O centers coordinating the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layer into which Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates to produce a “guessed” TS. Then, OPTIM was used to move the atomic positions, based on energies and gradients calculated in VASP with DFT + <i>U</i> and using the parameters outlined above. To model the van der Waals interactions in each model compound, calculations were repeated with increasingly accurate corrections and functionals: initially, a DFT-D3 correction was applied, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref67" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref67" aria-label="reference 67">(67)</a> followed by the OPT86B functional <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref68 ref69 ref70 ref71" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref68 ref69 ref70 ref71" aria-label="reference 68 to 71">(68−71)</a> and finally the SCAN <i>meta</i>-GGA functional. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref72 ref73 ref74" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref72 ref73 ref74" aria-label="reference 72 to 74">(72−74)</a> The same effective Hubbard <i>U</i> parameter as above was used, but the plane-wave energy cutoff was set to 1000 eV when using the <i>meta</i>-GGA functional to ensure convergence to within 1 meV per formula unit.</div><div class="NLM_p last">TS searches for O2 and OP4 model systems were performed under fixed volume conditions in supercells of Na<sub>10</sub>Mg<sub>5</sub>Mn<sub>13</sub>O<sub>36</sub> and Na<sub>8</sub>Mg<sub>4</sub>Mn<sub>14</sub>O<sub>36</sub> for the O2 model system and Na<sub>18</sub>Mn<sub>27</sub>Mg<sub>9</sub>O<sub>72</sub> for the OP4 model system. The unit cell parameters were fixed to those of geometry-optimized cells. Gamma-centered <i>k</i>-point grids were used to sample the reciprocal space for both systems, with a <i>k</i>-point sampling of &lt;0.5 Å<sup>–1</sup> in the Brillouin zone. The energy from single-point calculations was converged to 10<sup>–6</sup> eV, while the root-mean-square forces were converged to below 10<sup>–5</sup> eV Å<sup>–1</sup>.</div></div></div><div id="sec3" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i14">Results</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><div id="sec3_1" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i15" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i15"> XRD of the Pristine Material</h3><div class="NLM_p">The PXRD pattern for pristine NMMO was refined against a previously reported structural model, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref31 ref32" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref31 ref32" aria-label="reference 31 and 32">(31,32)</a> in which Mg and Mn are distributed across the TM sublattice and Na<sup>+</sup> ions are distributed across the edge- and face-sharing Na<sup>+</sup> prismatic sites (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">2</a>a); <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref28" aria-label="reference 28">(28)</a> no impurities were detected. Both the refined lattice parameters and site occupancies were consistent with previous reports (<a class="ref showTableEvent internalNav" data-id="tbl1" href="#tbl1">Table </a><a class="ref showTableEvent internalNav" data-id="tbl1" href="#tbl1">1</a>); <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref27 ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref27 ref28" aria-label="reference 27 and 28">(27,28)</a> the refined occupancies indicated an almost equal occupation of Mg and Mn at the TM(1) site (at the corners of the unit cell, <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">2</a>b) and preferential occupation of the TM(2) site by Mn (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">2</a>b), suggesting partial honeycomb ordering over the TM sublattice. The refinement also revealed that the Na P(2b) sites had a higher occupancy than the Na P(2d) sites.</div><figure id="fig2" data-index="2" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 2</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0003.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0003.jpeg" id="gr2" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 2. (a) Rietveld refinement of the PXRD pattern collected for pristine NMMO at room temperature (<i>R</i><sub>wp</sub> = 4.47%), with the inset showing an SEM image of pristine NMMO. Asterisks indicate reflections modeled by the larger (2 × 2 × 1) superstructure (see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S2</a>). (b) Structure of NMMO: the left image highlights the stacking of layers in the structure, with the preferential occupation of the TM sublattice shown on the right (the unit cell is denoted with a bold outline).</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0003.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig2"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_table-wrap" id="tbl1"><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption"><div class="NLM_caption" id=""><div class="title2">Table 1. Rietveld-Derived Lattice Parameters and Site Occupancies, Based on Laboratory PXRD Data Collected for Pristine NMMO Powder, <i>R</i><sub>w.p.</sub> = 4.47%; Standard Errors Are Given in Parentheses<a class="ref internalNav" href="#t1fn1" aria-label="a"><sup>a</sup></a></div></div></div><div class="scrollable-table-wrap"><table class="table "><colgroup><col align="left"><col align="left"><col align="left">5.0239(5)</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">&nbsp;</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">β&nbsp;(°)</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">90</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">&nbsp;</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">&nbsp;</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" rowsep0" align="left">&nbsp;</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">&nbsp;</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">site</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left"><i>x</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left"><i>y</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left"><i>z</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">Occ.</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">Mn(1)/Mg(1)</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">2<i>b</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.51(10)/0.49(10)</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">Mn(2)/Mg(2)</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">4<i>d</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.33333</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.66667</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.82(2)/0.18(10)</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">O</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">12<i>k</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.354</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.354</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.08</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">1</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">Na(P(2d))</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">6<i>g</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.301</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.25</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.35(10)</td></tr><tr valign="top" class="colsep0"><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" scope="row" align="left">Na(P(2b))</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">4<i>c</i></td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.33333</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.66667</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.25</td><td class="colsep0 rowsep0" align="left">0.49(10)</td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="NLM_table-wrap-foot" id="IDtable-wrap-foot-t1fn1"><div class="footnote" id="t1fn1"><sup><sup>a</sup></sup><p class="last">Note that the Na, Mg, and Mn site occupancies were constrained such that the stoichiometry of NMMO was fixed to be Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>; the occupancies of each TM site was also fixed to a total of 1; the atomic coordinates were fixed to those in ref  <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref28" aria-label="reference 28">(28)</a> (reproduced with permission from Springer-Nature).</p></div></div></div><div class="NLM_p">Overall, while the fit to the data is adequate, some peaks (<i>Q</i> = 1.90, 1.98, 2.60, and 3.11 Å<sup>–1</sup>; see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S1</a>) could not be indexed with the current structure, and several reflection intensities were less well-modeled. We were, however, able to index all the additional peaks to a superstructure involving a (2 × 2 × 1) expansion of the unit cell. A Pawley refinement confirmed that this superstructure was able to model all of the reflections (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S2</a>), suggesting that the poorer fit to some of the reflections using the smaller unit cell shown in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig2" id="" class=" internalNav">2</a> can be ascribed to the additional ordering that creates this superstructure.
