Previous authors have identified superstructure reflections in this <i>Q</i> region to an ordering of Na<sup>+</sup> ions and vacancies known as the “long zig-zag” (LZZ); <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref30 ref75 ref76" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref30 ref75 ref76" aria-label="reference 30, 75 and 76">(30,75,76)</a> indeed, the LZZ ordering has also been identified as a ground state ordering for P2 cathodes with a Na<sup>+</sup> ion content of <i>x</i> = 0.67 (e.g., P2–Na<sub>0.67</sub>CoO<sub>2</sub>). <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref77 ref78" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref77 ref78" aria-label="reference 77 and 78">(77,78)</a> On this basis, we attribute the superstructure to an LZZ ordering.</div><div class="NLM_p last">Additional refinements of the PXRD pattern to structural models incorporating stacking faults and/or a mixture of phases with honeycomb-ordered and random TM occupancy on the Mg/Mn sublattice gave poorer fits to the data, suggesting that the “random” TM distribution/honeycomb model (which showed preferential occupancies of Mg and Mn on the two TM sites) is a more accurate description of the pristine material structure. TEM and selected area electron diffraction images also confirmed the presence of partial honeycomb ordering over the TM sublattice (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S3</a>). A more detailed analysis of both the honeycomb and (2 × 2 × 1) superstructures is beyond the scope of this work—in part because neutron diffraction measurements are required for a full analysis—but will be explored in a subsequent study.</div></div><div id="sec3_2" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i17" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i17"> Electrochemistry</h3><div class="NLM_p">The voltage profile for the first charge–discharge cycle of NMMO can be broken down into (at least) three distinct stages (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>a). Stage 1 comprises the sloping region from the open circuit voltage to approximately 4.22 V, corresponding to approximately 20% of the total charge capacity. Stage 2 is the voltage plateau during charge; stage 3 is the discharge. Subsequent electrochemical cycles were observed to become more sloping—on both charge and discharge—with a smaller voltage hysteresis (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S4</a>). The distinct voltage profiles for the first charge and discharge—observed with a large voltage hysteresis—indicates different sodiation and desodiation mechanisms in NMMO. This hysteresis is more clearly seen in the differential voltage–capacity curves (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>f), where peaks in the differential voltage–capacity curve are observed at different potentials.</div><figure id="fig3" data-index="3" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 3</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0004.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0004.jpeg" id="gr3" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 3. Electrochemical and <i>ex situ</i> XRD analysis of NMMO. The voltage profile for the first charge–discharge cycle of NMMO is shown in (a), with the changes in phase proportions during the first cycle plotted in (b) (note that the error bars are smaller than the marker size). (c) <i>Ex situ</i> laboratory XRD patterns recorded during the first cycle; the pristine P2 superstructure peaks, where observed, are indicated with asterisks, and expansions of two low-<i>Q</i> regions of the diffraction patterns are shown in (d,e). (d) corresponds to the (002) and (004) reflections for P2, O2, and OP4 phases of NMMO, while (e) shows the region of the <i>Q</i>-space corresponding to the (100) reflection for P2-NMMO. In (f), the differential voltage–capacity curve is shown for the first charge–discharge cycle.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0004.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig3"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">To understand the origin of this hysteresis and examine the bulk structural changes that take place during electrochemical cycling, we carried out <i>operando</i> and <i>ex situ</i> XRD (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figures </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>c and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S5–S15</a>). Although quantitative Rietveld refinement of the <i>operando</i> diffraction data was not possible, useful qualitative information about the bulk structural evolution of NMMO can be obtained, where the phase transitions manifest themselves in dramatic changes to the observed pattern. For each <i>ex situ</i> XRD refinement, the background was fit with a 10-term Chebychev polynomial; the lattice parameters of all phases were allowed to vary freely, and the occupancies of Na, Mg, and Mn were allowed to vary while fixing the composition of each state of charge.</div><div class="NLM_p">During stage 1, the diffraction patterns remain broadly similar, save small changes in peak positions and intensities, indicating Na<sup>+</sup> extraction from a single phase, as expected from the sloping voltage profile. The superstructure peaks seen in pristine NMMO disappear by point C2, indicating a loss of the superstructure, likely caused by both the increasing Na<sup>+</sup> ion disorder and oxidation of the Mn<sup>3+</sup> ions to Mn<sup>4+</sup>.</div><div class="NLM_p">During stage 2 (the charge plateau), a new low-<i>Q</i> peak (<i>ca.</i> 1.35 Å<sup>–1</sup>) appeared, suggesting the formation of a new phase. The appearance of the new low-angle peak was coincident with a broadening and decrease in intensity of the low-<i>Q</i> (002) peak from the P2 phase (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>d). Previous studies assigned the new peak to an O2 phase, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref27 ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref27 ref28" aria-label="reference 27 and 28">(27,28)</a> despite other members of the Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>[Mg<sub><i>y</i></sub>Mn<sub>1–<i>y</i></sub>]O<sub>2</sub> family forming an OP4 phase at high states of charge. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref24" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref24" aria-label="reference 24">(24)</a> Rietveld refinements <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref31 ref32" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref31 ref32" aria-label="reference 31 and 32">(31,32)</a> of the <i>ex situ</i> diffraction patterns collected at high states of charge (points C4 and C5 in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>) show that both OP4 and O2 phases are present along this charge plateau, the new low-<i>Q</i> peak corresponding to the (002) and (004) reflections of the O2 and OP4 phases, respectively. The data could not be modeled by using only P2 and O2 or only P2 and OP4 phases. The O2 and OP4 phases grow at the expense of the P2 phase (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>b), suggesting that the P-type layers gradually transform to O-type on desodiation (presumably <i>via</i> layer slippage), as anticipated. At the end of the charge, both O2 and OP4 phases are present, but their low-<i>Q</i> reflections remain severely broadened and at similar <i>Q</i> values (4.87 and 4.91 Å<sup>–1</sup> for (004)<sub>OP4</sub> and (002)<sub>O2</sub>, respectively), indicating little long-range order in these phases.</div><div class="NLM_p">While thermodynamically, only two phases should coexist during a two-phase reaction, the transformation from a P2 phase to an O phase is likely to be kinetically sluggish as it involves layer slippage. Many of the reflections from the OP4 and O2 phases were coincident, but some (such as the (006)<sub>OP4</sub> and (105)<sub>O2</sub>) were distinct (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figures S10 and S11</a>); we therefore propose that NMMO transforms from a P2 phase into what has been called a “<i>Z</i> phase” at high states of charge, as observed in other Mn-based layered NIB cathodes at high states of charge. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref29 ref30" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref29 ref30" aria-label="reference 29 and 30">(29,30)</a> This single (<i>Z</i>) phase can be conceptualized as an intergrowth of OP4 and O2 phases, with no long-range order between the O- and P-type layers and the concentrations of O layers within blocks of ordered OP4 regions increasing as Na is removed. In our Rietveld refinements, we refine the O2 and OP4 blocks (or phases) separately to account for the varying amounts of O- and P-type layers in this highly disordered phase.</div><div class="NLM_p">As with other layered NIB cathodes known to exhibit a P2-to-<i>Z</i> phase transformation, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref30 ref79" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref30 ref79" aria-label="reference 30 and 79">(30,79)</a> the material at the end of the first charge is best described as an O2-like phase with residual P-type layers, in line with the previous assertion that an O2 phase forms at the end of the first charge. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref27 ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref27 ref28" aria-label="reference 27 and 28">(27,28)</a> Rietveld refinements of the diffraction patterns at high states of charge against structural models with a random distribution of O- and P-type layers or refinements with variable numbers and probabilities of stacking faults were too computationally demanding and unsuccessful. Therefore, we will continue in this work to use the O2 and OP4 structures as models of the high-voltage phases but acknowledge that these are surrogates for the “true” <i>Z</i>-intergrowth phase.</div><div class="NLM_p">Our refinements clearly showed the absence of Na<sup>+</sup> in the O2-type layers. We then explored various models for the Mg<sup>2+</sup> positions, including Mg<sup>2+</sup> in either the tetrahedral or octahedral sites in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layers of the O2 and OP4 phases and Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the octahedral TMO<sub>2</sub> sites (as in the pristine structure). All these refinements gave similar fits to the data (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S16</a>), with a marginal improvement for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration out of the original TM sites. While we note that this migration is not conclusive based on the <i>ex situ</i> XRD results, the presence of Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the tetrahedral sites of the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layers is consistent with the formation of a <i>Z</i> phase as it is hypothesized that <i>Z</i>-phase materials may be stabilized by TM migration <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref79" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref79" aria-label="reference 79">(79)</a> and only form where P-type layers have been desodiated and undergo layer slippage to become O-type. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref30" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref30" aria-label="reference 30">(30)</a> This proposed Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration is explored below <i>via</i> calculations.</div><div class="NLM_p">The <i>operando</i> and <i>ex situ</i> diffraction patterns along stage 3 (discharge) initially remained essentially the same between points C5 and D1, suggesting no significant structural changes. However, the relative proportions of the O2 and OP4 phases changed slightly, with the OP4 phase growing at the expense of the O2 phase, perhaps indicating a “relaxation” of the structure, <i>via</i> layer slippage of some of the O-type layers back to P-type due to the small amount of Na<sup>+</sup> (0.03 equivalents) inserted back into NMMO (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>b).</div><div class="NLM_p">After point D1, the low intensity (002) peak from the P2 phase grows in intensity and moves to a higher <i>Q</i>, toward the low-<i>Q</i> peaks of the OP4 and O2 phases (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figures </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>c and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S5</a>). Eventually, the low-<i>Q</i> peaks of the O2, OP4, and P2 phases merge, with the P2 component growing at the expense of the O2 and OP4 components. At the end of discharge, the P2 phase dominates, with no OP4 and only a negligible amount of O2 present; we attribute any remaining O2 phase to small domains of the O2 phase trapped within a P2 matrix. All peaks in the diffraction pattern at the end of the first discharge are broader than those observed in the pristine material and in the early stages of charge, likely due to the decrease in crystallinity (loss of long-range ordering) and development of stacking faults induced by electrochemical cycling. Furthermore, the superstructure peaks seen in pristine NMMO do not return, indicating the loss of more long-range ordering beyond the P2 cell used in the structural refinements.</div><div class="NLM_p last">We also note that the (100) peak of the P2 phase—which indicates the presence of ordering across the Mg/Mn sublattice— significantly decreases in intensity (compared to the pristine material) on cycling, indicating that the loss of Mg/Mn ordering during charge is not regained on discharge; this is consistent with Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figures </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>e and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S4d</a>).</div></div><div id="sec3_3" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i18" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i18"> Extended X-ray Absorption Fine Structure</h3><div class="NLM_p">To examine the changes in the structure during electrochemical cycling further, we carried out <i>ex situ</i> Mn <i>K</i>-edge EXAFS analysis on NMMO at points C0, C2, C5, and D3 along the voltage profile (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">4</a>). The EXAFS plots show four significant features (I–IV, <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig4" id="" class=" internalNav">4</a>), which were fitted to single- and double-scattering paths (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figures S17–S20</a>). Data collected at the C0, C2, and D3 states were fitted against paths derived from a P2 structure only (with all Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the octahedral sites in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers), while data from C5 were fitted against paths from both OP4 and O2 structures to reflect the dominant phase fractions at each of these states of charge. Again, we explored models for the OP4 and O2 phases, where Mg remained in its original location in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer or Mg<sup>2+</sup> occupied either tetrahedral or octahedral sites in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layers. In all cases, path calculations were carried out on (2 × 2 × 2) supercells of the dominant phase(s) at those states of charge; the lattice parameters for these supercells were taken from <i>ex situ</i> Rietveld refinements of the XRD data at the same state of charge. The fitted Debye–Waller factors and effective scattering distances for the dominant single-scattering paths from each element, X, (X = O, Mn, Mg, and Na), are presented in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Table S1</a>.</div><figure id="fig4" data-index="4" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 4</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0005.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0005.jpeg" id="gr4" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 4. <i>Ex situ</i> Mn <i>K</i>-edge EXAFS data for NMMO at different states of charge, showing the four most prominent features in the data up to <i>r</i> = 4.8 Å.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0005.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig4"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">In all cases, feature I is dominated by scattering from O and feature II is dominated by scattering from Mn and Mg. Feature III is dominated by scattering from Na in all cases except at C5, where scattering from Mg<sup>2+</sup> dominates. Feature IV is composed of a combination of several scattering paths.</div><div class="NLM_p">Between C0 and C2, the effective Mn–O distance in NMMO decreases, as expected for Mn–O oxidation. In addition, the Mn–Mn distance increases between C0 and C2, likely due to the increase in the Coulombic repulsion between Mn centers (see the <a class="ref internalNav" href="#sec4" aria-label="Discussion">Discussion</a> section). At the same time, the Mn–Mg distance decreases, likely due to the contraction of the Mn–O bonds induced by Mn oxidation.</div><div class="NLM_p">On charging along the high-voltage plateau (<i>i.e.</i>, C2 to C5), the Mn–O distance continues to decrease in both the OP4 and O2 phases, again due to Mn–O oxidation. The intra-TMO<sub>2</sub>-layer Mn–Mn and Mn–Mg scattering distances also decrease in the OP4 and O2 phases, reflecting the shortened Mn–O bonds.</div><div class="NLM_p">As can be seen in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S21</a>, a noticeable improvement to the fit of feature III is seen on migration of Mg<sup>2+</sup> into either the vacant tetrahedral or octahedral sites of the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layers. While not conclusive of Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration, they provide additional support for the vacation of the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers by Mg<sup>2+</sup>.</div><div class="NLM_p">Finally, between the end of the first charge (C5) and the discharged (D3) states, the Mn–O distance returns to almost the same value as that of the pristine material, as expected for similar Na<sup>+</sup> contents and Mn–O oxidation states. The Mn–Mn and Mn–Mg distances increase between C5 and D3 and, like the Mn–O distance, return to similar values to those in pristine NMMO.</div><div class="NLM_p last">In contrast to the other scattering paths, the Mn–Na scattering distance continually decreases from C0 to C2 to D3; we attribute this decrease to a change in the equilibrium Na<sup>+</sup> position (see the <a class="ref internalNav" href="#sec4" aria-label="Discussion">Discussion</a> section). At point C5, scattering paths involving Na make no contribution to the EXAFS data observed, reflecting the low Na<sup>+</sup> content in NMMO. Furthermore, the Debye–Waller factor for paths involving Na is significantly larger than those for O, Mn, and Mg, which likely reflects the comparatively high mobility and disorder of the Na<sup>+</sup> ions.</div></div><div id="sec3_4" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i19" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i19"> NMR Spectroscopy</h3><div class="NLM_p">Having established the changes in the bulk structure during the first charge/discharge cycles of NMMO, we next went on to examine the local structural evolution using <i>ex situ</i><sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectroscopy (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">5</a>). Pristine NMMO exhibits three overlapping resonances at 1525, 1430, and 1360 ppm, confirmed in pjMATPASS experiments; this also confirmed that no additional resonances are hidden underneath the sidebands (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figures S22 and S23</a>).</div><figure id="fig5" data-index="5" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 5</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0006.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0006.jpeg" id="gr5" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 5. <i>Ex situ</i><sup>23</sup>Na Hahn-Echo NMR spectra recorded for NMMO at different states of charge during the first charge–discharge cycle. Asterisks and daggers lie above or to the right-hand side of spinning sideband or diamagnetic impurity peaks, respectively. All spectra are normalized by the sample mass and number of scans; the intensities of the spectra at points C1, C5, and D1 have been increased to make the spectra more visible. The factor of these increases is shown to the right of these spectra; note that this has also increased the noise relative to other states of charge.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0006.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig5"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">As depicted in the <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a> (Figures S28–S30), the hyperfine shifts calculated using the bond pathway analysis for the model P2 material Na<sub>2/3</sub>[Mg<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>2/3</sub>]O<sub>2</sub> (containing Mn<sup>4+</sup> and no Mn<sup>3+</sup>) and the methodology outlined in previous publications <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref39 ref40 ref41" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref39 ref40 ref41" aria-label="reference 39 to 41">(39−41)</a> range from −190 ppm to 3000 ppm, assuming a random arrangement of Mg<sup>2+</sup> and Mn<sup>4+</sup> ions, with these shifts depending on the number of Mg<sup>2+</sup> and Mn<sup>4+</sup> ions in the local coordination shells and on the Na–O–Mn bond angles (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figures S28, S29, and S30; Tables S3 and S4</a>). Despite using the same basis sets and procedures as those run for similar layered NIB cathode materials, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref80" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref80" aria-label="reference 80">(80)</a> none of the calculated shifts of the P(2b) sites matched the observed resonances. The effect of second-order quadrupolar coupling on the shift, width, and shape of the peak was also accounted for: the calculated parameters lead to a width of approximately 20 ppm (noticeably smaller than the experimentally observed 80 ppm line width) and a shape that did not match the observed spectrum. The quadrupole-induced shifts, when added to the hyperfine shifts calculated, also did not improve the match to the shifts of the observed resonances (see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a>; Table S2).</div><div class="NLM_p">The first explanation for the discrepancy is that the Mg<sup>2+</sup> and Mn<sup>4+</sup> ions are at least partially ordered, as observed via XRD. This hypothesis was tested <i>via</i> a simple honeycomb-ordered model (see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S30, Table S4</a>, and associated text), and now, only four resonances are generated at 1785–2108, 27–179, 591–713, and 1256–1247 ppm (the ranges resulting from the values generated when using different hybrid functionals in the calculations; see the <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a>). In this honeycomb-ordered model, the agreement with the experimental spectrum is better than the random model but still poor.</div><div class="NLM_p">The second explanation for the discrepancies is that the resonances seen experimentally arise from Na<sup>+</sup> ions exchanging between sites within the layers: as observed for other layered NIB and LIB cathodes, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref80 ref81 ref82" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref80 ref81 ref82" aria-label="reference 80 to 82">(80−82)</a> the line shape of the observed spectra for NMMO during charge and discharge will be strongly affected by Na<sup>+</sup> ion mobility on the timescale of the NMR experiment (specifically the <sup>23</sup>Na hyperfine interaction). Hopping during the NMR experiment has two effects: first, the broadening and coalescence of the resonances corresponding to individual <sup>23</sup>Na sites and second, additional spin–spin (<i>T</i><sub>2</sub>) relaxation effects when the hopping frequency and difference in resonant frequencies are similar in size. When hops between sites are fast compared to the difference in the resonant frequencies of these sites, a sharp, coalesced feature is seen at a shift which is the thermodynamic average of the shifts of the sites between which Na<sup>+</sup> ions hop (the fast regime; the thermodynamic average accounts for the relative energies and energy barriers to Na<sup>+</sup> ions hopping between two sites). When hops are slower, either a single, broadened, low-intensity feature is seen (the intermediate regime) or two features corresponding to the two sites between which Na<sup>+</sup> hops are seen (the slow regime).</div><div class="NLM_p">To account for this motional effect, we determined the weighted average of the calculated shifts of the four resonances generated in the ordered honeycomb model (with shifts and probabilities given in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Table S6</a>). This produced shifts between 1307 and 1501 ppm (the range again depending on the choice of the functional), which is in very good agreement with the shifts for the three overlapping resonances seen experimentally and provides further evidence for cation ordering within the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers.</div><div class="NLM_p">To demonstrate the effect of Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion on the NMR timescale, we first attempted room-temperature two-dimensional NMR exchange spectroscopy experiments. These were not successful, likely due to the short relaxation times in this system. We, therefore, carried out variable-temperature <sup>23</sup>Na NMR experiments (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figures S25 and S26</a>), which, for the pristine material, revealed a gradual sharpening of the resonances at higher temperatures and broadening and decrease in intensity at lower temperatures, consistent with Na<sup>+</sup> ions going from the fast regime (at 378 K) to the intermediate regime (at 288 K). Although changes in the relative intensity occur, the resonances do not coalesce at high temperatures, suggesting that not all of the Na<sup>+</sup> ions are exchanged, perhaps because the different resonances correspond to different layers of Na<sup>+</sup> ions, each with different distributions of Mg<sup>2+</sup>, Mn<sup>3+</sup>, and Mn<sup>4+</sup> cations, for example, Na<sup>+</sup> ions sitting in layers with the AA-honeycomb stacking of the nearby TMO<sub>2</sub> layers; Na<sup>+</sup> sitting in layers with the AB-honeycomb stacking; and Na<sup>+</sup> in layers with a “random” arrangement of TM cations in the adjacent TMO<sub>2</sub> layers. Alternatively, Na<sup>+</sup> ions may be in a partially ordered array, perhaps related to the observed superstructure, with each resonance corresponding to three distinct modes of Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion (which depends on the number of vacant Na<sup>+</sup> ion sites nearby). Establishing exactly which sites Na<sup>+</sup> ions hop between and the ordering of TM cations in the adjacent TMO<sub>2</sub> layers—and therefore establishing which resonance corresponds to different Na<sup>+</sup> ion hopping routes—is beyond the scope of this work because it requires detailed analysis and simulation of these variable-temperature spectra and analysis of the energetics of the different hop pathways between the multiple Na environments. Instead, we describe the changes in the <i>ex situ</i><sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra with the state of charge and use these spectra to infer changes in the mobility and local structure. The results are then related to the <i>ex situ</i> XRD and EXAFS data and the Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration calculations in the <a class="ref internalNav" href="#sec4" aria-label="Discussion">Discussion</a> section.</div><div class="NLM_p">The general trend seen on charging from C0 to C4 is a gradual increase in the <sup>23</sup>Na isotropic shift, consistent with other members of the Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>Mg<sub><i>y</i></sub>Mn<sub>1–<i>y</i></sub>O<sub>2</sub> family <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref24" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref24" aria-label="reference 24">(24)</a> and suggestive of a gradual change to the electronic structure of NMMO during the charge (<i>i.e.</i>, Mn oxidation from Mn<sup>3+</sup> to Mn<sup>4+</sup>) and/or a gradual change in the energies of the different Na sites within the layer (causing a gradual change in the exchange-averaged shift). In general, the observed resonances also became sharper during the charge. Exceptions to these trends occur at 2.90 V on the first charge (C1 in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">5</a>) and at the end of the first charge (C5); the spectra for these points have been magnified in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig5" id="" class=" internalNav">5</a> for the sake of clarity. Repeated measurements of all points along the charge–discharge curve were carried out; these also showed the same sharp resonances at C0, C2, C3, and C4 and broad resonances at C1 and C5. We therefore assign these broadened, low-intensity features to slower Na<sup>+</sup> motion (C1 and C5) and/or low Na<sup>+</sup> content (C5) rather than low-quality samples or spectral artefacts. The variable-temperature spectrum of C1 (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S26</a>) shows that a sharp series of resonances emerges at 378 K, consistent with our proposal that the motion at room temperature is slower for this sample than that for C0 and C2–C4. The resonances seen at points C1 and C5 also show a slightly lower shift, likely due to a change in the energy barriers associated with Na<sup>+</sup> ion hopping, which results in both different site occupancies and also Na<sup>+</sup> ions that are not detected in these Hahn-echo experiments (see below).</div><div class="NLM_p">Unlike other members of the Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>Mg<sub><i>y</i></sub>Mn<sub>1–<i>y</i></sub>O<sub>2</sub> family, however, a distinct, broad resonance at 1100 ppm, corresponding to the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> environments of the OP4 phase of Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>Mg<sub><i>y</i></sub>Mn<sub>1–<i>y</i></sub>O<sub>2</sub>, <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref24" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref24" aria-label="reference 24">(24)</a> was not observed for NMMO, suggesting that a distinct (ordered) OP4 phase does not form—which in turn suggests that the <i>Z</i> phase is a more appropriate description of the high-voltage phase. Furthermore, that no discrete peak is observed when OP4 starts to emerge (e.g., in C4) provides compelling evidence that no (or very few) Na<sup>+</sup> ions occupy the O-type layers. It is possible that Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion in the O-type layers of OP4-NMMO are in the intermediate regime, where no distinct resonances are seen, due to the severe broadening of the signal. However, the decrease in intensity seen on charging NMMO from C2 to C5 correlates with the decrease in the P2 phase fraction (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">6</a>), so we assign this signal to Na<sup>+</sup> ions in P-type layers, rather than O-type. Since the phase fraction of P2 is low at the end of first charge (<i>ca.</i> 1%), we attribute this <sup>23</sup>Na NMR resonance to Na<sup>+</sup> ions now in the P-type layers of the <i>Z</i> phase (or in our O2-OP4 surrogate model, the P-type layers of the OP4 phase).</div><figure id="fig6" data-index="6" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 6</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0007.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0007.jpeg" id="gr6" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 6. Variation in the intensity of the isotropic resonances in the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR Hahn-echo spectrum of NMMO samples at the high-voltage charge plateau (the values of <i>x</i> in the legend correspond to the composition Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>), with the inset showing the variation in the P2 phase fraction along the charge plateau (obtained from Rietveld refinement of the <i>ex situ</i> XRD patterns). The spectra were acquired at the same spinning speed and using the same recycle delay, set to at least 5 times the longitudinal relaxation time (<i>i.e.</i>, <i>d</i><sub>1</sub> &gt; 5<i>T</i><sub>1</sub>), and spectra have been scaled by sample mass and the number of scans to allow a quantitative comparison of the intensities.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0007.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig6"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">The shoulders to higher and lower frequencies of the main signal in the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra decrease in intensity during the charge, while the main resonance sharpens and increases in intensity. This phenomenon suggests that there is either preferential Na<sup>+</sup> extraction—with Na<sup>+</sup> ions giving rise to the shoulder peaks being removed before Na<sup>+</sup> ions which give rise to the central resonance—and/or an increase in the relative energies of these sites (leading to a lower population of these Na<sup>+</sup> sites) or that the rate of exchange between the sites increases as the Na<sup>+</sup> ions are extracted. Likely, all these phenomena occur. Of note, the position of the weak signal that remains in the spectrum of C1 coincides with the low-frequency shoulder seen in the C0 spectrum, suggesting that the Na<sup>+</sup> ions corresponding to the high-frequency shoulder and central resonances have entered the intermediate motional regime. The <sup>23</sup>Na signal at C2 is more intense than that at C1, a consequence of faster Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion—<i>i.e.</i>, C1 is in the intermediate regime, while C2 is in the fast regime. The spectrum at C2 also contains weaker shoulder peaks, which weaken as more Na<sup>+</sup> ions are removed. Since the structural changes between C0 and C1 are minor and the (2 × 2 × 1) superstructure reflections are still present in the diffraction patterns of C1 (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S7</a>), the decrease in the <sup>23</sup>Na signal intensity is tentatively associated with increased Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering—possibly enabled by the removal of the first few Na<sup>+</sup> ions on charging—leading to slower overall Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion. It is possible that the broadening of the spectra is also associated with the onset of a disruption of electronic (Mn<sup>3+</sup>/Mn<sup>4+</sup>) ordering that likely occurs around this composition.</div><div class="NLM_p last">On discharge, the isotropic resonances remain broad, suggesting slower Na<sup>+</sup> motion on discharge than that on charge, possibly related to residual Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions in the Na<sup>+</sup> layers, as proposed based on diffraction results and explored computationally below. The features observed on discharge are also likely broadened due to the presence of stacking faults and increased structural disorder at short length scales, as observed in XRD. The observed resonances for these states of charge also remain at slightly higher shifts than those seen on charge, indicating different local environments and hopping barriers for Na<sup>+</sup> ions, which perhaps correspond to Na<sup>+</sup> ions in O-type layers with residual Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions present and/or Na<sup>+</sup> ions in P-type environments whose electronic structure differs from the original P2 phase.</div></div><div id="sec3_5" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i20" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i20"> Calculations of Mg<sup>2+</sup> Migration Barriers</h3><div class="NLM_p">While both the <i>ex situ</i> XRD and EXAFS data are consistent with Mg<sup>2+</sup> having migrated to tetrahedral sites in O-type layers, they do not provide conclusive proof. Thus, to identify whether this proposed migration is energetically (thermodynamically and kinetically) feasible, we next calculated the diffusion profiles and activation energy barriers for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration in O-type layers using single-ended TS searches for a series of O2 and OP4 models (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figures </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a> and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S31–S35</a>). While the true structure of NMMO along the charge plateau is a <i>Z</i> phase, it was not possible to run TS searches over the length scale required to adequately define a <i>Z</i>-phase unit cell; therefore, we have again focused on the separate O2 and OP4 layer slabs which make up the <i>Z</i> phase by performing calculations on (2 × 2 × 1) supercells of the O2 and OP4 phases.</div><figure id="fig7" data-index="7" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 7</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0008.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0008.jpeg" id="gr7" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 7. (a) Schematic Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration mechanism in O2-NMMO, where Mg<sup>2+</sup> moves between an octahedral site in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer (Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub>) and a tetrahedral site in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layer (Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub>). (b) Expanded view of the TS of this mechanism, with the axially coordinated O<sup>2–</sup> ion (which stabilizes the migrating Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the TS), O<sub>ax</sub>, labeled. (c) Energy profiles for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration in O2-NMMO cells with one Na<sup>+</sup> per O-type layer into which Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates (“single Na<sup>+</sup>”) and no Na<sup>+</sup> (“desodiated”) in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layer into which Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates. (d,e) Variation of the activation energy barriers for the migration of Mg<sup>2+</sup> in O2-NMMO from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> and from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub>, respectively, as the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> slab thickness changes. All but one cell size was based on the cell sizes obtained from <i>ex situ</i> XRD Rietveld refinements.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0008.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig7"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">In all cases, the migration pathway consisted of Mg<sup>2+</sup> moving between an octahedrally coordinated site in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer (Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub>) and a tetrahedrally coordinated site in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layer (Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub>) <i>via</i> a TS in which Mg<sup>2+</sup> occupies a trigonal planar (or approximately planar) coordination environment (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>a,b). In all cases, our TS searches revealed that the Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> configuration was considerably lower in energy than the Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> configuration, akin to the selective occupation of tetrahedral Mg<sup>2+</sup> sites in MgMn<sub>2</sub>O<sub>4</sub> spinels. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref61 ref83" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref61 ref83" aria-label="reference 61 and 83">(61,83)</a> The barrier for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration was found to depend on the presence of Na<sup>+</sup> near the migrating Mg<sup>2+</sup>, the lattice parameters of the cell and the presence of stacking faults.</div><div class="NLM_p">In the absence of Na<sup>+</sup>, a typical barrier for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrating from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> was extremely low: approximately 75 meV for the O2 phase and 70 meV for the OP4 phase (for a Na<sup>+</sup> layer slab thickness of 2.3 Å; <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>d and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S32c</a>), indicating that Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration is feasible when the O-type layer into which Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates is empty. The reverse process—Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrating from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub>—has a significantly higher energy barrier: approximately 700 meV for the O2 phase and 500 meV for the OP4 phase, primarily because the final state is higher in energy. When Na<sup>+</sup> occupies the O-type layer (composition Na<sub>0.56</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>), the barrier for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrating from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> increases to at least 110 meV for the O2 phase (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figures </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>c and <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S33</a>) but is still well within the range of overpotentials applied to the material during cycling and results in an overall lowering of the energy of O2-NMMO by approximately 1 eV. The inflexion seen at approximately 50% along the reaction pathway for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrating into the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layer containing one Na<sup>+</sup> (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>c) corresponds to the movement of Na<sup>+</sup> in the O-type layer from its octahedral site into a tetrahedral site (further from the migrated Mg<sup>2+</sup>), with the rest of the path corresponding to the movement of the same Na<sup>+</sup> ion into a new octahedral site further from the migrated Mg<sup>2+</sup>. Most of the Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion occurs after Mg<sup>2+</sup> has migrated; the Na<sup>+</sup> ion moves by less than 0.5 Å (<i>i.e.</i>, less than half of the ionic radius of Na<sup>+</sup> <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref84" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref84" aria-label="reference 84">(84)</a>) as Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates. The increase in both barriers (Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> and vice versa) arises from the increase in Coulombic repulsion between Mg<sup>2+</sup> and the nearby Na<sup>+</sup> in the TS: additional TS searches indicated that as the Mg<sup>2+</sup>–Na<sup>+</sup> distance decreased, the barrier increased significantly (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S33</a>). TS searches with Na<sup>+</sup> in the O-type layer into which Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates could not be converged for the OP4 system, presumably due to the flat potential curve associated with Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration in this system. Searches for the O2 system will also likely have relatively flat potential curves but not so flat that a TS could not be found.</div><div class="NLM_p">To reflect the changes in the O2 and OP4 lattice parameters obtained from <i>ex situ</i> XRD (a consequence of Na<sup>+</sup> deintercalation), we investigated the effect of cell size on the barriers to Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>d,e). While we have plotted changes in the Na<sup>+</sup> layer slab thickness in <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>d,e, we highlight that both the <i>a</i> and <i>c</i> lattice parameters were varied to understand how cell size affects the barriers (<i>i.e.</i>, for each cell size, a separate, fixed-cell calculation was performed). The <i>a</i> and <i>c</i> parameters used were taken from the Rietveld-refined parameters at points C4, C5, D3, and D4, with an extra point with <i>a</i> and <i>c</i> parameters at the average of D1 and D4 (to account for cell sizes between these points) for the O2 phase and points C5, D2, D3, and the average of C4 and D3 (again, chosen to account for the spread of cell sizes observed) for the OP4 phase; these states of charge are indicated on <a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figures </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>, <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">S31, and S32</a>, where appropriate. Note that changes in <i>c</i> dominate changes in the cell size, and thus, our presentation of the results and subsequent discussion will proceed in terms of changes in the Na<sup>+</sup> layer slab thickness for the sake of clarity. For the O2 and OP4 phases, as the Na<sup>+</sup> slab thickness increases, the energy barrier to migration from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> increases approximately linearly (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>b). This likely arises from the loss of stabilization of the trigonally coordinated Mg<sup>2+</sup> TS by the oxygen atom opposite Mg<sup>2+</sup>, O<sub>ax</sub>, due to the increase in the Mg–O<sub>ax</sub> distance. For the thinnest slab, the Mg–O<sub>ax</sub> distance in the Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> configuration was 1.93 Å, while the thickest slab had a Mg–O<sub>ax</sub> distance of 2.41 Å; for comparison, a typical Mg<sub>tet</sub>–O distance is 1.9–2.0 Å (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S31</a>). <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref85 ref86" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref85 ref86" aria-label="reference 85 and 86">(85,86)</a></div><div class="NLM_p">The barrier to migration from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> in the O2 phase initially increased as the Na<sup>+</sup> layer slab thickness increased but then decreased for thicker slabs (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig7" id="" class=" internalNav">7</a>e). We attribute this to the increased stabilization of Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> at intermediate Mg–O<sub>ax</sub> bond lengths: shorter bonds increase electrostatic repulsion, while long bonds have a weaker spatial overlap of orbitals and therefore increase the overall electronic energy. The OP4 phase had thinner Na<sup>+</sup> slabs than the O2 phase so that as the slab thickness increased, the barrier to migration decreased; since the thinner slabs have the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers closer together, it is likely that the decrease in the barrier arises from an increase in the stability of the TS due to less electrostatic repulsion between the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S32</a>). We anticipate similar behavior to that of the O2 phase when these slab sizes are comparable, but calculations on these states could not be converged, again likely due to the shallow potential curves for this system.</div><div class="NLM_p">Finally, when AA/AB stacking faults are introduced (<i>i.e.</i>, when the Mg and Mn positions differ between layers), the activation energies in the O2 phase increase, while the activation energies in the OP4 phase remain approximately constant (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S34</a>).</div><div class="NLM_p">Thus, in the <i>Z</i> phase, which contains a mixture of O2 and OP4 domains, the barriers to Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration are predicted to increase when Na<sup>+</sup> ions occupy the O-type layer, the <i>c</i> axis extends, and when AA/AB stacking faults occur.</div><div class="NLM_p">We also carried out TS searches on the migration process involving Mg<sup>2+</sup> moving from the tetrahedral site in the O-type layer to an adjacent octahedral site in the same O-type layer (since this is the most likely route for Mg<sup>2+</sup> to take to migrate from the octahedral site in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer to the octahedral site in the Na<sup>+</sup> layer). A typical energy barrier for a hop from the tetrahedral site to an octahedral Na<sup>+</sup> site was approximately 900 meV, and that of the reverse (from an octahedral Na<sup>+</sup> site to a tetrahedral site) was approximately 50 meV (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S35</a>), the difference reflecting the 860 meV higher energy associated with the occupancy of the octahedral site in comparison to that of the tetrahedrally coordinated Mg<sup>2+</sup>.</div><div class="NLM_p last">Therefore, our <i>ab initio</i> TS searches reveal that Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration is thermodynamically favorable (<i>i.e.</i>, a lower energy structure is generated) and kinetically accessible (<i>i.e.</i>, it involves a single ion hop whose barrier is within the range of overpotentials applied along the charge plateau of NMMO). Clearly, the bulk and local structures of NMMO change during the first charge–discharge cycle, as seen in <i>operando</i> and <i>ex situ</i> XRD, <i>ex situ</i> EXAFS, and <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra. These changes are the origin of the voltage hysteresis seen in NMMO.</div></div></div><div id="sec4" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i21">Discussion</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><div class="NLM_p">A large voltage hysteresis was observed during the first charge–discharge cycle of NMMO. This voltage hysteresis represents a significant energy loss during electrochemical cycling, which can lead to low efficiencies and lifetimes. To provide strategies that might help mitigate this hysteresis, we have investigated both the bulk and local structural changes taking place in NMMO during the first charge–discharge cycle, where the hysteresis is the greatest; subsequent cycles showed a more sloping voltage profile with a smaller voltage hysteresis (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S3</a>), consistent with many oxygen-redox-based materials. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref87 ref88 ref89 ref90 ref91" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref87 ref88 ref89 ref90 ref91" aria-label="reference 87 to 91">(87−91)</a> The large voltage hysteresis during the first charge–discharge cycle suggests the presence of different phases during charge and discharge, evidence for which is seen in XRD, Mn <i>K</i>-edge EXAFS, and <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra.</div><div id="sec4_1" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i22" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i22"> Bulk and Local Structure of Pristine NMMO</h3><div class="NLM_p last">Pristine NMMO adopts a P2 structure, with Mg<sup>2+</sup> cations showing a preference to sit at TM sites at the corners of the unit cell to form a honeycomb-like arrangement where they are surrounded by Mn<sup>3+/4+</sup> ions only (in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers). All available Na<sup>+</sup> sites in the Na layers are partially occupied, providing pathways and mechanisms for Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion. The <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectrum was consistent with the honeycomb ordering and, furthermore, indicated fast Na<sup>+</sup> ion hopping on the NMR timescale, with resonances observed at shifts which are the thermodynamic average of the shifts of the sites between which Na<sup>+</sup> hops (see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Supporting Information</a> Section 9, Table S6). EXAFS also suggested high Na<sup>+</sup> ion mobility due to the large Debye–Waller factors for Na-based scattering paths.</div></div><div id="sec4_2" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i23" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i23"> Structural Evolution during Charge</h3><div class="NLM_p">During stage 1 (charge from pristine up to 4.22 V vs Na<sup>0/+</sup>), NMMO undergoes a single-phase reaction, with the lattice parameters responding dynamically to Na<sup>+</sup> extraction: the <i>a</i> axis shortens due to Mn–O oxidation, while the <i>c</i> axis lengthens due to the loss of Na<sup>+</sup> ions from between the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers, resulting in greater electrostatic repulsion between the layers (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig8" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig8" id="" class=" internalNav">8</a>a). EXAFS data confirm the decrease in the Mn–O distance, which also leads to a decrease in the Mn–Mg distance. The Mn–Mn distance increases during stage 1, which we attribute to the increased Coulombic repulsion between Mn centers due to the increase in the average oxidation state.</div><figure id="fig8" data-index="8" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 8</h2><button class="figure-viewer__trigger" aria-label="open figure viewer"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0009.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0009.jpeg" id="gr8" class="inline-fig internalNav"></button><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 8. Rietveld-derived lattice parameters for (a) the P2 phase, (b) the OP4 phase, and (c) the O2 phase at different states of charge. Note that the OP4 and O2 phase do not appear until point C4 (highlighted) and the OP4 phase disappears after point D3.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0009.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig8"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><div class="NLM_p">The EXAFS data also indicate a decrease in the Mn–Na distance between points C0 and C2, despite the expansion in the <i>c</i> axis seen in XRD results. We attribute the decrease in this scattering distance to a change in the equilibrium position of Na<sup>+</sup> with respect to the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer. The distance between Mn and its nearest neighbor Na<sup>+</sup> will vary according to the local environment. Each Na<sup>+</sup> P(2d) and P(2b) site can have a different local environment: for example, Na<sup>+</sup> can occupy a P(2b) site which shares two, one, or no faces with Mg<sup>2+</sup>, or it can occupy a P(2d) site with no, 1, 2, 3...up to 12 Mg-nearest neighbors. A decrease in the Mn–Na distance between C0 and C2 suggests that the equilibrium Na<sup>+</sup> position moves closer to Mn.</div><div class="NLM_p">While pristine NMMO shows sharp, distinct resonances in its <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectrum, when charged to 2.90 V (<i>i.e.</i>, point C1), a broad, low-intensity feature is seen, suggesting slower Na<sup>+</sup> hopping compared to that of the pristine material, perhaps due to partial Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering. The composition at C1 is <i>x</i> ≈ 5/8. As NMMO has six Na<sup>+</sup> sites per Na<sup>+</sup> layer per unit cell, ordering schemes consistent with this composition correspond to a Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering schemes over four unit cells with 15 Na<sup>+</sup> sites occupied, examples of which are illustrated in <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S37</a>. Once formed, the energy barrier to Na<sup>+</sup> hopping will increase as any move away from the low-energy, ordered array of Na<sup>+</sup> ions and vacancies (<i>i.e.</i>, the local thermodynamic minimum) will increase the total electrostatic repulsion between Na<sup>+</sup> ions. This will lead to slower Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion (<i>i.e.</i>, the intermediate regime) and broad <sup>23</sup>Na NMR resonance. Indeed, vacancy ordering at <i>x</i> = 5/8 is known to occur readily in Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>MnO<sub>2</sub> (the parent material). <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref92 ref93" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref92 ref93" aria-label="reference 92 and 93">(92,93)</a> At this point, a sharp peak in the d<i>Q</i>/d<i>V</i> profile is also seen (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig3" id="" class=" internalNav">3</a>f), likely corresponding to Mn<sup>3+</sup> oxidation, perhaps indicating (some) degree of Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering. No new peaks (corresponding to a new superstructure) were, however, observed in the <i>ex situ</i> and <i>operando</i> XRD data, but the pristine superstructure peaks remained.</div><div class="NLM_p">On charging to point C2 (the beginning of the charge plateau), the composition reaches <i>x</i> ≈ 0.54, corresponding to 13 Na<sup>+</sup> per layer of four unit cells; here, sharp resonances are seen, consistent with fast motion, due to the increase in the number of Na<sup>+</sup> vacancies. The faster Na<sup>+</sup> motion is also reflected in the Debye–Waller factors for the Mn–Na scattering paths, which increase between the beginning (C0) and the end (C2) of stage 1.</div><div class="NLM_p">Stage 2 comprises the voltage plateau during charge. While a flat voltage region should reflect a two-phase reaction, evidence for this is not observed in <i>ex situ</i> or <i>operando</i> XRD spectra until over halfway along the plateau (point C4), where a new, broad peak is observed, corresponding to reflections from the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers in the <i>Z</i> phase (a disordered intergrowth of the O2 and OP4 phases). In the <i>Z</i>-phase material, the O-type layers are Na<sup>+</sup>-deficient—as seen in the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra, which contain signals from the P-type layers only (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig6" id="" class=" internalNav">6</a>)—and, on the basis of the calculations, contain migrated Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions in tetrahedral sites.</div><div class="NLM_p">During stage 2, XRD refinement of the P2 phase reveals a decrease in the <i>a</i> axis (again consistent with Mn–O oxidation) and an initial increase in the <i>c</i> axis, followed by a sharp decrease at the end of charge (point C5). Likewise, the O2 and OP4 phases show a decrease in the <i>a</i> and <i>c</i> axes from point C4 to C5 (<a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig8" id="" class=" internalNav">Figure </a><a data-tab="pane-pcw-Figures" href="#fig8" id="" class=" internalNav">8</a>b,c). The initial increase in <i>c</i> for the P2 phase continues the trend seen in stage 1: loss of Na<sup>+</sup> decreases the shielding of negative charges on the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers, resulting in greater electrostatic repulsion between the layers. The large decrease in <i>c</i> for the O2 and OP4 phases at the end of charge may reflect the same phenomenon as that seen in layered LIB materials, where a “collapse” of the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers has been seen. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref81 ref94 ref95" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref81 ref94 ref95" aria-label="reference 81, 94 and 95">(81,94,95)</a> However, here, an additional cause of the collapse in <i>c</i> at these high voltages is ascribed (at least in part) to Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration as the charges on the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers will be effectively shielded by Mg<sup>2+</sup>; we also anticipate that the small tetrahedral Mg<sup>2+</sup> (compared to octahedral Na<sup>+</sup>) will facilitate layer collapse. Therefore, we expect that the high voltage capacity observed in NMMO is coupled with Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration, analogous to metal cation migration seen in some O-redox-active LIB cathodes. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref91 ref96" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref91 ref96" aria-label="reference 91 and 96">(91,96)</a></div><div class="NLM_p">The Mn <i>K</i>-edge EXAFS data also revealed a decrease in the Mn–O distance along the charge plateau, as well as the presence of Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layers at the end of the first charge.</div><div class="NLM_p">Despite the nucleation and growth of the <i>Z</i> phase along the high-voltage plateau, no new <sup>23</sup>Na NMR resonances are observed, suggesting that the remaining Na<sup>+</sup> ions in the <i>Z</i> phase reside primarily in the residual P-type layers, where the local environments remain essentially the same as those in P2-NMMO; this also confirms the observation that no Na<sup>+</sup> scattering contributes to the EXAFS at point C5. The slight increase in the isotropic <sup>23</sup>Na NMR shift seen along the charge plateau, as well as the sharpening of the resonances along this plateau, most likely arises from an increase in Na<sup>+</sup> ion mobility in the P-type layers and residual Mn oxidation.</div><div class="NLM_p last">The <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra showed a decrease in the intensity of the shoulder peaks during charge (C2 to C5), while the central resonance becomes sharper and more intense, suggesting that Na<sup>+</sup> is preferentially extracted from the sites that give rise to the shoulder peaks and/or the remaining Na<sup>+</sup> ions spend more time hopping between the sites which correspond to the central resonance. The shoulders could also arise from differences in the honeycomb stacking between the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers (as seen in Li<sub>2</sub>MnO<sub>3</sub>, e.g. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref97" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref97" aria-label="reference 97">(97)</a>), with Na<sup>+</sup> ions being more readily extracted from some stacking sequences.</div></div><div id="sec4_3" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i24" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i24"> Structural Evolution during Discharge</h3><div class="NLM_p">The beginning of discharge consists of a sharp decrease in voltage (from 4.5 V to approximately 3.8 V) with little change in Na<sup>+</sup> content. We ascribe this drop in voltage to the reversal in the sign of the internal resistance (<i>iR</i> drop) and reversal of the sign of overpotentials between charge and discharge, as seen in additional galvanostatic intermittent titration technique (GITT) data (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S39</a>), along with the onset of sodiation.</div><div class="NLM_p">Between points C5 and D1 (the beginning of stage 3), very little change in the diffraction patterns and <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra are seen; the O2 and OP4 lattice parameters also remain approximately constant, but the phase fraction of OP4 increases at the expense of the O2 phase, suggesting that some rearrangement of the O-type and P-type layers in the <i>Z</i> phase takes place, which is likely a “relaxation” of the structure. Since a small amount of Na<sup>+</sup> is inserted into NMMO between C5 and D1 (approximately 0.03 equivalents), some O-type layers may transform back to become P-type, thereby increasing the fraction of the OP4 phase. As both electrodes were relaxed for at least 1 h after charging (C5) or discharging (D1), we anticipate these rearrangements to occur during discharge, rather than during the rest period.</div><div class="NLM_p">The rest of discharge (points D2 to D4 inclusive) is described by a sloping voltage profile, suggesting single-phase Na<sup>+</sup> insertion. The <i>ex situ</i> and <i>operando</i> diffraction patterns indicate a gradual increase in the P2 phase fraction at the expense of the O2 and OP4 phases, suggesting that the <i>Z</i> phase gradually transforms back into the P2 phase, presumably <i>via</i> insertion of Na<sup>+</sup> into the O-type layers and subsequent slippage of these O-type layers to become P-type.</div><div class="NLM_p">Furthermore, the <i>a</i> lattice parameter for all phases increases throughout discharge, and at point D3 (whose composition is approximately <i>x</i> = 0.66), the Mn–O scattering distance returns to almost the same length as that in the pristine material. The <i>c</i> lattice parameter for the P2, OP4, and O2 phases also increases initially on discharge due to insertion of the large Na<sup>+</sup> ions; in the case of the O2 phase, this expansion is very large, presumably because the O-type layers were devoid of Na<sup>+</sup> on charge but must accommodate the large Na<sup>+</sup> ions on discharge—<i>i.e.</i>, the Na<sup>+</sup> layers dominate the expansion in <i>c</i> for the O2 phase. In the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectrum, a set of broad, overlapping resonances are seen between 1380 and 1650 ppm. Since the O2 and OP4 phase fractions at D3 are approximately 1.0(10) and 0.5(10)%, respectively, we do not anticipate that the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> environments in these phases will contribute significantly to the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectrum observed. We ascribe the broadening of these resonances and the low intensity in part to the low crystallinity and wide distribution of local environments and also to the relatively slow Na<sup>+</sup> hopping.</div><div class="NLM_p">By point D3, the <i>c</i> axis for the P2 (98.5(2)% phase fraction) and OP4 (1.00(10)%) phases begins to decrease, while for the O2 phase (0.51(14)%), <i>c</i> remains approximately constant. The contraction in <i>c</i> for the P2 and OP4 phases likely originates from the large number of Na<sup>+</sup> ions between the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers: as more Na<sup>+</sup> ions are inserted between the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers, the repulsive electrostatic interactions decrease, enabling the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers to move closer together, in a fashion analogous to that of layered LIB cathodes. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref81" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref81" aria-label="reference 81">(81)</a> These repulsive interactions are anticipated to be greatest in the P-type layers, where O<sup>2–</sup> anions are eclipsed rather than staggered; as a result, the P2 phase contracts the most, followed by OP4, while the O2 phase sees little change in <i>c</i>.</div><div class="NLM_p">By the end of stage 3 (points D3 and D4), negligible amounts of the O2 and OP4 phases remain, suggesting that most of the <i>Z</i> phase has transformed back to a P2-like phase, with residual O-type layers “trapped” as stacking faults. These stacking faults are also captured in the (002) reflection, which is broader and lower in intensity than that of P2-NMMO during stages 1 and 2.</div><div class="NLM_p">In addition to the residual O-type layers, the P2 phase generated on discharge is more disordered compared to the P2 phase on charge, as suggested from the broadened Bragg peaks. The (100) reflection—diagnostic of ordering over the TM sublattice—has a much lower intensity than that on charge, indicating that the partial honeycomb order in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers of pristine NMMO is lost on cycling. The origin of this loss of order is likely from residual Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions in O-type layers (and therefore vacancies in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers). An additional source of disorder may also arise from inter- and intralayer Mn<sup><i>n</i>+</sup> migration, where Mn<sup><i>n</i>+</sup> cations move from their octahedral sites in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer to neighboring vacant octahedral sites also in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers, created from Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration. When Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates back to the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer on discharge—most likely driven by electrostatic repulsion from Na<sup>+</sup> being inserted into these O-type layers—it must move into the new vacant site created by Mn<sup><i>n</i>+</sup> migration, which disrupts the partial Mn/Mg honeycomb order seen in the pristine material.</div><div class="NLM_p">The increase in the structural disorder of NMMO during discharge is also borne out in the EXAFS data: the Mn–O, Mn–Mn, and Mn–Mg scattering distances at point D3 return to similar values to those of the pristine material but with much larger Debye–Waller factors, indicating greater variability (<i>i.e.</i>, more disorder) in these distances. The Mn–Na distance at D3, however, is significantly shorter than that in the pristine material, suggesting a change in the equilibrium position for Na<sup>+</sup>. This is reflected in the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectra during stage 3, where broad, low-intensity features are observed at shifts that are slightly higher than those observed on charge—indicating different local <sup>23</sup>Na environments, greater local disorder, and slower Na<sup>+</sup> ion motion. By the end of the first discharge, the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR spectrum becomes severely broadened due to the large distribution of local sites which are occupied.</div><div class="NLM_p last">Our <i>ab initio</i> single-ended TS searches show that the barrier for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> back into the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer is significantly larger than the barrier for migration into Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> sites. Therefore, the thermodynamic driving force required for Mg<sup>2+</sup> to migrate back to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> will be larger than that required for Mg<sup>2+</sup> to migrate into the Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet</sub> sites, suggesting that on discharge, Mg<sup>2+</sup> will not migrate back to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> at the same potentials that Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrated to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> on charge. Consequently, we expect Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration to contribute to the observed voltage hysteresis.</div></div><div id="sec4_4" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_2"><div id="ac_i25" class="anchor-spacer"></div><h3 class="article-section__title" id="_i25"> Implication of Results and Outlook</h3><div class="NLM_p">Recent studies on Li-rich NMC layered cathodes <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref96" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref96" aria-label="reference 96">(96)</a> and on layered Li<sub>2</sub>Sn<sub><i>y</i></sub>Ir<sub>1–<i>y</i></sub>O<sub>3</sub> cathodes <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref91" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref91" aria-label="reference 91">(91)</a> have suggested that metal migration and de-coordination (or undercoordination) of oxide anions during charge may promote oxygen redox and stabilize oxidized oxide ion species, for example, by forming TM–O π bonds. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref91 ref96 ref98" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref91 ref96 ref98" aria-label="reference 91, 96 and 98">(91,96,98)</a> Our results suggest that Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration likely plays a significant role in the charge–discharge behavior of NMMO: not only does it affect Na<sup>+</sup> hopping kinetics, but it also influences the bulk structure of NMMO, which in turn will likely influence the electronic structure and the ability of NMMO to stabilize oxidized O species. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref99" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref99" aria-label="reference 99">(99)</a></div><div class="NLM_p">In previous studies, the ionic bonds between Mg<sup>2+</sup> and O<sup>2–</sup> were proposed to generate high-energy electronic states on O which could be readily depopulated to give O redox. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref28" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref28" aria-label="reference 28">(28)</a> If Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates into the Na<sup>+</sup> O-type layers, however, we anticipate the Mg–O bond to become much more covalent in character and for some of the O<sup>2–</sup> ligands to become underbonded. In the regions of the material where the Mn<sup><i>n</i>+</sup> and Mg<sup>2+</sup> ions are honeycomb-ordered, the migration of Mg<sup>2+</sup> will generate “rings” of Mn<sup><i>n</i>+</sup> ions in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer, which may enable redox-active delocalized π systems to form, akin to those proposed by Kitchaev and co-workers as the source of high voltage capacity seen in some supposed O redox materials. <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref100" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref100" aria-label="reference 100">(100)</a></div><div class="NLM_p">The results presented here highlight that the suppression of Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration through careful material design—for example, by using dopants in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layers which have strong octahedral site preference (such as Ni<sup>2+</sup> and Cr<sup>3+</sup>) or using dopants with large cationic radii (such as Sr<sup>2+</sup>) to encourage “pillaring” throughout the structure <a href="javascript:void(0);" class="ref ref101" id="referenceLink" data-rid="ref101" aria-label="reference 101">(101)</a> —may be important for decreasing the hysteresis in this promising class of high-capacity NIB cathodes.</div><div class="NLM_p last">Future <sup>25</sup>Mg NMR and theoretical studies of the effect of Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration on the chemical and electronic structure of NMMO will be carried out to review the ionicity and covalency of both the Mg–O and Mn–O interactions to assess the extent to which O redox behavior and Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration are coupled.</div></div></div><div id="sec5" class="NLM_sec NLM_sec_level_1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i26">Conclusions</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><div class="NLM_p">In this work, we have presented the bulk and local structural changes which take place during the first charge–discharge cycle of a layered NIB cathode, Na<sub>0.67</sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>, NMMO.</div><div class="NLM_p">On charging NMMO, we observed single-phase Na<sup>+</sup> extraction, followed by a two-phase reaction between the P2 and <i>Z</i> phases.
