The <i>Z</i> phase may be described as an intergrowth of O2 and OP4 phases and is generated by TMO<sub>2</sub> layer slippage in the P2 phase to form O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layers interspersed with P-type layers, with little crystallographic order from layer to layer. The <i>Z</i> phase is stabilized by Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration to the tetrahedral sites in the O-type layers, as identified in the <i>ab initio</i> TS searches, the barrier for which is affected by changes in the lattice parameters, the presence of Na<sup>+</sup>, and the presence of stacking faults. This is the first report of <i>Z</i> phase formation and evidence for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration in this material.</div><div class="NLM_p">During charge, we also observed a general increase in the Na<sup>+</sup> mobility along the high-voltage charge plateau—due to an increase in the <i>c</i> axis (<i>i.e.</i>, an increase in the Na<sup>+</sup> layer slab width) as well as an increase in the number of Na<sup>+</sup> vacancies—and a gradual change in the electronic structure of NMMO.</div><div class="NLM_p">On discharge, NMMO undergoes single-phase Na<sup>+</sup> insertion into the <i>Z</i> phase. As Na<sup>+</sup> vacancies are filled, layer slippage from O- to P-type layers takes place, eventually forming a P2-like phase at the end of discharge. This P2-like phase retains a few O-type layers and has a lower Na<sup>+</sup> mobility compared to the material on charge, which we attribute to the presence of residual Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the Na<sup>+</sup> layers, giving rise to additional disorder in the P2-type phase formed on discharge.</div><div class="NLM_p last">The distinct phases that form during charge and discharge result in the large voltage hysteresis observed and likely stem from the asymmetric energy profile associated with Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration. The role of Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration on both the Na<sup>+</sup> ion mobility and the changes in electronic structure—and potentially anion redox—will be the focus of future studies.</div></div><div class="NLM_back"><div class="article_supporting-info" id="notes1"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="_i27">Supporting Information</h2><div class="article__copy"><button class="article__copy__btn"><i class="article__copy__icon icon-copy-solid" aria-hidden="true"></i></button><span class="article__copy__text">Click to copy section link</span><span class="article__copy__success">Section link copied!</span></div></div></div></div><hr><p class="last">The Supporting Information is available free of charge at <a href="/doi/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248?goto=supporting-info" class="ext-link">https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248</a>.</p><ul class="NLM_list-list_type-label" id="silist"><li><p class="inline">Detailed experimental, additional pristine and <i>ex situ</i> XRD Rietveld refinements, TEM results, additional electrochemical results, Mn <i>K</i>-edge EXAFS fits, additional TS search results, additional <sup>23</sup>Na NMR results, details about the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR shift calculations, magnetic susceptibility results, Na<sup>+</sup>/vacancy ordering schemes for NMMO, and GITT results (<a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">PDF</a>)</p></li></ul><p></p><div class="supInfoBoxOnFTP "><div class="sup-info-attachments"><ul><li><a class="suppl-anchor" href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf">cm1c00248_si_001.pdf (4.76 MB)</a></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="testing" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248" data-url="https://widgets.figshare.com/static/figshare.js" id="figshare-widget"></div><div class="TermsAndConditionsDropzone3" of Chemistry, University of Cambridge, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 1EW, United

    <span class="author-orcid"><img height="20" width="27" src="/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/orchid-2856f829046fbda55b90e1582edf0e9a.png" alt="Orcid"><a href="https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4339-7282" title="Orcid link">https://orcid.org/0000-0003-4339-7282</a></span></div></li><li><div class="authorItemInformation"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor strong">Michael A. Jones</span> - <span class="hlFld-Affiliation affiliation">Department
of Chemistry, University of Cambridge, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 1EW, United
Kingdom</span>;&nbsp;
    <span class="author-orcid"><img height="20" width="27" src="/products/achs/releasedAssets/images/orchid-2856f829046fbda55b90e1582edf0e9a.png" alt="Orcid"><a href="https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6730-9964" title="Orcid link">https://orcid.org/0000-0002-6730-9964</a></span></div></li><li><div class="authorItemInformation"><span class="hlFld-ContribAuthor strong">Jeongjae Lee</span> - <span class="hlFld-Affiliation affiliation">Department
of Chemistry, University of Cambridge, Lensfield Road, Cambridge CB2 1EW, United
Kingdom</span>;&nbsp;
    <span class="hlFld-Affiliation affiliation">School

        </p><ol id="references" class="useLabel"><li id="ref1"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref1" class="refNumLink">1</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit1" data-doi="10.1002/adfm.201200691"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Slater, M. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Johnson, C. S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Adv. Funct. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>23</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">947</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">958</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/adfm.201200691</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D23%26publication_year%3D2013%26pages%3D947-958%26journal%3DAdv.%2BFunct.%2BMater.%26author%3DM.%2BD.%2BSlater%26author%3DD.%2BKim%26author%3DE.%2BLee%26author%3DC.%2BS.%2BJohnson%26title%3DSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fadfm.201200691&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fadfm.201200691&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit1R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">1</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Slater, Michael D.; Kim, Donghan; Lee, Eungje; Doeff, Marca; Johnson, Christopher S.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Advanced Functional Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">23</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">947-958</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AFMDC6</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1616-301X</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  The status of ambient temp. sodium ion batteries is reviewed in light of recent developments in anode, electrolyte and cathode materials.  These devices, although early in their stage of development, are promising for large-scale grid storage applications due to the abundance and very low cost of sodium-contg. precursors used to make the components.  The engineering knowledge developed recently for highly successful Li ion batteries can be leveraged to ensure rapid progress in this area, although different electrode materials and electrolytes will be required for dual intercalation systems based on sodium.  In particular, new anode materials need to be identified, since the graphite anode, commonly used in lithium systems, does not intercalate sodium to any appreciable extent.  A wider array of choices is available for cathodes, including high performance layered transition metal oxides and polyanionic compds.  Recent developments in electrodes are encouraging, but a great deal of research is necessary, particularly in new electrolytes, and the understanding of the SEI films.  The engineering modeling calcns. of Na-ion battery energy d. indicate that 210 Wh kg-1 in gravimetric energy is possible for Na-ion batteries compared to existing Li-ion technol. if a cathode capacity of 200 mAh g-1 and a 500 mAh g-1 anode can be discovered with an av. cell potential of 3.3 V.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref2"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref2" class="refNumLink">2</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit2" data-doi="10.1039/c2ee02781j"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palomares, V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Serras, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Villaluenga, I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hueso, K. B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carretero-González, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Na-Ion Batteries, Recent Advances and Present Challenges to Become Low Cost Energy Storage Systems</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2012</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>5</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">5884</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c2ee02781j</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D5%26publication_year%3D2012%26pages%3D5884%26journal%3DEnergy%2BEnviron.%2BSci.%26author%3DV.%2BPalomares%26author%3DP.%2BSerras%26author%3DI.%2BVillaluenga%26author%3DK.%2BB.%2BHueso%26author%3DJ.%2BCarretero-Gonz%25C3%25A1lez%26author%3DT.%2BRojo%26title%3DNa-Ion%2BBatteries%252C%2BRecent%2BAdvances%2Band%2BPresent%2BChallenges%2Bto%2BBecome%2BLow%2BCost%2BEnergy%2BStorage%2BSystems%26doi%3D10.1039%252Fc2ee02781j&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2Fc2ee02781j&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit2R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">2</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Na-ion batteries, recent advances and present challenges to become low cost energy storage systems</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Palomares, Veronica; Serras, Paula; Villaluenga, Irune; Hueso, Karina B.; Carretero-Gonzalez, Javier; Rojo, Teofilo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2012</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">5</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5884-5901</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Energy prodn. and storage have become key issues concerning our welfare in daily life.  Present challenges for batteries are twofold.  In the first place, the increasing demand for powering systems of portable electronic devices and zero-emission vehicles stimulates research towards high energy and high voltage systems.  In the second place, low cost batteries are required in order to advance towards smart elec. grids that integrate discontinuous energy flow from renewable sources, optimizing the performance of clean energy sources.  Na-ion batteries can be the key for the second point, because of the huge availability of sodium, its low price and the similarity of both Li and Na insertion chemistries.  In spite of the lower energy d. and voltage of Na-ion based technologies, they can be focused on applications where the wt. and footprint requirement is less drastic, such as elec. grid storage.  Much work has to be done in the field of Na-ion in order to catch up with Li-ion technol.  Cathodic and anodic materials must be optimized, and new electrolytes will be the key point for Na-ion success.  This review will gather the up-to-date knowledge about Na-ion battery materials, with the aim of providing a wide view of the systems that have already been explored and a starting point for the new research on this battery technol.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref3"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref3" class="refNumLink">3</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit3" data-doi="10.1039/c3ee41031e"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palomares, V.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Casas-Cabanas, M.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Castillo-Martínez, E.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Han, M.                         cas_cit5R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">5</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Research Development on Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Kubota, Kei; Dahbi, Mouad; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemical Reviews (Washington, DC, United States)</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review of sodium-ion battery technol.  Future outlook of sodium-ion batteries is discussed.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref6"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref6" class="refNumLink">6</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit6" data-doi="10.1016/j.ensm.2020.04.040"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gao, R.-M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zheng, Z.-J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, P.-F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, C.-Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ye, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Cao, F.-F.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Recent Advances and Prospects of Layered Transition Metal Oxide Cathodes for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Energy Storage Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>30</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">9</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">26</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.ensm.2020.04.040</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D30%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D9-26%26journal%3DEnergy%2BStorage%2BMater.%26author%3DR.-M.%2BGao%26author%3DZ.-J.%2BZheng%26author%3DP.-F.%2BWang%26author%3DC.-Y.%2BWang%26author%3DH.%2BYe%26author%3DF.-F.%2BCao%26title%3DRecent%2BAdvances%2Band%2BProspects%2Bof%2BLayered%2BTransition%2BMetal%2BOxide%2BCathodes%2Bfor%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.ensm.2020.04.040&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.ensm.2020.04.040&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref7"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref7" class="refNumLink">7</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit7" data-doi="10.1149/2.0201514jes"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Review—Manganese-Based P2-Type Transition Metal Oxides as Sodium-Ion Battery Cathode Materials</span>. <i>J. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>162</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">A2589</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">A2604</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/2.0201514jes</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D162%26publication_year%3D2015%26pages%3DA2589-A2604%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26author%3DR.%2BJ.%2BCl%25C3%25A9ment%26author%3DP.%2BG.%2BBruce%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26title%3DReview%25E2%2580%2594Manganese-Based%2BP2-Type%2BTransition%2BMetal%2BOxides%2Bas%2BSodium-Ion%2BBattery%2BCathode%2BMaterials%26doi%3D10.1149%252F2.0201514jes&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F2.0201514jes&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit7R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">7</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Review-Manganese-Based P2-Type Transition Metal Oxides as Sodium-Ion Battery Cathode Materials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Clement, Raphaele J.; Bruce, Peter G.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">162</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">14</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">A2589-A2604</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Sodium transition metal oxides (NaMO2) with a P2 structure exhibit good Na+ ion cond. and are promising sodium-ion battery cathode materials.  Manganese-based compds. have a high working potential vs. Na+/Na, and high capacity.  Yet, the layered nature of these materials means that they are prone to structural rearrangements at high voltage/low Na contents, the phase transformations and Na+ ion/vacancy ordering transitions resulting in capacity fade and poor reversibility.  This review discusses the latest advances in the field and focuses mainly on recent work on NayMn1-xMxO2 (x, y ≤ 1, M = Ni, Mg, Li) compds.  We compare the different lithium and sodium transition metal layered oxides (P2, O3, etc.) and describe the structures and mechanisms obsd. on alkali (de)intercalation.  The strategies used to enhance the electrochem. properties and stabilize the structural framework of sodium transition metal oxides are reviewed.  We show how X-ray diffraction and 7Li/23Na solid-state NMR can be combined to provide a detailed insight into the structural and electronic processes occurring upon electrochem. cycling of these materials.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref8"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref8" class="refNumLink">8</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit8" data-doi="10.1016/0378-4363(80)90214-4"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Delmas, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fouassier, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hagenmuller, P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Structural Classification and Properties of the Layered Oxides</span>. <i>Phys. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Electrodes with High Power and High Capacity for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries</span>. <i>Science</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2006</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>311</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">977</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">980</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1126/science.1122152</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D311%26publication_year%3D2006%26pages%3D977-980%26journal%3DScience%26author%3DK.%2BKang%26author%3DY.%2BS.%2BMeng%26author%3DJ.%2BBr%25C3%25A9ger%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26author%3DG.%2BCeder%26title%3DElectrodes%2Bwith%2BHigh%2BPower%2Band%2BHigh%2BCapacity%2Bfor%2BRechargeable%2BLithium%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1126%252Fscience.1122152&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1126%2Fscience.1122152&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit9R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">9</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Electrodes with High Power and High Capacity for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kang, Kisuk; Meng, Ying Shirley; Breger, Julien; Grey, Clare P.; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Science (Washington, DC, United States)</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2006</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">311</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">5763</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">977-980</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">SCIEAS</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0036-8075</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Association for the Advancement of Science</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">New applications such as hybrid elec. vehicles and power backup require rechargeable batteries that combine high energy d. with high charge and discharge rate capability.  Using ab initio computational modeling, strategies to design high-rate battery electrodes were identified.  Tests were performed with [Li(Ni0.5Mn0.5)O2], a safe, inexpensive material that probably has poor intrinsic rate capability.  Modification of its crystal structure provided unexpected high-rate capability, better than that of LiCoO2, the battery electrode material of choice.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref10"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref10" class="refNumLink">10</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit10" data-doi="10.1039/b108830k"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Caballero, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hernán, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Morales, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sánchez, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Santos Peña, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Aranda, M. A. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Synthesis and Characterization of High-Temperature Hexagonal P2-Na0.6 MnO2 and Its Electrochemical Behaviour as Cathode in Sodium Cells</span>. <i>J.                         cas_cit10R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">10</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Synthesis and characterization of high-temperature hexagonal P2-Na0.6MnO2 and its electrochemical behaviour as cathode in sodium cells</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Caballero, A.; Hernan, L.; Morales, J.; Sanchez, L.; Santos Pena, J.; Aranda, M. A. G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2002</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1142-1147</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMACEP</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0959-9428</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A layered sodium manganese oxide, Na0.6MnO2, stable at temps. &gt;800°, was synthesized by using a sol-gel method that employs Mn(acac)3 (ac = acetylacetonate), Na2CO3, and propionic acid to form the resin framework.  This layered bronze possesses a hexagonal, P2-type structure, in which the distortion assocd. with Mn3+ is hardly noticeable.  It reacts slowly, though reversibly, with atm. moisture, which causes the interlayer spacing in the structure to increase by ∼2.5 Å, by intercalation of water mols. into the interlayer gap occupied by Na+ ions.  The anhyd. material was tested as a cathode in sodium cells.  Although the electrochem. intercalation of Na+ occurs in two steps, the host retains its main structural features, with a slight tendency in the interlayer spacing to contract as the sodium content increases.  The similarity between the discharge and charge profiles of the first cycles reveals a quasi-reversible nature of the intercalation process and that the cell can deliver a const. sp. capacity of ∼140 A-h/kg at 0.1 mA/cm2 when cycled in a voltage region of 3.8-2.0 V.  However, the continuous strains and distortions resulting from the insertion and extn. of Na+ ions cause the host structure to gradually collapse and yield an amorphous material after the first eight cycles.  This leads to a progressive redn. of the cell capacity, irresp. of the specific voltage region used.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref11"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref11" class="refNumLink">11</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit11" data-doi="10.1007/s100080050138"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Alcántara, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lavela, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tirado, J.                         cas_cit11R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">11</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Recent advances in the study of layered lithium transition metal oxides and their application as intercalation electrodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Alcantara, R.; Lavela, P.; Tirado, J. L.; Zhecheva, E.; Stoyanova, R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Solid State Electrochemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1999</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Springer-Verlag</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review with 131 refs. is presented on the extensive work carried out during the last 30 yr on layered oxides structurally related to LiCoO2 and LiNiO2.  The studies considered here range from the structural and chem. characterization of the layered solids to the detailed evaluation of their aptitude towards lithium deintercalation-intercalation reactions, which form the basis of their successful application in rechargeable battery technol.  The different challenges remaining in this area, such as the development of advanced prepn. procedures and the optimization of the electrochem. performance by controlled changes in compn., structure, and particle morphol., are discussed.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref12"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref12" class="refNumLink">12</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit12" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.201602888"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Radin, M.                 10.1038/s42004-020-0257-6</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D3%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D9%26journal%3DCommun.%2BChem.%26author%3DC.%2BHakim%26author%3DN.%2BSabi%26author%3DL.%2BA.%2BMa%26author%3DM.%2BDahbi%26author%3DD.%2BBrandell%26author%3DK.%2BEdstr%25C3%25B6m%26author%3DL.%2BC.%2BDuda%26author%3DI.%2BSaadoune%26author%3DR.%2BYounesi%26title%3DUnderstanding%2Bthe%2BRedox%2BProcess%2Bupon%2BElectrochemical%2BCycling%2Bof%2Bthe%2BP2-Na0.78Co1%252F2Mn1%252F3Ni1%252F6O2%2BElectrode%2BMaterial%2Bfor%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fs42004-020-0257-6&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fs42004-020-0257-6&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit13R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">13</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Understanding the redox process upon electrochemical cycling of the P2-Na0.78Co1/2Mn1/3Ni1/6O2 electrode material for sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Hakim, Charifa; Sabi, Noha; Ma, Le Anh; Dahbi, Mouad; Brandell, Daniel; Edstrom, Kristina; Duda, Laurent C.; Saadoune, Ismael; Younesi, Reza</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Communications Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">9</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CCOHCT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2399-3669</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Rechargeable sodium-ion batteries have recently attracted renewed interest as an alternative to Li-ion batteries for elec. energy storage applications, because of the low cost and wide availability of sodium resources.  Thus, the electrochem. energy storage community has been devoting increased attention to designing new cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries.  Here we investigate P2- Na0.78Co1/2Mn1/3Ni1/6O2 as a cathode material for sodium ion batteries.  The main focus is to understand the mechanism of the electrochem. performance of this material, esp. differences obsd. in redox reactions at high potentials.  Between 4.2 V and 4.5 V, the material delivers a reversible capacity which is studied in detail using advanced anal. techniques.  In situ X-ray diffraction reveals the reversibility of the P2-type structure of the material.  Combined soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy and resonant inelastic X-ray scattering demonstrates that Na deintercalation at high voltages is charge compensated by formation of localized electron holes on oxygen atoms.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref14"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref14" class="refNumLink">14</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit14" data-doi="10.1016/j.electacta.2020.135978"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Stansby, J. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dose, W. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sharma, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kimpton, J. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">López
del Amo, J. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gonzalo, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Structural Evolution and Electrochemistry of the Mn-Rich P2– Na2/3Mn0.9Ti0.05Fe0.05O2 Positive Electrode Material</span>. <i>Electrochim. Acta</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>341</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">135978</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.electacta.2020.135978</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D341%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D135978%26journal%3DElectrochim.%2BActa%26author%3DJ.%2BH.%2BStansby%26author%3DW.%2BM.%2BDose%26author%3DN.%2BSharma%26author%3DJ.%2BA.%2BKimpton%26author%3DJ.%2BM.%2BL%25C3%25B3pez%250Adel%2BAmo%26author%3DE.%2BGonzalo%26author%3DT.%2BRojo%26title%3DStructural%2BEvolution%2Band%2BElectrochemistry%2Bof%2Bthe%2BMn-Rich%2BP2%25E2%2580%2593%2BNa2%252F3Mn0.9Ti0.05Fe0.05O2%2BPositive%2BElectrode%2BMaterial%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.electacta.2020.135978&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.electacta.2020.135978&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit14R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">14</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Structural evolution and electrochemistry of the Mn-Rich P2- Na2/3Mn0.9Ti0.05Fe0.05O2 positive electrode material</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Stansby, Jennifer H.; Dose, Wesley M.; Sharma, Neeraj; Kimpton, Justin A.; Lopez del Amo, Juan Miguel; Gonzalo, Elena; Rojo, Teofilo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Electrochimica Acta</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">341</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">135978</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ELCAAV</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4686</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Pos. electrodes still limit the max. attainable energy d. of Na-ion batteries.  Increasing the amt. of electrochem. active transition metal is one way of improving energy d.  However, this is complicated by the balance between initial capacity and structural stability/capacity retention.  Here, the Mn-rich P2- Na2/3Mn0.9Fe0.05Ti0.05O2 was synthesized via the solid-state method and its structural evolution during operation, between 1.9 and 4.2 V, studied.  Through operando x-ray powder diffraction data, no evidence is found for the formation of Z, OP4 or O2 phases and the material primarily displays regions of two-phase coexistence.  P2- Na2/3Mn0.9Fe0.05Ti0.05O2 delivers a 2nd charge/discharge capacity of 152/164 mAh g-1 at C/10, within the voltage range 4.0-2.0 V and retains 75% of the discharge capacity at the 50th cycle.  A detailed comparison, in terms of both the electrochem. performance and structural evolution, to related Mn-rich phases is provided.  Further structural stability and battery performance can be improved through subtle co-substitutions.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref15"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref15" class="refNumLink">15</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit15" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.201000061"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kang, S.-H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Slater, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rood, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Vaughey, J.                         cas_cit15R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">15</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Enabling sodium batteries using lithium-substituted sodium layered transition metal oxide cathodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kim, Donghan; Kang, Sun-Ho; Slater, Michael; Rood, Shawn; Vaughey, John T.; Karan, Naba; Balasubramanian, Mahalingam; Johnson, Christopher S.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Advanced Energy Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2011</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">1</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),

        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1614-6840</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-Blackwell</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A series of layered NaxLiγNi0.25Mn0.75Oδ oxides within the range 0.7 ≤ x ≤ 1.2; 0 ≤ γ ≤ 0.5 was synthesized and evaluated as cathodes in rechargeable sodium batteries.  As example, layered Na0.85Li0.17Ni0.21Mn0.64O2 oxide cathodes demonstrated modest electrochem. performance and structural stability for reversible Na intercalation reactions.  Considered as baseline material, a new cathode has been produced which can be used to benchmark other cathodes and help to accelerate the synthesis of improved advanced materials for Na batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref16"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref16" class="refNumLink">16</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit16" data-doi="10.1149/2.088406jes"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Karan, N.                 10.1149/2.088406jes</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D161%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3DA1107-A1115%26journal%3DJ.%2BElectrochem.%2BSoc.%26author%3DN.%2BK.%2BKaran%26author%3DM.%2BD.%2BSlater%26author%3DF.%2BDogan%26author%3DD.%2BKim%26author%3DC.%2BS.%2BJohnson%26author%3DM.%2BBalasubramanian%26title%3DOperando%2BStructural%2BCharacterization%2Bof%2Bthe%2BLithium-Substituted%2BLayered%2BSodium-Ion%2BCathode%2BMaterial%2BP2-Na%2B0.85%2BLi%2B0.17%2BNi%2B0.21%2BMn%2B0.64%2BO%2B2%2Bby%2BX-Ray%2BAbsorption%2BSpectroscopy%26doi%3D10.1149%252F2.088406jes&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1149%2F2.088406jes&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit16R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">16</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Operando Structural Characterization of the Lithium-Substituted Layered Sodium-Ion Cathode Material P2-Na0.85Li0.17Ni0.21Mn0.64O2 by X-ray Absorption Spectroscopy</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Karan, Naba K.; Slater, Michael D.; Dogan, Fulya; Kim, Donghan; Johnson, Christopher S.; Balasubramanian, Mahalingam</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">161</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">A1107-A1115</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Layered sodium-ion cathode material P2-Na0.85Li0.17Ni0.21Mn0.64O2 was investigated using operando XAS to characterize structural changes occurring in the material during electrochem. sodiation/desodiation.  Based on XANES data, the primary mode of charge compensation in this material is due to Ni2-3/4+ redox activity, while the Mn remains in the +4 oxidn. state, thereby providing stability to this material during extended cycling.  Investigation of the initial state of the compd. by high resoln. synchrotron x-ray diffraction and 6Li MAS NMR revealed a significant amt. of structural disorder due to integration of a small amt. of monoclinic layered Li phase within the overall hexagonal layered Na-structure, which manifests as Li-induced stacking faults.  High quality EXAFS data could be obtained using our cell construction and revealed the local structural evolution around the redox active Ni centers.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref17"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref17" class="refNumLink">17</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit17" data-doi="10.1021/am5080437"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hasa, I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Buchholz, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Passerini, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hassoun, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A Comparative Study of Layered Transition Metal Oxide Cathodes for Application in Sodium-Ion Battery</span>. <i>ACS Appl.                 10.1021/am5080437</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D7%26publication_year%3D2015%26pages%3D5206-5212%26journal%3DACS%2BAppl.%2BMater.%2BInterfaces%26author%3DI.%2BHasa%26author%3DD.%2BBuchholz%26author%3DS.%2BPasserini%26author%3DJ.%2BHassoun%26title%3DA%2BComparative%2BStudy%2Bof%2BLayered%2BTransition%2BMetal%2BOxide%2BCathodes%2Bfor%2BApplication%2Bin%2BSodium-Ion%2BBattery%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fam5080437&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fam5080437&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit17R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">17</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Comparative study of layered transition metal oxide cathodes for application in sodium-ion battery</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Hasa, Ivana; Buchholz, Daniel; Passerini, Stefano; Hassoun, Jusef</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Applied Materials &amp; Interfaces</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">7</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5206-5212</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AAMICK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1944-8244</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Herein, we report a study on P-type layered sodium transition metal-based oxides with a general formula of NaxMO2 (M = Ni, Fe, Mn).  We synthesize the materials via copptn. followed by annealing in air and rinsing with water, and we examine the electrodes as cathodes for sodium-ion batteries using a propylene carbonate-based electrolyte.  We fully investigate the effect of the Ni-to-Fe ratio, annealing temp., and sodium content on the electrochem. performances of the electrodes.  The impact of these parameters on the structural and electrochem. properties of the materials is revealed by X-ray diffraction, SEM, and cyclic voltammetry, resp.  The suitability of this class of P-type materials for sodium battery application is finally demonstrated by cycling tests revealing an excellent electrochem. performance in terms of delivered capacity (i.e., about 200 mAh g-1) and charge-discharge efficiency (approaching 100%).</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref18"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref18" class="refNumLink">18</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit18" data-doi="10.1002/anie.201911698"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zuo, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zheng, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xiang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhou, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xiao, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shan, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shi, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhong, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fu, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, Y.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">P2-Na <sub>0.67</sub> Al <sub>x</sub> <sub>M</sub>n 1– <sub>x&nbsp;O</sub> <sub>2</sub> : <sub>C</sub>ost-Effective, Stable and High-Rate Sodium Electrodes by Suppressing Phase Transitions and Enhancing Sodium Cation Mobility</span>. <i>Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>58</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">18086</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">18095</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/anie.201911698</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D58%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D18086-18095%26journal%3DAngew.%2BChem.%252C%2BInt.%2BEd.%26author%3DX.%2BLiu%26author%3DW.%2BZuo%26author%3DB.%2BZheng%26author%3DY.%2BXiang%26author%3DK.%2BZhou%26author%3DZ.%2BXiao%26author%3DP.%2BShan%26author%3DJ.%2BShi%26author%3DQ.%2BLi%26author%3DG.%2BZhong%26author%3DR.%2BFu%26author%3DY.%2BYang%26title%3DP2-Na%2B0.67%2BAl%2Bx%2BMn%2B1%25E2%2580%2593%2Bx%25C2%25A0O%2B2%25E2%2580%25AF%253A%2BCost-Effective%252C%2BStable%2Band%2BHigh-Rate%2BSodium%2BElectrodes%2Bby%2BSuppressing%2BPhase%2BTransitions%2Band%2BEnhancing%2BSodium%2BCation%2BMobility%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fanie.201911698&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fanie.201911698&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit18R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">18</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">P2-Na0.67AlxMn1-xO2: Cost-Effective, Stable and High-Rate Sodium Electrodes by Suppressing Phase Transitions and Enhancing Sodium Cation Mobility</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Liu, Xiangsi; Zuo, Wenhua; Zheng, Bizhu; Xiang, Yuxuan; Zhou, Ke; Xiao, Zhumei; Shan, Peizhao; Shi, Jingwen; Li, Qi; Zhong, Guiming; Fu, Riqiang; Yang, Yong</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Angewandte Chemie, International Edition</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">58</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">50</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">18086-18095</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACIEF5</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1433-7851</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Na layered P2-stacking Na0.67MnO2 materials showed great promise for Na-ion batteries.  However, the undesired Jahn-Teller effect of the Mn4+/Mn3+ redox couple and multiple biphasic structural transitions during charge/discharge of the materials lead to anisotropic structure expansion and rapid capacity decay.  Herein, by introducing abundant Al into the transition-metal layers to decrease the no. of Mn3+, the authors obtain the low cost pure P2-type Na0.67AlxMn1-xO2 (x = 0.05, 0.1 and 0.2) materials with high structural stability and promising performance.  The Al-doping effect on the long/short range structural evolutions and electrochem. performances is further studied by combining in situ synchrotron XRD and solid-state NMR techniques.  The authors' results reveal that Al-doping alleviates the phase transformations thus giving rise to better cycling life, and leads to a larger spacing of Na+ layer thus producing a remarkable rate capability of 96 mAh g-1 at 1200 mA g-1.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref19"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref19" class="refNumLink">19</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit19" data-doi="10.1021/cm403855t"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xu, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, D. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pell, A. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meng, Y. S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Identifying the Critical Role of Li Substitution in P2–Nax [Liy Niz Mn1-y-z]O 2 (0 &lt; x , y , z &lt; 1) Intercalation Cathode Materials for High-Energy Na-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>26</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1260</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1269</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/cm403855t</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D26%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3D1260-1269%26journal%3DChem.%2BMater.%26author%3DJ.%2BXu%26author%3DD.%2BH.%2BLee%26author%3DR.%2BJ.%2BCl%25C3%25A9ment%26author%3DX.%2BYu%26author%3DM.%2BLeskes%26author%3DA.%2BJ.%2BPell%26author%3DG.%2BPintacuda%26author%3DX.-Q.%2BYang%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26author%3DY.%2BS.%2BMeng%26title%3DIdentifying%2Bthe%2BCritical%2BRole%2Bof%2BLi%2BSubstitution%2Bin%2BP2%25E2%2580%2593Nax%2B%255BLiy%2BNiz%2BMn1-y-z%255DO%2B2%2B%25280%2B%253C%2Bx%2B%252C%2By%2B%252C%2Bz%2B%253C%2B1%2529%2BIntercalation%2BCathode%2BMaterials%2Bfor%2BHigh-Energy%2BNa-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fcm403855t&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fcm403855t&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit19R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">19</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Identifying the Critical Role of Li Substitution in P2-Nax[LiyNizMn1-y-z]O2 (0 &lt; x, y, z &lt; 1) Intercalation Cathode Materials for High-Energy Na-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Xu, Jing; Lee, Dae Hoe; Clement, Raphaele J.; Yu, Xiqian; Leskes, Michal; Pell, Andrew J.; Pintacuda, Guido; Yang, Xiao-Qing; Grey, Clare P.; Meng, Ying Shirley</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">26</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1260-1269</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Li-substituted layered P2-Na0.80[Li0.12Ni0.22Mn0.66]O2 is studied as an advanced cathode material for Na-ion batteries.  Both n diffraction and NMR spectroscopy are used to elucidate the local structure, and they reveal that most of the Li ions are located in transition metal (TM) sites, preferably surrounded by Mn ions.  To characterize structural changes occurring upon electrochem. cycling, in situ synchrotron x-ray diffraction is conducted.  No significant phase transformation is obsd. up to 4.4 V charge for this material, unlike Li-free P2-type Na cathodes.  The presence of monovalent Li ions in the TM layers allows more Na ions to reside in the prismatic sites, stabilizing the overall charge balance of the compd.  Consequently, more Na ions remain in the compd. upon charge, the P2 structure is retained in the high voltage region, and the phase transformation is delayed.  Ex situ NMR is conducted on samples at different states of charge/discharge to track Li-ion site occupation changes.  Surprisingly, Li is mobile, some Li ions migrate from the TM layer to the Na layer at high voltage, and yet this process is highly reversible.  Novel design principles for Na cathode materials are proposed from an atomistic level understanding of the underlying electrochem. processes.  These principles enable one to devise an optimized, high capacity, and structurally stable compd. as a potential cathode material for high-energy Na-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref20"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref20" class="refNumLink">20</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit20" data-doi="10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.02.069"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Buchholz, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Vaalma, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chagas, L. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Passerini, S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Mg-Doping for Improved Long-Term Cyclability of Layered Na-Ion Cathode Materials - The Example of P2-Type NaxMg0.11Mn0.89O2</span>. <i>J. Power Sources</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>282</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">581</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">585</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.02.069</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D282%26publication_year%3D2015%26pages%3D581-585%26journal%3DJ.%2BPower%2BSources%26author%3DD.%2BBuchholz%26author%3DC.%2BVaalma%26author%3DL.%2BG.%2BChagas%26author%3DS.%2BPasserini%26title%3DMg-Doping%2Bfor%2BImproved%2BLong-Term%2BCyclability%2Bof%2BLayered%2BNa-Ion%2BCathode%2BMaterials%2B-%2BThe%2BExample%2Bof%2BP2-Type%2BNaxMg0.11Mn0.89O2%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.jpowsour.2015.02.069&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.jpowsour.2015.02.069&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit20R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">20</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Mg-doping for improved long-term cyclability of layered Na-ion cathode materials - The example of P2-type NaxMg0.11Mn0.89O2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Buchholz, Daniel; Vaalma, Christoph; Chagas, Luciana Gomes; Passerini, Stefano</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Power Sources</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">282</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">581-585</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPSODZ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0378-7753</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are establishing themselves as a low-cost alternative to the widespread lithium-ion technol., a trend that is exemplified by the use of aluminum as anode current collector.  In order to be in line with this philosophy, environmentally friendly, abundant and cheap materials need to be used in order to provide a complementary rather than competing battery technol. other than lithium-ion.  With the same scope in mind, herein we present the structural and electrochem. characterization of P2-type NaxMg0.11Mn0.89O2 material to demonstrate the effectiveness of Mg-doping for the development of future layered cathode materials.  Of particular interest is the effect on the long-term cyclability (200 cycles), which has not been reported, yet.  As shown in the manuscript, a Mg content as low as 11% in the MO2 layer leads to a smoothing of the potential profile, very high coulombic efficiencies exceeding 99.5% at 12 mA g-1 and a stable long-term cycling behavior.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref21"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref21" class="refNumLink">21</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit21" data-doi="10.1002/nano.202000030"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Deng, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gao, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yin, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zou, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hou, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ji, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Manganese-based Layered Oxide Cathodes for Sodium Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Nano Sel.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>1</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">200</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">225</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/nano.202000030</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D1%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D200-225%26journal%3DNano%2BSel.%26author%3DH.%2BLiu%26author%3DW.%2BDeng%26author%3DX.%2BGao%26author%3DJ.%2BChen%26author%3DS.%2BYin%26author%3DL.%2BYang%26author%3DG.%2BZou%26author%3DH.%2BHou%26author%3DX.%2BJi%26title%3DManganese-based%2BLayered%2BOxide%2BCathodes%2Bfor%2BSodium%2BIon%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1002%252Fnano.202000030&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1002%2Fnano.202000030&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
