R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">What Triggers Oxygen Loss in Oxygen Redox Cathode Materials?</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>31</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">3293</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3300</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00227</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D31%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D3293-3300%26journal%3DChem.%2BMater.%26author%3DR.%2BA.%2BHouse%26author%3DU.%2BMaitra%26author%3DL.%2BJin%26author%3DJ.%2BG.%2BLozano%26author%3DJ.%2BW.%2BSomerville%26author%3DN.%2BH.%2BRees%26author%3DA.%2BJ.%2BNaylor%26author%3DL.%2BC.%2BDuda%26author%3DF.%2BMassel%26author%3DA.%2BV.%2BChadwick%26author%3DS.%2BRamos%26author%3DD.%2BM.%2BPickup%26author%3DD.%2BE.%2BMcNally%26author%3DX.%2BLu%26author%3DT.%2BSchmitt%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BRoberts%26author%3DP.%2BG.%2BBruce%26title%3DWhat%2BTriggers%2BOxygen%2BLoss%2Bin%2BOxygen%2BRedox%2BCathode%2BMaterials%253F%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.chemmater.9b00227&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.9b00227&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit23R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">23</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">What Triggers Oxygen Loss in Oxygen Redox Cathode Materials?</span></div><div class="casAuthors">House, Robert A.; Maitra, Urmimala; Jin, Liyu; Lozano, Juan G.; Somerville, James W.; Rees, Nicholas H.; Naylor, Andrew J.; Duda, Laurent C.; Massel, Felix; Chadwick, Alan V.; Ramos, Silvia; Pickup, David M.; McNally, Daniel E.; Lu, Xingye; Schmitt, Thorsten; Roberts, Matthew R.; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">31</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3293-3300</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">It is possible to increase the charge capacity of transition-metal (TM) oxide cathodes in alkali-ion batteries by invoking redox reactions on the oxygen.  However, oxygen loss often occurs.  To explore what affects oxygen loss in oxygen redox materials, we have two analogous Na-ion cathodes, P2-Na0.67Mg0.28Mn0.72O2 and P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2 are compared.  On charging to 4.5 V, &gt; 0.4e- are removed from the oxide ions of these materials, but neither compd. exhibits oxygen loss.  Li is retained in P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2 but displaced from the TM to the alkali metal layers, showing that vacancies in the TM layers, which also occur in other oxygen redox compds. that exhibit oxygen loss such as Li[Li0.2Ni0.2Mn0.6]O2, are not a trigger for oxygen loss.  On charging at 5 V, P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2 exhibits oxygen loss, whereas P2-Na0.67Mg0.28Mn0.72O2 does not.  Under these conditions, both Na+ and Li+ are removed from P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2, resulting in underbonded oxygen (fewer than 3 cations coordinating oxygen) and surface-localized O loss.  In contrast, for P2-Na0.67Mg0.28Mn0.72O2, oxygen remains coordinated by at least 2 Mn4+ and 1 Mg2+ ions, stabilizing the oxygen and avoiding oxygen loss.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref24"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref24" class="refNumLink">24</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit24" data-doi="10.1039/c6ee01750a"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Robert Armstrong, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Singh, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Structurally Stable Mg-Doped P2-Na 2/3 Mn 1–y Mg y O 2 Sodium-Ion Battery Cathodes with High Rate Performance: Insights from Electrochemical, NMR and Diffraction Studies</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>9</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">3240</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3251</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c6ee01750a</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D9%26publication_year%3D2016%26pages%3D3240-3251%26journal%3DEnergy%2BEnviron.%2BSci.%26author%3DR.%2BJ.%2BCl%25C3%25A9ment%26author%3DJ.%2BBillaud%26author%3DA.%2BRobert%2BArmstrong%26author%3DG.%2BSingh%26author%3DT.%2BRojo%26author%3DP.%2BG.%2BBruce%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26title%3DStructurally%2BStable%2BMg-Doped%2BP2-Na%2B2%252F3%2BMn%2B1%25E2%2580%2593y%2BMg%2By%2BO%2B2%2BSodium-Ion%2BBattery%2BCathodes%2Bwith%2BHigh%2BRate%2BPerformance%253A%2BInsights%2Bfrom%2BElectrochemical%252C%2BNMR%2Band%2BDiffraction%2BStudies%26doi%3D10.1039%252Fc6ee01750a&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2Fc6ee01750a&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit24R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">24</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Structurally stable Mg-doped P2-Na2/3Mn1-yMgyO2 sodium-ion battery cathodes with high rate performance: insights from electrochemical, NMR and diffraction studies</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Clement, Raphaele J.; Billaud, Juliette; Robert Armstrong, A.; Singh, Gurpreet; Rojo, Teofilo; Bruce, Peter G.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">9</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">10</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3240-3251</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries are a more sustainable alternative to the existing lithium-ion technol. and could alleviate some of the stress on the global lithium market as a result of the growing elec. car and portable electronics industries.  Fundamental research focused on understanding the structural and electronic processes occurring on electrochem. cycling is key to devising rechargeable batteries with improved performance.  We present an in-depth investigation of the effect of Mg doping on the electrochem. performance and structural stability of Na2/3MnO2 with a P2 layer stacking by comparing three compns.: Na2/3Mn1-yMgyO2 (y = 0.0, 0.05, 0.1).  We show that Mg substitution leads to smoother electrochem., with fewer distinct electrochem. processes, improved rate performance and better capacity retention.  These observations are attributed to the more gradual structural changes upon charge and discharge, as obsd. with synchrotron, powder X-ray, and neutron diffraction.  Mg doping reduces the no. of Mn3+ Jahn-Teller centers and delays the high voltage phase transition occurring in P2-Na2/3MnO2.  The local structure is investigated using 23Na solid-state NMR (ssNMR) spectroscopy.  The ssNMR data provide direct evidence for fewer oxygen layer shearing events, leading to a stabilized P2 phase, and an enhanced Na-ion mobility up to 3.8 V vs.  Na+/Na upon Mg doping.  The 5% Mg-doped phase exhibits one of the best rate performances reported to date for sodium-ion cathodes with a P2 structure, with a reversible capacity of 106 mA h g-1 at the very high discharge rate of 5000 mA g-1.  In addn., its structure is highly reversible and stable cycling is obtained between 1.5 and 4.0 V vs.  Na+/Na, with a capacity of approx. 140 mA h g-1 retained after 50 cycles at a rate of 1000 mA g-1.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref25"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref25" class="refNumLink">25</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit25" data-doi="10.1039/c4ee00465e"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Singh, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armstrong, A. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gonzalo, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Roddatis, V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armand, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Na 0.67 Mn 1–x Mg x O 2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2): A High Capacity Cathode for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>7</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1387</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1391</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c4ee00465e</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D7%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3D1387-1391%26journal%3DEnergy%2BEnviron.%2BSci.%26author%3DJ.%2BBillaud%26author%3DG.%2BSingh%26author%3DA.%2BR.%2BArmstrong%26author%3DE.%2BGonzalo%26author%3DV.%2BRoddatis%26author%3DM.%2BArmand%26author%3DT.%2BRojo%26author%3DP.%2BG.%2BBruce%26title%3DNa%2B0.67%2BMn%2B1%25E2%2580%2593x%2BMg%2Bx%2BO%2B2%2B%25280%2B%25E2%2589%25A4%2Bx%2B%25E2%2589%25A4%2B0.2%2529%253A%2BA%2BHigh%2BCapacity%2BCathode%2Bfor%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1039%252Fc4ee00465e&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2Fc4ee00465e&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit25R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">25</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Na0.67Mn1-xMgxO2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2): a high capacity cathode for sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Billaud, Juliette; Singh, Gurpreet; Armstrong, A. Robert; Gonzalo, Elena; Roddatis, Vladimir; Armand, Michel; Rojo, Teofilo; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">7</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1387-1391</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Earth-abundant Na0.67[Mn1-xMgx]O2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2) cathode materials with the P2 structure have been synthesized as pos. electrodes for sodium-ion batteries.  Na0.67MnO2 exhibits a capacity of 175 mA h g-1 with good capacity retention.  A Mg content of 5% is sufficient to smooth the charge/discharge profiles without affecting the capacity, while further increasing the Mg content improves the cycling stability, but at the expense of a lower discharge capacity (∼150 mA h g-1 for Na0.67Mn0.8Mg0.2O2).  It was obsd. that the cooling process during synthesis, as well as Mg content, have an influence on the structure.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref26"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref26" class="refNumLink">26</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit26" data-doi="10.1021/ja509704t"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armstrong, A. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Canales-Vázquez, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rozier, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A High-Performance Cathode for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>136</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">17243</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">17248</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja509704t</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D136%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3D17243-17248%26journal%3DJ.%2BAm.%2BChem.%2BSoc.%26author%3DJ.%2BBillaud%26author%3DR.%2BJ.%2BCl%25C3%25A9ment%26author%3DA.%2BR.%2BArmstrong%26author%3DJ.%2BCanales-V%25C3%25A1zquez%26author%3DP.%2BRozier%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26author%3DP.%2BG.%2BBruce%26title%3DA%2BHigh-Performance%2BCathode%2Bfor%2BSodium-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fja509704t&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fja509704t&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit26R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">26</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">β-NaMnO2: A High-Performance Cathode for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Billaud, Juliette; Clement, Raphaele J.; Armstrong, A. Robert; Canales-Vazquez, Jesus; Rozier, Patrick; Grey, Clare P.; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">136</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">49</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">17243-17248</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">There is much interest in Na-ion batteries for grid storage because of the lower projected cost compared with Li-ion.  Identifying Earth-abundant, low-cost, and safe materials that can function as intercalation cathodes in Na-ion batteries is an important challenge facing the field.  Here such a material, β-NaMnO2, is investigated with a different structure from that of NaMnO2 polymorphs and other compds. studied extensively in the past.  It exhibits a high capacity (of ca. 190 mA h g-1 at a rate of C/20), along with a good rate capability (142 mA h g-1 at a rate of 2C) and a good capacity retention (100 mA h g-1after 100 Na extn./insertion cycles at a rate of 2C).  Powder XRD, HRTEM, and 23Na NMR studies revealed that this compd. exhibits a complex structure consisting of intergrown regions of α-NaMnO2 and β-NaMnO2 domains.  The collapse of the long-range structure at low Na content is expected to compromise the reversibility of the Na extn. and insertion processes occurring upon charge and discharge of the cathode material, resp.  Yet stable, reproducible, and reversible Na intercalation is obsd.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref27"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref27" class="refNumLink">27</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit27" data-doi="10.1039/c4ta04351k"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yabuuchi, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hara, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kubota, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Paulsen, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kumakura, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Komaba, S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A New Electrode Material for Rechargeable Sodium Batteries: P2-Type Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 with Anomalously High Reversible Capacity</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem.                 10.1039/c4ta04351k</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D2%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3D16851-16855%26journal%3DJ.%2BMater.%2BChem.%2BA%26author%3DN.%2BYabuuchi%26author%3DR.%2BHara%26author%3DK.%2BKubota%26author%3DJ.%2BPaulsen%26author%3DS.%2BKumakura%26author%3DS.%2BKomaba%26title%3DA%2BNew%2BElectrode%2BMaterial%2Bfor%2BRechargeable%2BSodium%2BBatteries%253A%2BP2-Type%2BNa2%252F3%255BMg0.28Mn0.72%255DO2%2Bwith%2BAnomalously%2BHigh%2BReversible%2BCapacity%26doi%3D10.1039%252Fc4ta04351k&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2Fc4ta04351k&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit27R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">27</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">A new electrode material for rechargeable sodium batteries: P2-type Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 with anomalously high reversible capacity</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Hara, Ryo; Kubota, Kei; Paulsen, Jens; Kumakura, Shinichi; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">2</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">40</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">16851-16855</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMCAET</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2050-7496</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">P2-type Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 is prepd. and electrode performance in Na cells is first provided.  The sample surprisingly delivers a large reversible capacity (220 mA h g-1) even though electrochem. inactive magnesium ions are enriched in the host structure.  This new electrode material is potentially utilized for rechargeable batteries made from only earth-abundant elements.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref28"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref28" class="refNumLink">28</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit28" data-doi="10.1038/nchem.2923"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Maitra, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">House, R. W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tapia-Ruiz, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lozano, J. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Oxygen Redox Chemistry without Excess Alkali-Metal Ions in Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2</span>. <i>Nat. Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>10</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">288</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">295</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/nchem.2923</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D10%26publication_year%3D2018%26pages%3D288-295%26journal%3DNat.%2BChem.%26author%3DU.%2BMaitra%26author%3DR.%2BA.%2BHouse%26author%3DJ.%2BW.%2BSomerville%26author%3DN.%2BTapia-Ruiz%26author%3DJ.%2BG.%2BLozano%26author%3DN.%2BGuerrini%26author%3DR.%2BHao%26author%3DK.%2BLuo%26author%3DL.%2BJin%26author%3DM.%2BA.%2BP%25C3%25A9rez-Osorio%26author%3DF.%2BMassel%26author%3DD.%2BM.%2BPickup%26author%3DS.%2BRamos%26author%3DX.%2BLu%26author%3DD.%2BE.%2BMcNally%26author%3DA.%2BV.%2BChadwick%26author%3DF.%2BGiustino%26author%3DT.%2BSchmitt%26author%3DL.%2BC.%2BDuda%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BRoberts%26author%3DP.%2BG.%2BBruce%26title%3DOxygen%2BRedox%2BChemistry%2Bwithout%2BExcess%2BAlkali-Metal%2BIons%2Bin%2BNa2%252F3%255BMg0.28Mn0.72%255DO2%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fnchem.2923&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fnchem.2923&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit28R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">28</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Oxygen redox chemistry without excess alkali-metal ions in Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Maitra, Urmimala; House, Robert A.; Somerville, James W.; Tapia-Ruiz, Nuria; Lozano, Juan G.; Guerrini, Niccolo; Hao, Rong; Luo, Kun; Jin, Liyu; Perez-Osorio, Miguel A.; Massel, Felix; Pickup, David M.; Ramos, Silvia; Lu, Xingye; McNally, Daniel E.; Chadwick, Alan V.; Giustino, Feliciano; Schmitt, Thorsten; Duda, Laurent C.; Roberts, Matthew R.; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">10</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">288-295</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NCAHBB</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1755-4330</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The search for improved energy-storage materials has revealed Li- and Na-rich intercalation compds. as promising high-capacity cathodes.  They exhibit capacities in excess of what would be expected from alkali-ion removal/reinsertion and charge compensation by transition-metal (TM) ions.  The addnl. capacity is provided through charge compensation by oxygen redox chem. and some oxygen loss.  It has been reported previously that oxygen redox occurs in O 2p orbitals that interact with alkali ions in the TM and alkali-ion layers (i.e., oxygen redox occurs in compds. contg. Li+-O(2p)-Li+ interactions).  Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 exhibits an excess capacity and here we show that this is caused by oxygen redox, even though Mg2+ resides in the TM layers rather than alkali-metal (AM) ions, which demonstrates that excess AM ions are not required to activate oxygen redox.  We also show that, unlike the alkali-rich compds., Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 does not lose oxygen.  The extn. of alkali ions from the alkali and TM layers in the alkali-rich compds. results in severely underbonded oxygen, which promotes oxygen loss, whereas Mg2+ remains in Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2, which stabilizes oxygen.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref29"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref29" class="refNumLink">29</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit29" data-doi="10.1021/ic5017802"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mortemard
De Boisse, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carlier, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guignard, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bourgeois, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Delmas, C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">P2-NaxMn1/2Fe1/2O2 Phase Used as Positive Electrode in Na Batteries: Structural Changes Induced by the Electrochemical (De)Intercalation Process</span>. <i>Inorg. Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>53</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">11197</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">11205</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ic5017802</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D53%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3D11197-11205%26journal%3DInorg.%2BChem.%26author%3DB.%2BMortemard%250ADe%2BBoisse%26author%3DD.%2BCarlier%26author%3DM.%2BGuignard%26author%3DL.%2BBourgeois%26author%3DC.%2BDelmas%26title%3DP2-NaxMn1%252F2Fe1%252F2O2%2BPhase%2BUsed%2Bas%2BPositive%2BElectrode%2Bin%2BNa%2BBatteries%253A%2BStructural%2BChanges%2BInduced%2Bby%2Bthe%2BElectrochemical%2B%2528De%2529Intercalation%2BProcess%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fic5017802&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fic5017802&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit29R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">29</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">P2-NaxMn1/2Fe1/2O2 Phase Used as Positive Electrode in Na Batteries: Structural Changes Induced by the Electrochemical (De)intercalation Process</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Mortemard de Boisse, Benoit; Carlier, Dany; Guignard, Marie; Bourgeois, Lydie; Delmas, Claude</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Inorganic Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">53</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">20</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">11197-11205</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">INOCAJ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0020-1669</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The electrochem. properties of the P2-type NaxMn1/2Fe1/2O2 (x = 0.62) phase used as a pos. electrode in Na batteries were tested in various voltage ranges at C/20.  Even if the highest capacity was obtained for the 1st cycles between 1.5 and 4.3 V, the best capacity after 50 cycles was obtained while cycling between 1.5 and 4.0 V (120 mAh g-1).  The structural changes occurring in the material during the (de)intercalation were studied by operando in situ x-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) and ex situ synchrotron XRPD.  A phase with an orthorhombic P'2-type structure is formed for x ≈ 1, due to the cooperative Jahn-Teller effect of the Mn3+ ions.  P2 structure type stacking is obsd. for 0.35 &lt; x &lt; 0.82, while &gt;4.0 V, a new phase appears.  A full indexation of the XRPD pattern of this latter phase was not possible because of the broadening of the diffraction peaks.  However, a much shorter interslab distance was found that may imply a gliding of the MO2 slab occurring at high voltage.  Raman spectroscopy was used as a local probe and showed that in this new phase the MO2 layers are maintained, but the phase exhibits a strong degree of disorder.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref30"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref30" class="refNumLink">30</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit30" data-doi="10.1039/c8ee02991a"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Somerville, J. W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sobkowiak, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tapia-Ruiz, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lozano, J. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">House, R. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gallington, L. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ericsson, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Häggström, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Roberts, M. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Maitra, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Nature of the “Z”-Phase in Layered Na-Ion Battery Cathodes</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">2223</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2232</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c8ee02991a</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D12%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D2223-2232%26journal%3DEnergy%2BEnviron.%2BSci.%26author%3DJ.%2BW.%2BSomerville%26author%3DA.%2BSobkowiak%26author%3DN.%2BTapia-Ruiz%26author%3DJ.%2BBillaud%26author%3DJ.%2BG.%2BLozano%26author%3DR.%2BA.%2BHouse%26author%3DL.%2BC.%2BGallington%26author%3DT.%2BEricsson%26author%3DL.%2BH%25C3%25A4ggstr%25C3%25B6m%26author%3DM.%2BR.%2BRoberts%26author%3DU.%2BMaitra%26author%3DP.%2BG.%2BBruce%26title%3DNature%2Bof%2Bthe%2B%25E2%2580%259CZ%25E2%2580%259D-Phase%2Bin%2BLayered%2BNa-Ion%2BBattery%2BCathodes%26doi%3D10.1039%252Fc8ee02991a&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1039%2Fc8ee02991a&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit30R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">30</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Nature of the "Z"-phase in layered Na-ion battery cathodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Somerville, James W.; Sobkowiak, Adam; Tapia-Ruiz, Nuria; Billaud, Juliette; Lozano, Juan G.; House, Robert A.; Gallington, Leighanne C.; Ericsson, Tore; Haggstrom, Lennart; Roberts, Matthew R.; Maitra, Urmimala; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2223-2232</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Layered sodium transition metal oxides with the P2 structure, e.g.  Na2/3[Ni1/3Mn2/3]O2, are regarded as candidates for Na-ion battery cathodes.  On charging, extn. of Na destabilizes the P2 phase (ABBA oxide ion stacking) in which Na+ is in trigonal prismatic coordination, resulting in layer gliding and formation of an O2 phase (ABAC stacking) with octahedral coordination.  However, many related compds. do not exhibit such a simple P2 to O2 transition but rather form a so called "Z"-phase.  Substituting Ni by Fe in Na2/3[Ni1/3Mn2/3]O2 is attractive as it reduces cost.  The Fe contg. compds., such as Na2/3[Ni1/6Mn1/2Fe1/3]O2, form a "Z"-phase when charged above 4.1 V vs.  Na+/Na.  By combining ex situ and operando X-ray diffraction with scanning transmission electron microscopy and simulated diffraction patterns, we demonstrate that the "Z"-phase is most accurately described as a continuously changing intergrowth structure which evolves from P2 to O2 through the OP4 structure as an intermediate.  On charging, Na+ removal results in O-type stacking faults within the P2 structure which increase in proportion.  At 50% O-type stacking faults, the ordered OP4 phase forms and on further charging more O-type stacking faults are formed progressing towards a pure O2 structure.  This gives the superficial appearance of a solid soln.  Furthermore, in contrast to some previous studies, we did not detect Fe migration at any state-of-charge using 57Fe-Mossbauer spectroscopy.  It was, however, found that the Fe-substitution serves to disrupt cation ordering in the material.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref31"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref31" class="refNumLink">31</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit31" data-doi="10.1107/s0365110x67000234"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rietveld, H. M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Line Profiles of Neutron Powder-Diffraction Peaks for Structure Refinement</span>. <i>Acta Crystallogr.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1967</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>22</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">151</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">152</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0365110x67000234</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D22%26publication_year%3D1967%26pages%3D151-152%26journal%3DActa%2BCrystallogr.%26author%3DH.%2BM.%2BRietveld%26title%3DLine%2BProfiles%2Bof%2BNeutron%2BPowder-Diffraction%2BPeaks%2Bfor%2BStructure%2BRefinement%26doi%3D10.1107%252Fs0365110x67000234&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1107%2Fs0365110x67000234&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit31R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">31</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Line profiles of neutron powder-diffraction peaks for structure refinement</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Rietveld, H. M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Acta Crystallographica</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1967</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">22</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">151-2</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACCRA9</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0365-110X</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">A structure refinement procedure is described, which obtains a least-sqs. fit between the calcd. and observed intensities measured at equal angular intervals on a neutron powder-diffractometer.  The structure parameters are significantly more reliable than those detd. by a method with the use of the integrated intensities of overlapping peaks.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref32"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref32" class="refNumLink">32</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit32" data-doi="10.1107/s0021889869006558"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rietveld, H. M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A Profile Refinement Method for Nuclear and Magnetic Structures</span>. <i>J. Appl. Crystallogr.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1969</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>2</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">65</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">71</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0021889869006558</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D2%26publication_year%3D1969%26pages%3D65-71%26journal%3DJ.%2BAppl.%2BCrystallogr.%26author%3DH.%2BM.%2BRietveld%26title%3DA%2BProfile%2BRefinement%2BMethod%2Bfor%2BNuclear%2Band%2BMagnetic%2BStructures%26doi%3D10.1107%252Fs0021889869006558&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1107%2Fs0021889869006558&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit32R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">32</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Profile refinement method for nuclear and magnetic structures</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Rietveld, H. M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Applied Crystallography</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1969</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">2</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">Pt. 2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">65-71</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACGAR</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0021-8898</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">A structural refinement method for neutron diffraction is presented which makes direct use of the profile intensities obtained from the powder diagram.  It is applicable to nuclear structures and to magnetic structures which can be described on the nuclear unit cell or a multiple thereof.  Equations for the measured profiles to be used in the least sqs. treatment are cor. for asymmetry and preferred orientation; the angular dependence of the half widths of the peaks is given by the formula of Caglioti, et al. (1958).  The magnetic contribution to the profile equation is expressed by calcg. only one av. cross section for each set of equiv. reflections.  It is possible to introduce constraint functions, linear or quadratic, between parameters used in the least sqs. treatment.  Results of the use of this method are given for a series of compds.  In all instances it has proved superior to any other method involving integrated neutron powder intensities, single or overlapping.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref33"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref33" class="refNumLink">33</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit33"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Coelho, A.</span></span> <i>TOPAS-Academic: General Profile and Structure Analysis Software for Powder Diffraction Data</i>: <span class="NLM_publisher-loc">Brisbane, Australia</span>, <span class="NLM_year">2007</span>.</span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="http://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?hl=en&amp;publication_year=2007&amp;author=A.+Coelho&amp;title=TOPAS-Academic%3A+General+Profile+and+Structure+Analysis+Software+for+Powder+Diffraction+Data" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref34"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref34" class="refNumLink">34</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit34" data-doi="10.1107/s1600576718000183"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Coelho, A. A.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">TOPAS and TOPAS-Academic : An Optimization Program Integrating Computer Algebra and Crystallographic Objects Written in C++</span>. <i>J. Appl. Crystallogr.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>51</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">210</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">218</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s1600576718000183</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D51%26publication_year%3D2018%26pages%3D210-218%26journal%3DJ.%2BAppl.%2BCrystallogr.%26author%3DA.%2BA.%2BCoelho%26title%3DTOPAS%2Band%2BTOPAS-Academic%25E2%2580%25AF%253A%2BAn%2BOptimization%2BProgram%2BIntegrating%2BComputer%2BAlgebra%2Band%2BCrystallographic%2BObjects%2BWritten%2Bin%2BC%252B%252B%26doi%3D10.1107%252Fs1600576718000183&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1107%2Fs1600576718000183&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit34R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">34</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">TOPAS and TOPAS-Academic: an optimization program integrating computer algebra and crystallographic objects written in C++</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Coelho, Alan A.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Applied Crystallography</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">51</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">210-218</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACGAR</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1600-5767</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">International Union of Crystallography</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">TOPAS and its academic variant TOPAS-Academic are nonlinear least-squares optimization programs written in the C++ programming language.  This paper describes their functionality and architecture.  The latter is of benefit to developers seeking to reduce development time.  TOPAS allows linear and nonlinear constraints through the use of computer algebra, with parameter dependencies, required for parameter derivs., automatically detd.  In addn., the objective function can include restraints and penalties, which again are defined using computer algebra.  Of importance is a conjugate gradient soln. routine with bounding constraints which guide refinements to convergence.  Much of the functionality of TOPAS is achieved through the use of generic functionality; for example, flexible peak-shape generation allows neutron time-of-flight (TOF) peak shapes to be described using generic functions.  The kernel of TOPAS can be run from the command line for batch mode operation or from a closely integrated graphical user interface.  The functionality of TOPAS includes peak fitting, Pawley and Le Bail refinement, Rietveld refinement, single-crystal refinement, pair distribution function refinement, magnetic structures, const. wavelength neutron refinement, TOF refinement, stacking-fault anal., Laue refinement, indexing, charge flipping, and structure soln. through simulated annealing.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref35"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref35" class="refNumLink">35</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit35" data-doi="10.1107/s0909049505012719"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ravel, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Newville, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">ATHENA, ARTEMIS, HEPHAESTUS: Data Analysis for X-Ray Absorption Spectroscopy Using IFEFFIT</span>. <i>J. Synchrotron Radiat.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2005</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">537</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">541</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0909049505012719</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D12%26publication_year%3D2005%26pages%3D537-541%26journal%3DJ.%2BSynchrotron%2BRadiat.%26author%3DB.%2BRavel%26author%3DM.%2BNewville%26title%3DATHENA%252C%2BARTEMIS%252C%2BHEPHAESTUS%253A%2BData%2BAnalysis%2Bfor%2BX-Ray%2BAbsorption%2BSpectroscopy%2BUsing%2BIFEFFIT%26doi%3D10.1107%252Fs0909049505012719&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1107%2Fs0909049505012719&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit35R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">35</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">ATHENA, ARTEMIS, HEPHAESTUS: data analysis for x-ray absorption spectroscopy using IFEFFIT</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ravel, B.; Newville, M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Synchrotron Radiation</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2005</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">537-541</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JSYRES</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0909-0495</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Blackwell Publishing Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A software package for the anal. of x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) data is presented.  This package is based on the IFEFFIT library of numerical and XAS algorithms and is written in the Perl programming language using the Perl/Tk graphics toolkit.  The programs described here are: (i) ATHENA, a program for XAS data processing, (ii) ARTEMIS, a program for EXAFS data anal. using theor. stds. from FEFF and (iii) HEPHAESTUS, a collection of beamline utilities based on tables of at. absorption data.  These programs enable high-quality data anal. that is accessible to novices while still powerful enough to meet the demands of an expert practitioner.  The programs run on all major computer platforms and are freely available under the terms of a free software license.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref36"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref36" class="refNumLink">36</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit36" data-doi="10.1107/s0909049500016964"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Newville, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">IFEFFIT: Interactive XAFS Analysis and FEFF Fitting</span>. <i>J. Synchrotron Radiat.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2001</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>8</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">322</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">324</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0909049500016964</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D8%26publication_year%3D2001%26pages%3D322-324%26journal%3DJ.%2BSynchrotron%2BRadiat.%26author%3DM.%2BNewville%26title%3DIFEFFIT%253A%2BInteractive%2BXAFS%2BAnalysis%2Band%2BFEFF%2BFitting%26doi%3D10.1107%252Fs0909049500016964&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1107%2Fs0909049500016964&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit36R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">36</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">IFEFFIT: interactive XAFS analysis and FEFF fitting</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Newville, Matthew</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Synchrotron Radiation</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2001</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">8</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">322-324</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JSYRES</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0909-0495</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Munksgaard International Publishers Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">IFEFFIT, an interactive program and scriptable library of XAFS algorithms is presented.  The core algorithms of AUTOBK and FEFFIT were combined with general data manipulation and interactive graphics into a single package.  IFEFFIT comes with a command-line program that can be run either interactively or in batch-mode.  It also provides a library of functions that can be used easily from C or Fortran, as well as high level scripting languages such as Tcl, Perl and Python.  Using this library, a Graphical User Interface for rapid 'online' data anal. is demonstrated.  IFEFFIT is freely available with an Open Source license.  Outside use, development, and contributions are encouraged.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref37"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref37" class="refNumLink">37</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit37"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wasylishen, R.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Ashbrook, S.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">WimperisVega, S. A. J.</span></span> <i>NMR of Quadrupolar Nuclei in Solid Materials</i>; <span class="NLM_publisher-name">Wiley</span>, <span class="NLM_year">2012</span>, pp  <span class="NLM_fpage">17</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">44</span>.<span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Quadrupolar Nuclei in Solids</span></span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26publication_year%3D2012%26pages%3D17-44%26author%3DR.%2BWasylishen%26author%3DS.%2BAshbrook%26author%3DS.%2BA.%2BJ.%2BWimperisVega%26title%3DNMR%2Bof%2BQuadrupolar%2BNuclei%2Bin%2BSolid%2BMaterials&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The use of a magic-angle turning and phase-adjusted spinning sideband NMR expt. to resolve and quantify the individual local environments in the high field 7Li and 31P NMR spectra of paramagnetic Li-ion battery materials is demonstrated.  The use of short radio frequency pulses provides an excitation bandwidth that is sufficient to cover shift anisotropy of &gt;1 MHz in breadth, allowing isotropic and anisotropic components to be resolved.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref39"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref39" class="refNumLink">39</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit39" data-doi="10.1021/ja306876u"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R.
