                10.1107/s0567739476001551</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D32%26publication_year%3D1976%26pages%3D751-767%26journal%3DActa%2BCrystallogr.%252C%2BSect.%2BA%253A%2BCryst.%2BPhys.%252C%2BDiffr.%252C%2BTheor.%2BGen.%2BCrystallogr.%26author%3DR.%2BD.%2BShannon%26title%3DRevised%2BEffective%2BIonic%2BRadii%2Band%2BSystematic%2BStudies%2Bof%2BInteratomic%2BDistances%2Bin%2BHalides%2Band%2BChalcogenides%26doi%3D10.1107%252Fs0567739476001551&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1107%2Fs0567739476001551&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref85"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref85" class="refNumLink">85</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit85" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.74.094105"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kang, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Factors That Affect Li Mobility in Layered Lithium Transition Metal Oxides</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2006</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>74</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">094105</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.74.094105</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D74%26publication_year%3D2006%26pages%3D094105%26journal%3DPhys.%2BRev.%2BB%253A%2BCondens.%2BMatter%2BMater.%2BPhys.%26author%3DK.%2BKang%26author%3DG.%2BCeder%26title%3DFactors%2BThat%2BAffect%2BLi%2BMobility%2Bin%2BLayered%2BLithium%2BTransition%2BMetal%2BOxides%26doi%3D10.1103%252Fphysrevb.74.094105&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1103%2Fphysrevb.74.094105&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit85R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">85</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Factors that affect Li mobility in layered lithium transition metal oxides</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kang, Kisuk; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2006</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">74</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">094105/1-094105/7</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1098-0121</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The diffusion const. of Li in electrode materials is a key aspect of the rate capability of rechargeable Li batteries.  The factors that affect Li mobility in layered Li transition metal oxides are systematically studied in this paper by first-principles calcns.  In close packed oxides octahedral ions diffuse by migrating through intermediate tetrahedral sites.  The activation barrier for Li hopping is strongly affected by the size of the tetrahedral site and the electrostatic interaction between Li+ in that site and the cation in the octahedron that shares a face with it.  The size of the tetrahedral site is detd. by the c-lattice parameter which has a remarkably strong effect on the activation barrier for Li migration.  The effect of other factors such as cation mixing and doping with nontransition metal ions can be interpreted quant. in terms of the size and electrostatic effect.  A general strategy to design high rate electrode materials is discussed.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref86"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref86" class="refNumLink">86</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit86" data-doi="10.1107/s2052520616008507"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gagné, O. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hawthorne, F. C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Bond-Length Distributions for Ions Bonded to Oxygen: Alkali and Alkaline-Earth Metals</span>. <i>Acta Crystallogr., Sect. B: Struct. Sci., Cryst. Eng. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>72</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">602</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">625</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s2052520616008507</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D72%26publication_year%3D2016%26pages%3D602-625%26journal%3DActa%2BCrystallogr.%252C%2BSect.%2BB%253A%2BStruct.%2BSci.%252C%2BCryst.%2BEng.%2BMater.%26author%3DO.%2BC.%2BGagn%25C3%25A9%26author%3DF.%2BC.%2BHawthorne%26title%3DBond-Length%2BDistributions%2Bfor%2BIons%2BBonded%2Bto%2BOxygen%253A%2BAlkali%2Band%2BAlkaline-Earth%2BMetals%26doi%3D10.1107%252Fs2052520616008507&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1107%2Fs2052520616008507&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit86R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">86</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Bond-length distributions for ions bonded to oxygen: alkali and alkaline-earth metals</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Gagne, Olivier Charles; Hawthorne, Frank Christopher</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Acta Crystallographica, Section B: Structural Science, Crystal Engineering and Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">72</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">602-625</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACSBDA</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2052-5206</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">International Union of Crystallography</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Bond-length distributions have been examd. for 55 configurations of alkali-metal ions and 29 configurations of alk.-earth-metal ions bonded to oxygen, for 4859 coordination polyhedra and 38 594 bond distances (alkali metals), and for 3038 coordination polyhedra and 24 487 bond distances (alk.-earth metals).  Bond lengths generally show a pos. skewed Gaussian distribution that originates from the variation in Born repulsion and Coulomb attraction as a function of interat. distance.  The skewness and kurtosis of these distributions generally decrease with increasing coordination no. of the central cation, a result of decreasing Born repulsion with increasing coordination no.  We confirm the following min. coordination nos.: [3]Li+, [3]Na+, [4]K+, [4]Rb+, [6]Cs+, [3]Be2+, [4]Mg2+, [6]Ca2+, [6]Sr2+ and [6]Ba2+, but note that some reported examples are the result of extensive dynamic and/or positional short-range disorder and are not ordered arrangements.  Some distributions of bond lengths are distinctly multi-modal.  This is commonly due to the occurrence of large nos. of structure refinements of a particular structure type in which a particular cation is always present, leading to an over-representation of a specific range of bond lengths.  Outliers in the distributions of mean bond lengths are often assocd. with anomalous values of at. displacement of the constituent cations and/or anions.  For a sample of [6]Na+, the ratio Ueq(Na)/Ueq(bonded anions) is partially correlated with 〈[6]Na+-O2-〉 (R2 = 0.57), suggesting that the mean bond length is correlated with vibrational/displacement characteristics of the constituent ions for a fixed coordination no.  Mean bond lengths also show a weak correlation with bond-length distortion from the mean value in general, although some coordination nos. show the widest variation in mean bond length for zero distortion, e.g.  Li+ in [4]- and [6]-coordination, Na+ in [4]- and [6]-coordination.  For alkali-metal and alk.-earth-metal ions, there is a pos. correlation between cation coordination no. and the grand mean incident bond-valence sum at the central cation, the values varying from 0.84 v.u. for [5]K+ to 1.06 v.u. for [8]Li+, and from 1.76 v.u. for [7]Ba2+ to 2.10 v.u. for [12]Sr2+.  Bond-valence arguments suggest coordination nos. higher than [12] for K+, Rb+, Cs+ and Ba2+.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref87"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref87" class="refNumLink">87</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit87" data-doi="10.1038/s41560-019-0410-6"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Assat, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Glazier, S. L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Delacourt, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tarascon, J.-M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Probing the Thermal Effects of Voltage Hysteresis in Anionic Redox-Based Lithium-Rich Cathodes Using Isothermal Calorimetry</span>. <i>Nat. Energy</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">647</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">656</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41560-019-0410-6</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D4%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D647-656%26journal%3DNat.%2BEnergy%26author%3DG.%2BAssat%26author%3DS.%2BL.%2BGlazier%26author%3DC.%2BDelacourt%26author%3DJ.-M.%2BTarascon%26title%3DProbing%2Bthe%2BThermal%2BEffects%2Bof%2BVoltage%2BHysteresis%2Bin%2BAnionic%2BRedox-Based%2BLithium-Rich%2BCathodes%2BUsing%2BIsothermal%2BCalorimetry%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fs41560-019-0410-6&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fs41560-019-0410-6&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit87R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">87</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Probing the thermal effects of voltage hysteresis in anionic redox-based lithium-rich cathodes using isothermal calorimetry</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Assat, Gaurav; Glazier, Stephen L.; Delacourt, Charles; Tarascon, Jean-Marie</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Energy</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">647-656</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NEANFD</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2058-7546</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The commercialization of high-energy batteries with lithium-rich cathode materials exhibiting combined cationic/anionic redox processes awaits the elimination of certain practical bottlenecks.  Among these, large voltage hysteresis remains the most obscure from a fundamental thermochem. perspective.  Here, we study this issue by directly measuring, via isothermal calorimetry, the heat generated by Li/Li2Ru0.75Sn0.25O3 (Li/LRSO) cells during various cycling conditions, with LRSO being a 'model' Li-rich layered cathode.  We show how this heat thermodynamically relates to the lost elec. work that is crucial for practical applications.  We further reveal that anionic redox on charging and discharging adopts different metastable paths having non-identical enthalpy potentials, such that the overall Li content no longer remains the unique reaction coordinate, unlike in fully path-reversible cationic redox.  We elucidate how quasi-static voltage hysteresis is related to heat dissipated due to non-equil. entropy prodn.  Overall, this study establishes the great benefits of isothermal calorimetry for enabling energy-efficient electrode materials in next-generation batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref88"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref88" class="refNumLink">88</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit88" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.8b13633"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Taylor, Z. N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perez, A. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Coca-Clemente, J. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Braga, F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Drewett, N. E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pitcher, M. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Thomas, W. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dyer, M. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Collins, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zanella, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Johnson, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Day, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tang, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dhanak, V. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Claridge, J. B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hardwick, L. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rosseinsky, M. J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Stabilization of O.O Bonds by d 0 Cations in Li 4+x Ni 1-x WO 6 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.25) Rock Salt Oxides as the Origin of Large Voltage Hysteresis</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>141</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">7333</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">7346</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.8b13633</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D141%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D7333-7346%26journal%3DJ.%2BAm.%2BChem.%2BSoc.%26author%3DZ.%2BN.%2BTaylor%26author%3DA.%2BJ.%2BPerez%26author%3DJ.%2BA.%2BCoca-Clemente%26author%3DF.%2BBraga%26author%3DN.%2BE.%2BDrewett%26author%3DM.%2BJ.%2BPitcher%26author%3DW.%2BJ.%2BThomas%26author%3DM.%2BS.%2BDyer%26author%3DC.%2BCollins%26author%3DM.%2BZanella%26author%3DT.%2BJohnson%26author%3DS.%2BDay%26author%3DC.%2BTang%26author%3DV.%2BR.%2BDhanak%26author%3DJ.%2BB.%2BClaridge%26author%3DL.%2BJ.%2BHardwick%26author%3DM.%2BJ.%2BRosseinsky%26title%3DStabilization%2Bof%2BO.O%2BBonds%2Bby%2Bd%2B0%2BCations%2Bin%2BLi%2B4%252Bx%2BNi%2B1-x%2BWO%2B6%2B%25280%2B%25E2%2589%25A4%2Bx%2B%25E2%2589%25A4%2B0.25%2529%2BRock%2BSalt%2BOxides%2Bas%2Bthe%2BOrigin%2Bof%2BLarge%2BVoltage%2BHysteresis%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fjacs.8b13633&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fjacs.8b13633&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit88R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">88</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Stabilization of O-O Bonds by d0 Cations in Li4+xNi1-xWO6 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.25) Rock Salt Oxides as the Origin of Large Voltage Hysteresis</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Taylor, Zoe N.; Perez, Arnaud J.; Coca-Clemente, Jose A.; Braga, Filipe; Drewett, Nicholas E.; Pitcher, Michael J.; Thomas, William J.; Dyer, Matthew S.; Collins, Christopher; Zanella, Marco; Johnson, Timothy; Day, Sarah; Tang, Chiu; Dhanak, Vinod R.; Claridge, John B.; Hardwick, Laurence J.; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">141</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">18</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">7333-7346</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Multinary lithium oxides with the rock salt structure are of technol. importance as cathode materials in rechargeable lithium ion batteries.  Current state-of-the-art cathodes such as LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 rely on redox cycling of earth-abundant transition-metal cations to provide charge capacity.  Recently, the possibility of using the oxide anion as a redox center in Li-rich rock salt oxides has been established as a new paradigm in the design of cathode materials with enhanced capacities (&gt; 200 mAh/g).  To increase the lithium content and access electrons from oxygen-derived states, these materials typically require transition metals in high oxidn. states, which can be easily achieved using d0 cations.  However, Li-rich rock salt oxides with high valent d0 cations such as Nb5+ and Mo6+ show strikingly high voltage hysteresis between charge and discharge, the origin of which is uninvestigated.  In this work, a series of Li-rich compds., Li4+xNi1-xWO6 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.25) are studied by adopting two new and distinct cation-ordered variants of the rock salt structure.  The Li4.15Ni0.85WO6 (x = 0.15) phase has a large reversible capacity of 200 mAh/g, without accessing the Ni3+/Ni4+ redox couple, implying that more than two-thirds of the capacity is due to anionic redox, with good cyclability.  The presence of the 5d0 W6+ cation affords extensive (&gt; 2 V) voltage hysteresis assocd. with the anionic redox.  The exptl. evidence is presented for the formation of strongly stabilized localized O-O single bonds that explain the energy penalty required to reduce the material upon discharge.  The high valent d0 cation assocs. localized anion-anion bonding with the anion redox capacity.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref89"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref89" class="refNumLink">89</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit89" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.8b11413"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jacquet, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Iadecola, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Saubanère, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Berg, E. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>141</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">11452</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">11464</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.8b11413</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D141%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D11452-11464%26journal%3DJ.%2BAm.%2BChem.%2BSoc.%26author%3DQ.%2BJacquet%26author%3DA.%2BIadecola%26author%3DM.%2BSauban%25C3%25A8re%26author%3DH.%2BLi%26author%3DE.%2BJ.%2BBerg%26author%3DG.%2BRousse%26author%3DJ.%2BCabana%26author%3DM.-L.%2BDoublet%26author%3DJ.-M.%2BTarascon%26title%3DCharge%2BTransfer%2BBand%2BGap%2Bas%2Ban%2BIndicator%2Bof%2BHysteresis%2Bin%2BLi-Disordered%2BRock%2BSalt%2BCathodes%2Bfor%2BLi-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fjacs.8b11413&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fjacs.8b11413&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit89R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">89</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Charge Transfer Band Gap as an Indicator of Hysteresis in Li-Disordered Rock Salt Cathodes for Li-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Jacquet, Quentin; Iadecola, Antonella; Saubanere, Matthieu; Li, Haifeng; Berg, Erik. J.; Rousse, Gwenaelle; Cabana, Jordi; Doublet, Marie-Liesse; Tarascon, Jean-Marie</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">141</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">29</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">11452-11464</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Disordered rock salt cathodes showing both anionic and cationic redox are being extensively studied for their very high energy storage capacity.  Mn-based disordered rock salt compds. show much higher energy efficiency compared to the Ni-based materials as a result of the different voltage hysteresis, 0.5 and 2 V, resp.  To understand the origin of this difference, the design is reported of two model compds., Li1.3Ni0.27Ta0.43O2 and Li1.3Mn0.4Ta0.3O2, and their charge compensation mechanism is studied through the uptake and removal of Li via an arsenal of anal. techniques.  It is show that the different voltage hysteresis with Ni or Mn substitution is due to the different redn. potential for anionic redox.  The finding is rationalized by DFT calcns. and this phenomenon is proposed to be nested in the smaller charge transfer band gap of the Ni-based compds. compared to that of the Mn ones.  Altogether, these findings provide vital guidelines for designing high-capacity disordered rock salt cathode materials based on anionic redox activity for the next generation of Li ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref90"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref90" class="refNumLink">90</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit90" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00772"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Song, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tang, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Borkiewicz, O. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>31</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">3756</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3765</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00772</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D31%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D3756-3765%26journal%3DChem.%2BMater.%26author%3DB.%2BSong%26author%3DM.%2BTang%26author%3DE.%2BHu%26author%3DO.%2BJ.%2BBorkiewicz%26author%3DK.%2BM.%2BWiaderek%26author%3DY.%2BZhang%26author%3DN.%2BD.%2BPhillip%26author%3DX.%2BLiu%26author%3DZ.%2BShadike%26author%3DC.%2BLi%26author%3DL.%2BSong%26author%3DY.-Y.%2BHu%26author%3DM.%2BChi%26author%3DG.%2BM.%2BVeith%26author%3DX.-Q.%2BYang%26author%3DJ.%2BLiu%26author%3DJ.%2BNanda%26author%3DK.%2BPage%26author%3DA.%2BHuq%26title%3DUnderstanding%2Bthe%2BLow-Voltage%2BHysteresis%2Bof%2BAnionic%2BRedox%2Bin%2BNa%2B2%2BMn%2B3%2BO%2B7%26doi%3D10.1021%252Facs.chemmater.9b00772&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.9b00772&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit90R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">90</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Understanding the Low-Voltage Hysteresis of Anionic Redox in Na2Mn3O7</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Song, Bohang; Tang, Mingxue; Hu, Enyuan; Borkiewicz, Olaf J.; Wiaderek, Kamila M.; Zhang, Yiman; Phillip, Nathan D.; Liu, Xiaoming; Shadike, Zulipiya; Li, Cheng; Song, Likai; Hu, Yan-Yan; Chi, Miaofang; Veith, Gabriel M.; Yang, Xiao-Qing; Liu, Jue; Nanda, Jagjit; Page, Katharine; Huq, Ashfia</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">31</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">10</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3756-3765</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The large-voltage hysteresis remains one of the biggest barriers to optimizing Li/Na-ion cathodes using lattice anionic redox reaction, despite their very high energy d. and relative low cost.  Very recently, a layered sodium cathode Na2Mn3O7 (or Na4/7Mn6/7.box.1/7O2, .box. is vacancy) was reported to have reversible lattice oxygen redox with much suppressed voltage hysteresis.  However, the structural and electronic structural origin of this small-voltage hysteresis has not been well understood.  In this article, through systematic studies using ex situ/in situ ESR and X-ray diffraction, we demonstrate that the exceptional small-voltage hysteresis (&lt;50 mV) between charge and discharge curves is rooted in the well-maintained oxygen stacking sequence in the absence of irreversible gliding of oxygen layers and cation migration from the transition-metal layers.  In addn., we further identify that the 4.2 V charge/discharge plateau is assocd. with a zero-strain (de)intercalation process of Na+ ions from distorted octahedral sites, while the 4.5 V plateau is linked to a reversible shrink/expansion process of the manganese-site vacancy during (de)intercalation of Na+ ions at distorted prismatic sites.  It is expected that these findings will inspire further exploration of new cathode materials that can achieve both high energy d. and efficiency by using lattice anionic redox.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref91"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref91" class="refNumLink">91</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit91" data-doi="10.1038/s41563-018-0276-1"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hong, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gent, W. E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xiao, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lim, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Seo, D.-H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wu, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Csernica, P. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Nordlund, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, C.-J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Stone, K. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Passarello, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Prendergast, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Toney, M. F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chueh, W. C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Metal–Oxygen Decoordination Stabilizes Anion Redox in Li-Rich Oxides</span>. <i>Nat. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>18</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">256</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">265</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41563-018-0276-1</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D18%26publication_year%3D2019%26pages%3D256-265%26journal%3DNat.%2BMater.%26author%3DJ.%2BHong%26author%3DW.%2BE.%2BGent%26author%3DP.%2BXiao%26author%3DK.%2BLim%26author%3DD.-H.%2BSeo%26author%3DJ.%2BWu%26author%3DP.%2BM.%2BCsernica%26author%3DC.%2BJ.%2BTakacs%26author%3DD.%2BNordlund%26author%3DC.-J.%2BSun%26author%3DK.%2BH.%2BStone%26author%3DD.%2BPassarello%26author%3DW.%2BYang%26author%3DD.%2BPrendergast%26author%3DG.%2BCeder%26author%3DM.%2BF.%2BToney%26author%3DW.%2BC.%2BChueh%26title%3DMetal%25E2%2580%2593Oxygen%2BDecoordination%2BStabilizes%2BAnion%2BRedox%2Bin%2BLi-Rich%2BOxides%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fs41563-018-0276-1&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fs41563-018-0276-1&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit91R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">91</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Metal-oxygen decoordination stabilizes anion redox in Li-rich oxides</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Hong, Jihyun; Gent, William E.; Xiao, Penghao; Lim, Kipil; Seo, Dong-Hwa; Wu, Jinpeng; Csernica, Peter M.; Takacs, Christopher J.; Nordlund, Dennis; Sun, Cheng-Jun; Stone, Kevin H.; Passarello, Donata; Yang, Wanli; Prendergast, David; Ceder, Gerbrand; Toney, Michael F.; Chueh, William C.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">18</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">256-265</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NMAACR</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1476-1122</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Reversible high-voltage redox chem. is an essential component of many electrochem. technologies, from (electro)catalysts to lithium-ion batteries.  Oxygen-anion redox has garnered intense interest for such applications, particularly lithium-ion batteries, as it offers substantial redox capacity at more than 4 V vs. Li/Li+ in a variety of oxide materials.  However, oxidn. of oxygen is almost universally correlated with irreversible local structural transformations, voltage hysteresis and voltage fade, which currently preclude its widespread use.  By comprehensively studying the Li2-xIr1-ySnyO3 model system, which exhibits tunable oxidn. state and structural evolution with y upon cycling, we reveal that this structure-redox coupling arises from the local stabilization of short approx. 1.8 Å metal-oxygen π bonds and approx. 1.4 Å O-O dimers during oxygen redox, which occurs in Li2-xIr1-ySnyO3 through ligand-to-metal charge transfer.  Crucially, formation of these oxidized oxygen species necessitates the decoordination of oxygen to a single covalent bonding partner through formation of vacancies at neighboring cation sites, driving cation disorder.  These insights establish a point-defect explanation for why anion redox often occurs alongside local structural disordering and voltage hysteresis during cycling.  Our findings offer an explanation for the unique electrochem. properties of lithium-rich layered oxides, with implications generally for the design of materials employing oxygen redox chem.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref92"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref92" class="refNumLink">92</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit92" data-doi="10.1038/nmat3964"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ma, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Su, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chisnell, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ong, S. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Toumar, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Idrobo, J.-C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lei, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bai, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lynn, J. W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, Y. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Direct Visualization of the Jahn–Teller Effect Coupled to Na Ordering in Na 5/8 MnO 2</span>. <i>Nat. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>13</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">586</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">592</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/nmat3964</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D13%26publication_year%3D2014%26pages%3D586-592%26journal%3DNat.%2BMater.%26author%3DX.%2BLi%26author%3DX.%2BMa%26author%3DD.%2BSu%26author%3DL.%2BLiu%26author%3DR.%2BChisnell%26author%3DS.%2BP.%2BOng%26author%3DH.%2BChen%26author%3DA.%2BToumar%26author%3DJ.-C.%2BIdrobo%26author%3DY.%2BLei%26author%3DJ.%2BBai%26author%3DF.%2BWang%26author%3DJ.%2BW.%2BLynn%26author%3DY.%2BS.%2BLee%26author%3DG.%2BCeder%26title%3DDirect%2BVisualization%2Bof%2Bthe%2BJahn%25E2%2580%2593Teller%2BEffect%2BCoupled%2Bto%2BNa%2BOrdering%2Bin%2BNa%2B5%252F8%2BMnO%2B2%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fnmat3964&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fnmat3964&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit92R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">92</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Direct visualization of the Jahn-Teller effect coupled to Na ordering in Na5/8MnO2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Li, Xin; Ma, Xiaohua; Su, Dong; Liu, Lei; Chisnell, Robin; Ong, Shyue Ping; Chen, Hailong; Toumar, Alexandra; Idrobo, Juan-Carlos; Lei, Yuechuan; Bai, Jianming; Wang, Feng; Lynn, Jeffrey W.; Lee, Young S.; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">13</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">586-592</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NMAACR</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1476-1122</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Publishing Group</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The cooperative Jahn-Teller effect (CJTE) refers to the correlation of distortions arising from individual Jahn-Teller centers in complex compds.  The effect usually induces strong coupling between the static or dynamic charge, orbital and magnetic ordering, which was related to many important phenomena such as colossal magnetoresistance and supercond.  The authors report a Na5/8MnO2 superstructure with a pronounced static CJTE that is coupled to an unusual Na vacancy ordering.  The authors visualize this coupled distortion and Na ordering down to the at. scale.  The Mn planes are periodically distorted by a charge modulation on the Mn stripes, which in turn drives an unusually large displacement of some Na ions through long-ranged Na-O-Mn3+-O-Na interactions into a highly distorted octahedral site.  At lower temps., magnetic order appears, in which Mn at. stripes with different magnetic couplings are interwoven with each other.  The authors' work demonstrates the strong interaction between alkali ordering, displacement, and electronic and magnetic structure, and underlines the important role that structural details play in detg. electronic behavior.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref93"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref93" class="refNumLink">93</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit93" data-doi="10.1103/physrevapplied.4.064002"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Toumar, A. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ong, S. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Richards, W. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dacek, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Vacancy Ordering in O3 -Type Layered Metal Oxide Sodium-Ion Battery Cathodes</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. Appl.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">064002</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevapplied.4.064002</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D4%26publication_year%3D2015%26pages%3D064002%26journal%3DPhys.%2BRev.%2BAppl.%26author%3DA.%2BJ.%2BToumar%26author%3DS.%2BP.%2BOng%26author%3DW.%2BD.%2BRichards%26author%3DS.%2BDacek%26author%3DG.%2BCeder%26title%3DVacancy%2BOrdering%2Bin%2BO3%2B-Type%2BLayered%2BMetal%2BOxide%2BSodium-Ion%2BBattery%2BCathodes%26doi%3D10.1103%252Fphysrevapplied.4.064002&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1103%2Fphysrevapplied.4.064002&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit93R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">93</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Vacancy ordering in O3-type layered metal oxide sodium-ion battery cathodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Toumar, Alexandra J.; Ong, Shyue Ping; Richards, William Davidson; Dacek, Stephen; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review Applied</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">064002/1-064002/9</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRAHB2</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2331-7019</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Current state-of-the-art Na-ion battery cathodes are selected from the broad chem. space of layered first-row transition-metal (TM) oxides.  Unlike their lithium-ion counterparts, seven first-row layered TM oxides can intercalate Na ions reversibly.  Their voltage curves indicate significant and numerous reversible phase transformations during electrochem. cycling.  These transformations are not yet fully understood but arise from Na-ion vacancy ordering and metal oxide slab glide.  In this study, we investigate the nature of vacancy ordering within the O3 host lattice framework.  We generate predicted electrochem. voltage curves for each of the Na-ion intercalating layered TM oxides by using a high-throughput framework of d.-functional-theory calcns.  We det. a set of vacancy-ordered phases appearing as ground states in all NaxMO2 systems and investigate the energy effect of the stacking of adjacent layers.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref94"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref94" class="refNumLink">94</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit94" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.9b13551"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grenier, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reeves, P. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Seymour, I. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Märker, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wiaderek, K. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chupas, P. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chapman, K. W.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Intrinsic Kinetic Limitations in Substituted Lithium Layered Transition-Metal Oxide Electrodes</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>142</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">7001</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">7011</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.9b13551</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D142%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D7001-7011%26journal%3DJ.%2BAm.%2BChem.%2BSoc.%26author%3DA.%2BGrenier%26author%3DP.%2BJ.%2BReeves%26author%3DH.%2BLiu%26author%3DI.%2BD.%2BSeymour%26author%3DK.%2BM%25C3%25A4rker%26author%3DK.%2BM.%2BWiaderek%26author%3DP.%2BJ.%2BChupas%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26author%3DK.%2BW.%2BChapman%26title%3DIntrinsic%2BKinetic%2BLimitations%2Bin%2BSubstituted%2BLithium%2BLayered%2BTransition-Metal%2BOxide%2BElectrodes%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fjacs.9b13551&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fjacs.9b13551&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit94R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">94</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Intrinsic Kinetic Limitations in Substituted Lithium-Layered Transition-Metal Oxide Electrodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Grenier, Antonin; Reeves, Philip J.; Liu, Hao; Seymour, Ieuan D.; Marker, Katharina; Wiaderek, Kamila M.; Chupas, Peter J.; Grey, Clare P.; Chapman, Karena W.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">142</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">15</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">7001-7011</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Substituted Li-layered transition-metal oxide (LTMO) electrodes such as LixNiyMnzCo1-y-zO2 (NMC) and LixNiyCo1-y-zAlzO2 (NCA) show reduced first cycle Coulombic efficiency (90-87% under std. cycling conditions) in comparison with the archetypal LixCoO2 (LCO; ~ 98% efficiency).  Focusing on LixNi0.8Co0.15Al0.05O2 as a model compd., we use operando synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD) and NMR (NMR) spectroscopy to demonstrate that the apparent first-cycle capacity loss is a kinetic effect linked to limited Li mobility at x &gt; 0.88, with near full capacity recovered during a potentiostatic hold following the galvanostatic charge-discharge cycle.  This kinetic capacity loss, unlike many capacity losses in LTMOs, is independent of the cutoff voltage during delithiation and it is a reversible process.  The kinetic limitation manifests not only as the kinetic capacity loss during discharge but as a subtle bimodal compositional distribution early in charge and, also, a dramatic increase of the charge-discharge voltage hysteresis at x &gt; 0.88. 7Li NMR measurements indicate that the kinetic limitation reflects limited Li transport at x &gt; 0.86.  Electrochem. measurements on a wider range of LTMOs including Lix(Ni,Fe)yCo1-yO2 suggest that 5% substitution is sufficient to induce the kinetic limitation and that the effect is not limited to Ni substitution.  We outline how, in addn. to a redn. in the no. of Li vacancies and shrinkage of the Li-layer size, the intrinsic charge storage mechanism (two-phase vs solid-soln.) and localization of charge give rise to addnl. kinetic barriers in NCA and nonmetallic LTMOs in general.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref95"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref95" class="refNumLink">95</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit95" data-doi="10.1038/s41563-020-0767-8"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xu, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Märker, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mahadevegowda, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reeves, P. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Day, S. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Groh, M.                 10.1038/s41563-020-0767-8</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D20%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D84-92%26journal%3DNat.%2BMater.%26author%3DC.%2BXu%26author%3DK.%2BM%25C3%25A4rker%26author%3DJ.%2BLee%26author%3DA.%2BMahadevegowda%26author%3DP.%2BJ.%2BReeves%26author%3DS.%2BJ.%2BDay%26author%3DM.%2BF.%2BGroh%26author%3DS.%2BP.%2BEmge%26author%3DC.%2BDucati%26author%3DB.%2BLayla%2BMehdi%26author%3DC.%2BC.%2BTang%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26title%3DBulk%2BFatigue%2BInduced%2Bby%2BSurface%2BReconstruction%2Bin%2BLayered%2BNi-Rich%2BCathodes%2Bfor%2BLi-Ion%2BBatteries%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fs41563-020-0767-8&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fs41563-020-0767-8&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord empty" id="

C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Coupling between Oxygen Redox and Cation Migration Explains Unusual Electrochemistry in Lithium-Rich Layered Oxides</span>. <i>Nat. Commun.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2017</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>8</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">2091</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41467-017-02041-x</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D8%26publication_year%3D2017%26pages%3D2091%26journal%3DNat.%2BCommun.%26author%3DW.%2BE.%2BGent%26author%3DK.%2BLim%26author%3DY.%2BLiang%26author%3DQ.%2BLi%26author%3DT.%2BBarnes%26author%3DS.-J.%2BAhn%26author%3DK.%2BH.%2BStone%26author%3DM.%2BMcIntire%26author%3DJ.%2BHong%26author%3DJ.%2BH.%2BSong%26author%3DY.%2BLi%26author%3DA.%2BMehta%26author%3DS.%2BErmon%26author%3DT.%2BTyliszczak%26author%3DD.%2BKilcoyne%26author%3DD.%2BVine%26author%3DJ.-H.%2BPark%26author%3DS.-K.%2BDoo%26author%3DM.%2BF.%2BToney%26author%3DW.%2BYang%26author%3DD.%2BPrendergast%26author%3DW.%2BC.%2BChueh%26title%3DCoupling%2Bbetween%2BOxygen%2BRedox%2Band%2BCation%2BMigration%2BExplains%2BUnusual%2BElectrochemistry%2Bin%2BLithium-Rich%2BLayered%2BOxides%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fs41467-017-02041-x&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fs41467-017-02041-x&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit96R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">96</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Coupling between oxygen redox and cation migration explains unusual electrochemistry in lithium-rich layered oxides</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Gent William E; Gent William E; Li Qinghao; Tyliszczak Tolek; Kilcoyne David; Vine David; Yang Wanli; Lim Kipil; Hong Jihyun; Li Yiyang; Chueh William C; Lim Kipil; Stone Kevin H; Hong Jihyun; Mehta Apurva; Toney Michael F; Liang Yufeng; Barnes Taylor; Prendergast David; Li Qinghao; Ahn Sung-Jin; Park Jin-Hwan; Doo Seok-Kwang; McIntire Mitchell; Ermon Stefano; Song Jay Hyok; Toney Michael F; Chueh William C</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2017</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">8</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2091</span>
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn"></span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">Lithium-rich layered transition metal oxide positive electrodes offer access to anion redox at high potentials, thereby promising high energy densities for lithium-ion batteries.  However, anion redox is also associated with several unfavorable electrochemical properties, such as open-circuit voltage hysteresis.  Here we reveal that in Li1.17-x Ni0.21Co0.08Mn0.54O2, these properties arise from a strong coupling between anion redox and cation migration.  We combine various X-ray spectroscopic, microscopic, and structural probes to show that partially reversible transition metal migration decreases the potential of the bulk oxygen redox couple by &gt; 1 V, leading to a reordering in the anionic and cationic redox potentials during cycling.  First principles calculations show that this is due to the drastic change in the local oxygen coordination environments associated with the transition metal migration.  We propose that this mechanism is involved in stabilizing the oxygen redox couple, which we observe spectroscopically to persist for 500 charge/discharge cycles.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref97"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref97" class="refNumLink">97</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit97" data-doi="10.1016/j.jssc.2005.05.027"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bréger, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jiang, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dupré, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meng, Y. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shao-Horn, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">High-Resolution X-Ray Diffraction, DIFFaX, NMR and First Principles Study of Disorder in the Li 2MnO 3-Li[Ni 1/2Mn 1/2]O 2 Solid Solution</span>. <i>J. Solid State Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2005</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>178</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">2575</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2585</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.jssc.2005.05.027</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D178%26publication_year%3D2005%26pages%3D2575-2585%26journal%3DJ.%2BSolid%2BState%2BChem.%26author%3DJ.%2BBr%25C3%25A9ger%26author%3DM.%2BJiang%26author%3DN.%2BDupr%25C3%25A9%26author%3DY.%2BS.%2BMeng%26author%3DY.%2BShao-Horn%26author%3DG.%2BCeder%26author%3DC.%2BP.%2BGrey%26title%3DHigh-Resolution%2BX-Ray%2BDiffraction%252C%2BDIFFaX%252C%2BNMR%2Band%2BFirst%2BPrinciples%2BStudy%2Bof%2BDisorder%2Bin%2Bthe%2BLi%2B2MnO%2B3-Li%255BNi%2B1%252F2Mn%2B1%252F2%255DO%2B2%2BSolid%2BSolution%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.jssc.2005.05.027&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.jssc.2005.05.027&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit97R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">97</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">High-resolution x-ray diffraction, DIFFaX, NMR and first principles study of disorder in the Li2MnO3-Li[Ni1/2Mn1/2]O2 solid solution</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Breger, Julien; Jiang, Meng; Dupre, Nicolas; Meng, Ying S.; Yang, Shao-Horn; Ceder, Gerbrand; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Solid State Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2005</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">178</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2575-2585</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JSSCBI</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0022-4596</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">X-ray diffraction patterns of Li[Li(1-2x)/3NixMn2/3-x/3]O2 show reflections between 20° and 35°, 2θ (CuKα) due to Li2MnO3-like ordering of the transition metal (Ni, Mn and Li) layers.  The ordering is rarely perfect, resulting in characteristic broadening and changes in the intensities of these reflections. 6Li MAS NMR studies of Li2MnO3 show that the [Li1/3Mn2/3] layers are well ordered, the disorder arising from the stacking of the layers in the c-direction.  DIFFaX was used to model the Li2MnO3 XRD data and ext. the stacking fault frequency.  Even well-ordered cation layers may show only weak or no superstructure reflections, if there is no or little ordering in the c-direction.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref98"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref98" class="refNumLink">98</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit98" data-doi="10.1016/j.joule.2020.05.004"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gent, W. E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Abate, I. I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Nazar, L. F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chueh, W. C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Design Rules for High-Valent Redox in Intercalation Electrodes</span>. <i>Joule</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1369</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1397</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.joule.2020.05.004</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D4%26publication_year%3D2020%26pages%3D1369-1397%26journal%3DJoule%26author%3DW.%2BE.%2BGent%26author%3DI.%2BI.%2BAbate%26author%3DW.%2BYang%26author%3DL.%2BF.%2BNazar%26author%3DW.%2BC.%2BChueh%26title%3DDesign%2BRules%2Bfor%2BHigh-Valent%2BRedox%2Bin%2BIntercalation%2BElectrodes%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.joule.2020.05.004&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.joule.2020.05.004&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit98R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">98</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Design Rules for High-Valent Redox in Intercalation Electrodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Gent, William E.; Abate, Iwnetim Iwnetu; Yang, Wanli; Nazar, Linda F.; Chueh, William C.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Joule</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1369-1397</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JOULBR</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2542-4351</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Cell Press</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">High-valent redox, where over-oxidn. of oxygen or transition metals (TMs) drives extensive charge sharing through the formation of short covalent bonds, has historically been avoided in intercalation electrodes because of its assocn. with structural disorder and electrochem. irreversibility.  Here, we present a perspective on the origin of these undesirable behaviors and materials design criteria to mitigate them.  Drawing parallels between oxygen redox and high-valent TM redox (e.g., CrIII/VI and VIII/V), we reveal that the defect formation energy landscape is the primary factor controlling the electrochem. reversibility of high-valent redox, as it dets. which defects form to accommodate the short covalent bonds as well as the nature of those covalent bonding arrangements.  By tuning the defect formation energy landscape, researchers can control the nature of the oxidized species while minimizing structural disorder.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref99"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref99" class="refNumLink">99</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit99" data-doi="10.1016/j.nanoen.2018.03.007"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gao, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shen, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kong, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yu, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lu, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, L.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Iron Migration and Oxygen Oxidation during Sodium Extraction from NaFeO2</span>. <i>Nano Energy</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>47</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">519</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">526</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.nanoen.2018.03.007</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D47%26publication_year%3D2018%26pages%3D519-526%26journal%3DNano%2BEnergy%26author%3DY.%2BLi%26author%3DY.%2BGao%26author%3DX.%2BWang%26author%3DX.%2BShen%26author%3DQ.%2BKong%26author%3DR.%2BYu%26author%3DG.%2BLu%26author%3DZ.%2BWang%26author%3DL.%2BChen%26title%3DIron%2BMigration%2Band%2BOxygen%2BOxidation%2Bduring%2BSodium%2BExtraction%2Bfrom%2BNaFeO2%26doi%3D10.1016%252Fj.nanoen.2018.03.007&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1016%2Fj.nanoen.2018.03.007&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit99R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">99</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Iron migration and oxygen oxidation during sodium extraction from NaFeO2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Li, Yejing; Gao, Yurui; Wang, Xuefeng; Shen, Xi; Kong, Qingyu; Yu, Richeng; Lu, Gang; Wang, Zhaoxiang; Chen, Liquan</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nano Energy</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">47</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">519-526</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NEANCA</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2211-2855</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The abundant resource of sodium (Na) makes the Na-ion batteries a promising alternate to the Li-ion batteries in elec. energy storage, esp. when iron (Fe)-based oxide electrodes are used.  Layer-structured NaxFeyM1-yO2 (M for Mn and Ni, etc.), for example, has drawn much attention and is one type of the most attractive cathode materials for the Na-ion batteries.  However, the poor cycling performance hinders their applications and the underneath mechanism for their poor performances remains unclear.  In this study, the structural transition of NaFeO2 was characterized and the driving forces for the irreversible Fe migration and O oxidn. were explored during Na extn.  The Fe migration from the Fe layer to the Na layer was obsd. for the first time at the at. scale.  The chem. states and coordination environment of the Fe ions within the Na layer were detd.  The d. functional theory (DFT) calcns. were carried out to understand the Fe migration and O oxidn.  These findings provide helpful revelation on constructing the structure and improving the performance of the NaFeO2-structured cathode materials for the Na-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref100"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref100" class="refNumLink">100</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit100" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.0c10704"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kitchaev, D. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Vinckeviciute, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Van Der Ven, A.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Delocalized Metal–Oxygen π-Redox Is the Origin of Anomalous Nonhysteretic Capacity in Li-Ion and Na-Ion Cathode Materials</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>143</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1908</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1916</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.0c10704</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D143%26publication_year%3D2021%26pages%3D1908-1916%26journal%3DJ.%2BAm.%2BChem.%2BSoc.%26author%3DD.%2BA.%2BKitchaev%26author%3DJ.%2BVinckeviciute%26author%3DA.%2BVan%2BDer%2BVen%26title%3DDelocalized%2BMetal%25E2%2580%2593Oxygen%2B%25CF%2580-Redox%2BIs%2Bthe%2BOrigin%2Bof%2BAnomalous%2BNonhysteretic%2BCapacity%2Bin%2BLi-Ion%2Band%2BNa-Ion%2BCathode%2BMaterials%26doi%3D10.1021%252Fjacs.0c10704&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1021%2Fjacs.0c10704&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit100R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">100</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Delocalized Metal-Oxygen π-Redox Is the Origin of Anomalous Nonhysteretic Capacity in Li-Ion and Na-Ion Cathode Materials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kitchaev, Daniil A.; Vinckeviciute, Julija; Van der Ven, Anton</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2021</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">143</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1908-1916</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The anomalous capacity of Li-excess cathode materials has ignited a vigorous debate over the nature of the underlying redox mechanism, which promises to substantially increase the energy d. of rechargeable batteries.  Unfortunately, nearly all materials exhibiting this anomalous capacity suffer from irreversible structural changes and voltage hysteresis.  Nonhysteretic excess capacity has been demonstrated in Na2Mn3O7 and Li2IrO3, making these materials key to understanding the electronic, chem., and structural properties that are necessary to achieve reversible excess capacity.  Here, high-fidelity random-phase-approxn. (RPA) electronic structure calcns. and group theory are used to derive the first fully consistent mechanism of nonhysteretic oxidn. beyond the transition metal limit, explaining the electrochem. and structural evolution of the Na2Mn3O7 and Li2IrO3 model materials.  It is shown that the source of anomalous nonhysteretic capacity is a network of π-bonded metal-d and O-p orbitals, whose activity is enabled by a unique resistance to transition metal migration.  The π-network forms a collective, delocalized redox center.  It is shown that the voltage, accessible capacity, and structural evolution upon oxidn. are collective properties of the π-network rather than that of any local bonding environment.  The results establish the first rigorous framework linking anomalous capacity to transition metal chem. and long-range structure, laying the groundwork for engineering materials that exhibit truly reversible capacity exceeding that of transition metal redox.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="ref101"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="javascript:void(0);" data-citation="" data-rid="ref101" class="refNumLink">101</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="cit101" data-doi="10.1038/s41467-020-20169-1"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Feng, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Cui, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhu, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gong, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Girard, M. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lajoie, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Trottier, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhang, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gu, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zuo, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Goodenough, J. B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zaghib, K.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Pillar-Beam Structures Prevent Layered Cathode Materials from Destructive Phase Transitions</span>. <i>Nat. Commun.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2021</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">13</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41467-020-20169-1</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><span class="references__suffix"><a class="google-scholar" href="/action/getFTRLinkout?url=http%3A%2F%2Fscholar.google.com%2Fscholar_lookup%3Fhl%3Den%26volume%3D12%26publication_year%3D2021%26pages%3D13%26journal%3DNat.%2BCommun.%26author%3DY.%2BWang%26author%3DZ.%2BFeng%26author%3DP.%2BCui%26author%3DW.%2BZhu%26author%3DY.%2BGong%26author%3DM.%2BA.%2BGirard%26author%3DG.%2BLajoie%26author%3DJ.%2BTrottier%26author%3DQ.%2BZhang%26author%3DL.%2BGu%26author%3DY.%2BWang%26author%3DW.%2BZuo%26author%3DY.%2BYang%26author%3DJ.%2BB.%2BGoodenough%26author%3DK.%2BZaghib%26title%3DPillar-Beam%2BStructures%2BPrevent%2BLayered%2BCathode%2BMaterials%2Bfrom%2BDestructive%2BPhase%2BTransitions%26doi%3D10.1038%252Fs41467-020-20169-1&amp;doi=10.1021%2Facs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;doiOfLink=10.1038%2Fs41467-020-20169-1&amp;linkType=gs&amp;linkLocation=Reference&amp;linkSource=FULL_TEXT" target="_blank">Google Scholar</a></span><div class="casRecord" id="
                        cas_cit101R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">101</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Pillar-beam structures prevent layered cathode materials from destructive phase transitions</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Wang, Yuesheng; Feng, Zimin; Cui, Peixin; Zhu, Wen; Gong, Yue; Girard, Marc-Andre; Lajoie, Gilles; Trottier, Julie; Zhang, Qinghua; Gu, Lin; Wang, Yan; Zuo, Wenhua; Yang, Yong; Goodenough, John B.; Zaghib, Karim</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Communications</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2021</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">13</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NCAOBW</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2041-1723</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Energy storage with high energy d. and low cost has been the subject of a decades-long pursuit.  Sodium-ion batteries are well expected because they utilize abundant resources.  However, the lack of competent cathodes with both large capacities and long cycle lives prevents the commercialization of sodium-ion batteries.  Conventional cathodes with hexagonal-P2-type structures suffer from structural degrdns. when the sodium content falls below 33%, or when the integral anions participate in gas evolution reactions.  Here, we show a "pillar-beam" structure for sodium-ion battery cathodes where a few inert potassium ions uphold the layer-structured framework, while the working sodium ions could diffuse freely.  The thus-created unorthodox orthogonal-P2 K0.4[Ni0.2Mn0.8]O2 cathode delivers a capacity of 194 mAh/g at 0.1 C, a rate capacity of 84% at 1 C, and an 86% capacity retention after 500 cycles at 1 C.  The addn. of the potassium ions boosts simultaneously the energy d. and the cycle life.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li></ol></div><script type="text/javascript" nonce="93187cd67a9f0762-MAN">window.refViewer={'ref1':['cit1'],'ref2':['cit2'],'ref3':['cit3'],'ref4':['cit4'],'ref5':['cit5'],'ref6':['cit6'],'ref7':['cit7'],'ref8':['cit8'],'ref9':['cit9'],'ref10':['cit10'],'ref11':['cit11'],'ref12':['cit12'],'ref13':['cit13'],'ref14':['cit14'],'ref15':['cit15'],'ref16':['cit16'],'ref17':['cit17'],'ref18':['cit18'],'ref19':['cit19'],'ref20':['cit20'],'ref21':['cit21'],'ref22':['cit22'],'ref23':['cit23'],'ref24':['cit24'],'ref25':['cit25'],'ref26':['cit26'],'ref27':['cit27'],'ref28':['cit28'],'ref29':['cit29'],'ref30':['cit30'],'ref31':['cit31'],'ref32':['cit32'],'ref33':['cit33'],'ref34':['cit34'],'ref35':['cit35'],'ref36':['cit36'],'ref37':['cit37'],'ref38':['cit38'],'ref39':['cit39'],'ref40':['cit40'],'ref41':['cit41'],'ref42':['cit42'],'ref43':['cit43'],'ref44':['cit44'],'ref45':['cit45'],'ref46':['cit46'],'ref47':['cit47'],'ref48':['cit48'],'ref49':['cit49'],'ref50':['cit50'],'ref51':['cit51'],'ref52':['cit52'],'ref53':['cit53'],'ref54':['cit54'],'ref55':['cit55'],'ref56':['cit56'],'ref57':['cit57'],'ref58':['cit58'],'ref59':['cit59'],'ref60':['cit60'],'ref61':['cit61'],'ref62':['cit62'],'ref63':['cit63'],'ref64':['cit64'],'ref65':['cit65'],'ref66':['cit66'],'ref67':['cit67'],'ref68':['cit68'],'ref69':['cit69'],'ref70':['cit70'],'ref71':['cit71'],'ref72':['cit72'],'ref73':['cit73'],'ref74':['cit74'],'ref75':['cit75'],'ref76':['cit76'],'ref77':['cit77'],'ref78':['cit78'],'ref79':['cit79'],'ref80':['cit80'],'ref81':['cit81'],'ref82':['cit82'],'ref83':['cit83'],'ref84':['cit84'],'ref85':['cit85'],'ref86':['cit86'],'ref87':['cit87'],'ref88':['cit88'],'ref89':['cit89'],'ref90':['cit90'],'ref91':['cit91'],'ref92':['cit92'],'ref93':['cit93'],'ref94':['cit94'],'ref95':['cit95'],'ref96':['cit96'],'ref97':['cit97'],'ref98':['cit98'],'ref99':['cit99'],'ref100':['cit100'],'ref101':['cit101']}</script><div calculated.</a></p></div></div></div></div></div><div class="recommendedDropzone7" data-pb-dropzone="recommendedDropzone7"><div class="show-recommended__wrapper collapsed"><h2
