aria-labelledby="pane-m1" class="tab__pane tab__pane-figures active"><figure data-id="_i1" data-index="0" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Abstract</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#_i1"><img class="rightTab-fig internalNav" src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0010.gif" alt="" id="rightTab-tgr1"></a><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0010.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=_i1"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig1" data-index="1" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 1</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig1"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0002.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0002.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr1" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 1. Structure of layered Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>TMO<sub>2</sub> cathode materials. (a) Structure of P2 cathodes, with the local coordination environment of the P(2b) and P(2d) Na<sup>+</sup> sites indicated, (b) structure adopted by O2 cathodes, and (c) structure adopted by OP4 cathodes. For the P2 and O2 materials, the local prismatic and octahedral Na<sup>+</sup> coordination environments are shown, respectively, as well as the route taken by Na<sup>+</sup> as it hops between adjacent sites. The TS for each Na<sup>+</sup> hopping route is highlighted with a black outline.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0002.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig1"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig2" data-index="2" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 2</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig2"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0003.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0003.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr2" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 2. (a) Rietveld refinement of the PXRD pattern collected for pristine NMMO at room temperature (<i>R</i><sub>wp</sub> = 4.47%), with the inset showing an SEM image of pristine NMMO. Asterisks indicate reflections modeled by the larger (2 × 2 × 1) superstructure (see <a href="/doi/suppl/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/suppl_file/cm1c00248_si_001.pdf" class="ext-link">Figure S2</a>). (b) Structure of NMMO: the left image highlights the stacking of layers in the structure, with the preferential occupation of the TM sublattice shown on the right (the unit cell is denoted with a bold outline).</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0003.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig2"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig3" data-index="3" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 3</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig3"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0004.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0004.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr3" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 3. Electrochemical and <i>ex situ</i> XRD analysis of NMMO. The voltage profile for the first charge–discharge cycle of NMMO is shown in (a), with the changes in phase proportions during the first cycle plotted in (b) (note that the error bars are smaller than the marker size). (c) <i>Ex situ</i> laboratory XRD patterns recorded during the first cycle; the pristine P2 superstructure peaks, where observed, are indicated with asterisks, and expansions of two low-<i>Q</i> regions of the diffraction patterns are shown in (d,e). (d) corresponds to the (002) and (004) reflections for P2, O2, and OP4 phases of NMMO, while (e) shows the region of the <i>Q</i>-space corresponding to the (100) reflection for P2-NMMO. In (f), the differential voltage–capacity curve is shown for the first charge–discharge cycle.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0004.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig3"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig4" data-index="4" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 4</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig4"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0005.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0005.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr4" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 4. <i>Ex situ</i> Mn <i>K</i>-edge EXAFS data for NMMO at different states of charge, showing the four most prominent features in the data up to <i>r</i> = 4.8 Å.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0005.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig4"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig5" data-index="5" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 5</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig5"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0006.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0006.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr5" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 5. <i>Ex situ</i><sup>23</sup>Na Hahn-Echo NMR spectra recorded for NMMO at different states of charge during the first charge–discharge cycle. Asterisks and daggers lie above or to the right-hand side of spinning sideband or diamagnetic impurity peaks, respectively. All spectra are normalized by the sample mass and number of scans; the intensities of the spectra at points C1, C5, and D1 have been increased to make the spectra more visible. The factor of these increases is shown to the right of these spectra; note that this has also increased the noise relative to other states of charge.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0006.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig5"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig6" data-index="6" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 6</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig6"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0007.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0007.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr6" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 6. Variation in the intensity of the isotropic resonances in the <sup>23</sup>Na NMR Hahn-echo spectrum of NMMO samples at the high-voltage charge plateau (the values of <i>x</i> in the legend correspond to the composition Na<sub><i>x</i></sub>[Mg<sub>0.28</sub>Mn<sub>0.72</sub>]O<sub>2</sub>), with the inset showing the variation in the P2 phase fraction along the charge plateau (obtained from Rietveld refinement of the <i>ex situ</i> XRD patterns). The spectra were acquired at the same spinning speed and using the same recycle delay, set to at least 5 times the longitudinal relaxation time (<i>i.e.</i>, <i>d</i><sub>1</sub> &gt; 5<i>T</i><sub>1</sub>), and spectra have been scaled by sample mass and the number of scans to allow a quantitative comparison of the intensities.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0007.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig6"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig7" data-index="7" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 7</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig7"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0008.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0008.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr7" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 7. (a) Schematic Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration mechanism in O2-NMMO, where Mg<sup>2+</sup> moves between an octahedral site in the TMO<sub>2</sub> layer (Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub>) and a tetrahedral site in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layer (Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub>). (b) Expanded view of the TS of this mechanism, with the axially coordinated O<sup>2–</sup> ion (which stabilizes the migrating Mg<sup>2+</sup> in the TS), O<sub>ax</sub>, labeled. (c) Energy profiles for Mg<sup>2+</sup> migration in O2-NMMO cells with one Na<sup>+</sup> per O-type layer into which Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates (“single Na<sup>+</sup>”) and no Na<sup>+</sup> (“desodiated”) in the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> layer into which Mg<sup>2+</sup> migrates. (d,e) Variation of the activation energy barriers for the migration of Mg<sup>2+</sup> in O2-NMMO from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> and from Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>tet.</sub> to Mg<sup>2+</sup><sub>oct.</sub>, respectively, as the O-type Na<sup>+</sup> slab thickness changes. All but one cell size was based on the cell sizes obtained from <i>ex situ</i> XRD Rietveld refinements.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0008.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig7"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure><figure data-id="fig8" data-index="8" class="article__inlineFigure"><h2 class="fig-label">Figure 8</h2><a class="internalNav" aria-label="scroll to figure" href="#fig8"><img src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/medium/cm1c00248_0009.gif" alt="" data-lg-src="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0009.jpeg" id="rightTab-gr8" class="rightTab-fig internalNav"></a><figcaption><div class="hlFld-FigureCaption caption"><p class="first last">Figure 8. Rietveld-derived lattice parameters for (a) the P2 phase, (b) the OP4 phase, and (c) the O2 phase at different states of charge. Note that the OP4 and O2 phase do not appear until point C4 (highlighted) and the OP4 phase disappears after point D3.</p></div></figcaption><div class="figure-bottom-links"><div class="download-hi-res-img"><a title="High Resolution Image" href="/cms/10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248/asset/images/large/cm1c00248_0009.jpeg"><span>High Resolution Image</span></a></div><div class="download-ppt"><a title="Download MS PowerPoint Slide" href="/action/downloadFigures?doi=10.1021/acs.chemmater.1c00248&amp;id=fig8"><span>Download MS PowerPoint Slide</span></a></div></div></figure></li><li id="pane-m2" aria-labelledby="pane-m2" class="tab__pane tab__pane-references"><div class="refs-header-label"><div class="article_content-header"><div class="article_content-header-row"><div class="article_content-title" tabindex="0"><h2 id="rightTab-_i29">References</h2></div></div></div><hr></div><p class="rightTab-references-count">
            This article references
            101 other publications.
        </p><ol id="rightTab-references" class="useLabel"><li id="rightTab-ref1"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref1" class="rightTabRefNumLink">1</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit1" data-doi="10.1002/adfm.201200691"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Slater, M. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Johnson, C. S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Adv. Funct. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>23</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">947</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">958</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/adfm.201200691</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit1R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">1</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Slater, Michael D.; Kim, Donghan; Lee, Eungje; Doeff, Marca; Johnson, Christopher S.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Advanced Functional Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">23</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">947-958</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AFMDC6</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1616-301X</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  The status of ambient temp. sodium ion batteries is reviewed in light of recent developments in anode, electrolyte and cathode materials.  These devices, although early in their stage of development, are promising for large-scale grid storage applications due to the abundance and very low cost of sodium-contg. precursors used to make the components.  The engineering knowledge developed recently for highly successful Li ion batteries can be leveraged to ensure rapid progress in this area, although different electrode materials and electrolytes will be required for dual intercalation systems based on sodium.  In particular, new anode materials need to be identified, since the graphite anode, commonly used in lithium systems, does not intercalate sodium to any appreciable extent.  A wider array of choices is available for cathodes, including high performance layered transition metal oxides and polyanionic compds.  Recent developments in electrodes are encouraging, but a great deal of research is necessary, particularly in new electrolytes, and the understanding of the SEI films.  The engineering modeling calcns. of Na-ion battery energy d. indicate that 210 Wh kg-1 in gravimetric energy is possible for Na-ion batteries compared to existing Li-ion technol. if a cathode capacity of 200 mAh g-1 and a 500 mAh g-1 anode can be discovered with an av. cell potential of 3.3 V.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref2"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref2" class="rightTabRefNumLink">2</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit2" data-doi="10.1039/c2ee02781j"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palomares, V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Serras, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Villaluenga, I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hueso, K. B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carretero-González, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Na-Ion Batteries, Recent Advances and Present Challenges to Become Low Cost Energy Storage Systems</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2012</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>5</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">5884</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c2ee02781j</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit2R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">2</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Na-ion batteries, recent advances and present challenges to become low cost energy storage systems</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Palomares, Veronica; Serras, Paula; Villaluenga, Irune; Hueso, Karina B.; Carretero-Gonzalez, Javier; Rojo, Teofilo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2012</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">5</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5884-5901</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Energy prodn. and storage have become key issues concerning our welfare in daily life.  Present challenges for batteries are twofold.  In the first place, the increasing demand for powering systems of portable electronic devices and zero-emission vehicles stimulates research towards high energy and high voltage systems.  In the second place, low cost batteries are required in order to advance towards smart elec. grids that integrate discontinuous energy flow from renewable sources, optimizing the performance of clean energy sources.  Na-ion batteries can be the key for the second point, because of the huge availability of sodium, its low price and the similarity of both Li and Na insertion chemistries.  In spite of the lower energy d. and voltage of Na-ion based technologies, they can be focused on applications where the wt. and footprint requirement is less drastic, such as elec. grid storage.  Much work has to be done in the field of Na-ion in order to catch up with Li-ion technol.  Cathodic and anodic materials must be optimized, and new electrolytes will be the key point for Na-ion success.  This review will gather the up-to-date knowledge about Na-ion battery materials, with the aim of providing a wide view of the systems that have already been explored and a starting point for the new research on this battery technol.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref3"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref3" class="rightTabRefNumLink">3</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit3" data-doi="10.1039/c3ee41031e"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Palomares, V.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Casas-Cabanas, M.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Castillo-Martínez, E.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Han, M. H.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Update on Na-based battery materials. A growing research path</span>.  <i>Energy and Environmental Science</i>; <span class="NLM_publisher-name">The Royal Society of Chemistry August</span>, <span class="NLM_year">2013</span>; Vol.  <span class="NLM_volume">6</span>, pp  <span class="NLM_fpage">2312</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2337</span>.<span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c3ee41031e</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref4"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref4" class="rightTabRefNumLink">4</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit4" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.201703137"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Delmas, C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Sodium and Sodium-Ion Batteries: 50 Years of Research</span>. <i>Adv.                         "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref7"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref7" class="rightTabRefNumLink">7</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit7" data-doi="10.1149/2.0201514jes"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Review—Manganese-Based P2-Type Transition Metal Oxides as Sodium-Ion Battery Cathode Materials</span>. <i>J. Electrochem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>162</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">A2589</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">A2604</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1149/2.0201514jes</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit7R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">7</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Review-Manganese-Based P2-Type Transition Metal Oxides as Sodium-Ion Battery Cathode Materials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Clement, Raphaele J.; Bruce, Peter G.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the Electrochemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">162</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">14</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">A2589-A2604</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JESOAN</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4651</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review.  Sodium transition metal oxides (NaMO2) with a P2 structure exhibit good Na+ ion cond. and are promising sodium-ion battery cathode materials.  Manganese-based compds. have a high working potential vs. Na+/Na, and high capacity.  Yet, the layered nature of these materials means that they are prone to structural rearrangements at high voltage/low Na contents, the phase transformations and Na+ ion/vacancy ordering transitions resulting in capacity fade and poor reversibility.  This review discusses the latest advances in the field and focuses mainly on recent work on NayMn1-xMxO2 (x, y ≤ 1, M = Ni, Mg, Li) compds.  We compare the different lithium and sodium transition metal layered oxides (P2, O3, etc.) and describe the structures and mechanisms obsd. on alkali (de)intercalation.  The strategies used to enhance the electrochem. properties and stabilize the structural framework of sodium transition metal oxides are reviewed.  We show how X-ray diffraction and 7Li/23Na solid-state NMR can be combined to provide a detailed insight into the structural and electronic processes occurring upon electrochem. cycling of these materials.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref8"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref8" class="rightTabRefNumLink">8</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit8" data-doi="10.1016/0378-4363(80)90214-4"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Delmas, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fouassier, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hagenmuller, P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Structural Classification and Properties of the Layered Oxides</span>. <i>Phys.                 10.1016/0378-4363(80)90214-4</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit8R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">8</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Structural classification and properties of the layered oxides</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Delmas, C.; Fouassier, C.; Hagenmuller, P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physica B+C:  Physics of Condensed Matter + Atomic, Molecular and Plasma Physics, Optics (Amsterdam)</span>

    </div><div class="casAbstract">A review with 17 refs. on the structure types and ionic cond. of layered oxides.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref9"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref9" class="rightTabRefNumLink">9</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit9" data-doi="10.1126/science.1122152"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kang, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meng, Y. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bréger, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Electrodes with High Power and High Capacity for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries</span>. <i>Science</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2006</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>311</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">977</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">980</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1126/science.1122152</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit9R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">9</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Electrodes with High Power and High Capacity for Rechargeable Lithium Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kang, Kisuk; Meng, Ying Shirley; Breger, Julien; Grey, Clare P.; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Science (Washington, DC, United States)</span>

    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">311</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">5763</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">977-980</span>CODEN:

        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0036-8075</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Association for the Advancement of Science</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">New applications such as hybrid elec. vehicles and power backup require rechargeable batteries that combine high energy d. with high charge and discharge rate capability.  Using ab initio computational modeling, strategies to design high-rate battery electrodes were identified.  Tests were performed with [Li(Ni0.5Mn0.5)O2], a safe, inexpensive material that probably has poor intrinsic rate capability.  Modification of its crystal structure provided unexpected high-rate capability, better than that of LiCoO2, the battery electrode material of choice.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref10"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref10" class="rightTabRefNumLink">10</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit10" data-doi="10.1039/b108830k"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Caballero, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hernán, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Morales, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sánchez, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Santos Peña, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Aranda, M. A. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Synthesis and Characterization of High-Temperature Hexagonal P2-Na0.6 MnO2 and Its Electrochemical Behaviour as Cathode in Sodium Cells</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2002</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1142</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1147</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/b108830k</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit10R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">10</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Synthesis and characterization of high-temperature hexagonal P2-Na0.6MnO2 and its electrochemical behaviour as cathode in sodium cells</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Caballero, A.; Hernan, L.; Morales, J.; Sanchez, L.; Santos Pena, J.; Aranda, M. A. G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2002</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1142-1147</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JMACEP</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0959-9428</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A layered sodium manganese oxide, Na0.6MnO2, stable at temps. &gt;800°, was synthesized by using a sol-gel method that employs Mn(acac)3 (ac = acetylacetonate), Na2CO3, and propionic acid to form the resin framework.  This layered bronze possesses a hexagonal, P2-type structure, in which the distortion assocd. with Mn3+ is hardly noticeable.  It reacts slowly, though reversibly, with atm. moisture, which causes the interlayer spacing in the structure to increase by ∼2.5 Å, by intercalation of water mols. into the interlayer gap occupied by Na+ ions.  The anhyd. material was tested as a cathode in sodium cells.  Although the electrochem. intercalation of Na+ occurs in two steps, the host retains its main structural features, with a slight tendency in the interlayer spacing to contract as the sodium content increases.  The similarity between the discharge and charge profiles of the first cycles reveals a quasi-reversible nature of the intercalation process and that the cell can deliver a const. sp. capacity of ∼140 A-h/kg at 0.1 mA/cm2 when cycled in a voltage region of 3.8-2.0 V.  However, the continuous strains and distortions resulting from the insertion and extn. of Na+ ions cause the host structure to gradually collapse and yield an amorphous material after the first eight cycles.  This leads to a progressive redn. of the cell capacity, irresp. of the specific voltage region used.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref11"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref11" class="rightTabRefNumLink">11</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit11" data-doi="10.1007/s100080050138"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Alcántara, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lavela, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tirado, J. L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhecheva, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Stoyanova, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Recent Advances in the Study of Layered Lithium Transition Metal Oxides and Their Application as Intercalation Electrodes</span>. <i>J.                 10.1007/s100080050138</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit11R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">11</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Recent advances in the study of layered lithium transition metal oxides and their application as intercalation electrodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Alcantara, R.; Lavela, P.; Tirado, J.             (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Springer-Verlag</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A review with 131 refs. is presented on the extensive work carried out during the last 30 yr on layered oxides structurally related to LiCoO2 and LiNiO2.  The studies considered here range from the structural and chem. characterization of the layered solids to the detailed evaluation of their aptitude towards lithium deintercalation-intercalation reactions, which form the basis of their successful application in rechargeable battery technol.  The different challenges remaining in this area, such as the development of advanced prepn. procedures and the optimization of the electrochem. performance by controlled changes in compn., structure, and particle morphol., are discussed.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref12"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref12" class="rightTabRefNumLink">12</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit12" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.201602888"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Radin, M.                         "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref13"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref13" class="rightTabRefNumLink">13</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit13" data-doi="10.1038/s42004-020-0257-6"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hakim, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sabi, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ma, L. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Saadoune, I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Younesi, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Understanding the Redox Process upon Electrochemical Cycling of the P2-Na0.78Co1/2Mn1/3Ni1/6O2 Electrode Material for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Commun. Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>3</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">9</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s42004-020-0257-6</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit13R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">13</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Understanding the redox process upon electrochemical cycling of the P2-Na0.78Co1/2Mn1/3Ni1/6O2 electrode material for sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Hakim, Charifa; Sabi, Noha; Ma, Le Anh; Dahbi, Mouad; Brandell, Daniel; Edstrom, Kristina; Duda, Laurent C.; Saadoune, Ismael; Younesi, Reza</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Communications Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">3</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">9</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CCOHCT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2399-3669</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Rechargeable sodium-ion batteries have recently attracted renewed interest as an alternative to Li-ion batteries for elec. energy storage applications, because of the low cost and wide availability of sodium resources.  Thus, the electrochem. energy storage community has been devoting increased attention to designing new cathode materials for sodium-ion batteries.  Here we investigate P2- Na0.78Co1/2Mn1/3Ni1/6O2 as a cathode material for sodium ion batteries.  The main focus is to understand the mechanism of the electrochem. performance of this material, esp. differences obsd. in redox reactions at high potentials.  Between 4.2 V and 4.5 V, the material delivers a reversible capacity which is studied in detail using advanced anal. techniques.  In situ X-ray diffraction reveals the reversibility of the P2-type structure of the material.  Combined soft X-ray absorption spectroscopy and resonant inelastic X-ray scattering demonstrates that Na deintercalation at high voltages is charge compensated by formation of localized electron holes on oxygen atoms.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref14"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref14" class="rightTabRefNumLink">14</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit14" data-doi="10.1016/j.electacta.2020.135978"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Stansby, J. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dose, W. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sharma, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kimpton, J. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">López
del Amo, J. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gonzalo, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Structural Evolution and Electrochemistry of the Mn-Rich P2– Na2/3Mn0.9Ti0.05Fe0.05O2 Positive Electrode Material</span>. <i>Electrochim. Acta</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>341</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">135978</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.electacta.2020.135978</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit14R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">14</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Structural evolution and electrochemistry of the Mn-Rich P2- Na2/3Mn0.9Ti0.05Fe0.05O2 positive electrode material</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Stansby, Jennifer H.; Dose, Wesley M.; Sharma, Neeraj; Kimpton, Justin A.; Lopez del Amo, Juan Miguel; Gonzalo, Elena; Rojo, Teofilo</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Electrochimica Acta</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2020</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">341</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">135978</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ELCAAV</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0013-4686</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Pos. electrodes still limit the max. attainable energy d. of Na-ion batteries.  Increasing the amt. of electrochem. active transition metal is one way of improving energy d.  However, this is complicated by the balance between initial capacity and structural stability/capacity retention.  Here, the Mn-rich P2- Na2/3Mn0.9Fe0.05Ti0.05O2 was synthesized via the solid-state method and its structural evolution during operation, between 1.9 and 4.2 V, studied.  Through operando x-ray powder diffraction data, no evidence is found for the formation of Z, OP4 or O2 phases and the material primarily displays regions of two-phase coexistence.  P2- Na2/3Mn0.9Fe0.05Ti0.05O2 delivers a 2nd charge/discharge capacity of 152/164 mAh g-1 at C/10, within the voltage range 4.0-2.0 V and retains 75% of the discharge capacity at the 50th cycle.  A detailed comparison, in terms of both the electrochem. performance and structural evolution, to related Mn-rich phases is provided.  Further structural stability and battery performance can be improved through subtle co-substitutions.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref15"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref15" class="rightTabRefNumLink">15</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit15" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.201000061"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kang, S.-H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Slater, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rood, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Vaughey, J.         </div><div class="casAbstract">A series of layered NaxLiγNi0.25Mn0.75Oδ oxides within the range 0.7 ≤ x ≤ 1.2; 0 ≤ γ ≤ 0.5 was synthesized and evaluated as cathodes in rechargeable sodium batteries.             (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Electrochemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Layered sodium-ion cathode material P2-Na0.85Li0.17Ni0.21Mn0.64O2 was investigated using operando XAS to characterize structural changes occurring in the material during electrochem. sodiation/desodiation.  Based on XANES data, the primary mode of charge compensation in this material is due to Ni2-3/4+ redox activity, while the Mn remains in the +4 oxidn. state, thereby providing stability to this material during extended cycling.  Investigation of the initial state of the compd. by high resoln. synchrotron x-ray diffraction and 6Li MAS NMR revealed a significant amt. of structural disorder due to integration of a small amt. of monoclinic layered Li phase within the overall hexagonal layered Na-structure, which manifests as Li-induced stacking faults.  High quality EXAFS data could be obtained using our cell construction and revealed the local structural evolution around the redox active Ni centers.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref17"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref17" class="rightTabRefNumLink">17</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit17" data-doi="10.1021/am5080437"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hasa, I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Buchholz, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Passerini, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hassoun, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A Comparative Study of Layered Transition Metal Oxide Cathodes for Application in Sodium-Ion Battery</span>. <i>ACS Appl.                         rightTab-cas_cit17R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">17</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Comparative study of layered transition metal oxide cathodes for application in sodium-ion battery</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Hasa, Ivana; Buchholz, Daniel; Passerini, Stefano; Hassoun, Jusef</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">ACS Applied Materials &amp; Interfaces</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Herein, we report a study on P-type layered sodium transition metal-based oxides with a general formula of NaxMO2 (M = Ni, Fe, Mn).  We synthesize the materials via copptn. followed by annealing in air and rinsing with water, and we examine the electrodes as cathodes for sodium-ion batteries using a propylene carbonate-based electrolyte.  We fully investigate the effect of the Ni-to-Fe ratio, annealing temp., and sodium content on the electrochem. performances of the electrodes.  The impact of these parameters on the structural and electrochem. properties of the materials is revealed by X-ray diffraction, SEM, and cyclic voltammetry, resp.  The suitability of this class of P-type materials for sodium battery application is finally demonstrated by cycling tests revealing an excellent electrochem. performance in terms of delivered capacity (i.e., about 200 mAh g-1) and charge-discharge efficiency (approaching 100%).</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref18"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref18" class="rightTabRefNumLink">18</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit18" data-doi="10.1002/anie.201911698"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zuo, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zheng, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xiang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhou, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xiao, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shan, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shi, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhong, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Fu, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, Y.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">P2-Na <sub>0.67</sub> Al <sub>x</sub> <sub>M</sub>n 1– <sub>x&nbsp;O</sub> <sub>2</sub> : <sub>C</sub>ost-Effective, Stable and High-Rate Sodium Electrodes by Suppressing Phase Transitions and Enhancing Sodium Cation Mobility</span>. <i>Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>58</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">18086</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">18095</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:

                        rightTab-cas_cit18R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">18</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">P2-Na0.67AlxMn1-xO2: Cost-Effective, Stable and High-Rate Sodium Electrodes by Suppressing Phase Transitions and Enhancing Sodium Cation Mobility</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Liu, Xiangsi; Zuo, Wenhua; Zheng, Bizhu; Xiang, Yuxuan; Zhou, Ke; Xiao, Zhumei; Shan, Peizhao; Shi, Jingwen; Li, Qi; Zhong, Guiming; Fu, Riqiang; Yang, Yong</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Angewandte Chemie, International Edition</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">58</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">50</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">18086-18095</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACIEF5</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1433-7851</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH &amp; Co. KGaA</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Na layered P2-stacking Na0.67MnO2 materials showed great promise for Na-ion batteries.  However, the undesired Jahn-Teller effect of the Mn4+/Mn3+ redox couple and multiple biphasic structural transitions during charge/discharge of the materials lead to anisotropic structure expansion and rapid capacity decay.  Herein, by introducing abundant Al into the transition-metal layers to decrease the no. of Mn3+, the authors obtain the low cost pure P2-type Na0.67AlxMn1-xO2 (x = 0.05, 0.1 and 0.2) materials with high structural stability and promising performance.  The Al-doping effect on the long/short range structural evolutions and electrochem. performances is further studied by combining in situ synchrotron XRD and solid-state NMR techniques.  The authors' results reveal that Al-doping alleviates the phase transformations thus giving rise to better cycling life, and leads to a larger spacing of Na+ layer thus producing a remarkable rate capability of 96 mAh g-1 at 1200 mA g-1.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref19"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref19" class="rightTabRefNumLink">19</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit19" data-doi="10.1021/cm403855t"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Xu, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, D. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Leskes, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pell, A. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meng, Y. S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Identifying the Critical Role of Li Substitution in P2–Nax [Liy Niz Mn1-y-z]O 2 (0 &lt; x , y , z &lt; 1) Intercalation Cathode Materials for High-Energy Na-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>26</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1260</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1269</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/cm403855t</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit19R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">19</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Identifying the Critical Role of Li Substitution in P2-Nax[LiyNizMn1-y-z]O2 (0 &lt; x, y, z &lt; 1) Intercalation Cathode Materials for High-Energy Na-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Xu, Jing; Lee, Dae Hoe; Clement, Raphaele J.; Yu, Xiqian; Leskes, Michal; Pell, Andrew J.; Pintacuda, Guido; Yang, Xiao-Qing; Grey, Clare P.; Meng, Ying Shirley</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">26</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1260-1269</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Li-substituted layered P2-Na0.80[Li0.12Ni0.22Mn0.66]O2 is studied as an advanced cathode material for Na-ion batteries.  Both n diffraction and NMR spectroscopy are used to elucidate the local structure, and they reveal that most of the Li ions are located in transition metal (TM) sites, preferably surrounded by Mn ions.  To characterize structural changes occurring upon electrochem. cycling, in situ synchrotron x-ray diffraction is conducted.  No significant phase transformation is obsd. up to 4.4 V charge for this material, unlike Li-free P2-type Na cathodes.  The presence of monovalent Li ions in the TM layers allows more Na ions to reside in the prismatic sites, stabilizing the overall charge balance of the compd.  Consequently, more Na ions remain in the compd. upon charge, the P2 structure is retained in the high voltage region, and the phase transformation is delayed.  Ex situ NMR is conducted on samples at different states of charge/discharge to track Li-ion site occupation changes.  Surprisingly, Li is mobile, some Li ions migrate from the TM layer to the Na layer at high voltage, and yet this process is highly reversible.  Novel design principles for Na cathode materials are proposed from an atomistic level understanding of the underlying electrochem. processes.  These principles enable one to devise an optimized, high capacity, and structurally stable compd. as a potential cathode material for high-energy Na-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref20"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref20" class="rightTabRefNumLink">20</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit20" data-doi="10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.02.069"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Buchholz, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Vaalma, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chagas, L. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Passerini, S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Mg-Doping for Improved Long-Term Cyclability of Layered Na-Ion Cathode Materials - The Example of P2-Type NaxMg0.11Mn0.89O2</span>. <i>J. Power Sources</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>282</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">581</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">585</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/j.jpowsour.2015.02.069</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit20R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">20</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Mg-doping for improved long-term cyclability of layered Na-ion cathode materials - The example of P2-type NaxMg0.11Mn0.89O2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Buchholz, Daniel; Vaalma, Christoph; Chagas, Luciana Gomes; Passerini, Stefano</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Power Sources</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">282</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue"></span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">581-585</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPSODZ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0378-7753</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier B.V.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) are establishing themselves as a low-cost alternative to the widespread lithium-ion technol., a trend that is exemplified by the use of aluminum as anode current collector.  In order to be in line with this philosophy, environmentally friendly, abundant and cheap materials need to be used in order to provide a complementary rather than competing battery technol. other than lithium-ion.  With the same scope in mind, herein we present the structural and electrochem. characterization of P2-type NaxMg0.11Mn0.89O2 material to demonstrate the effectiveness of Mg-doping for the development of future layered cathode materials.  Of particular interest is the effect on the long-term cyclability (200 cycles), which has not been reported, yet.  As shown in the manuscript, a Mg content as low as 11% in the MO2 layer leads to a smoothing of the potential profile, very high coulombic efficiencies exceeding 99.5% at 12 mA g-1 and a stable long-term cycling behavior.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref21"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref21" class="rightTabRefNumLink">21</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit21" data-doi="10.1002/nano.202000030"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liu, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Deng, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gao, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yin, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zou, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hou, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ji, X.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Manganese-based Layered Oxide Cathodes for Sodium Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Nano Sel.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2020</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>1</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">200</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">225</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1002/nano.202000030</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref22"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref22" class="rightTabRefNumLink">22</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit22" data-doi="10.1002/aenm.201802379"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bai, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sathiya, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mendoza-Sánchez, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Iadecola, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Vergnet, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dedryvère, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Saubanère, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Abakumov, A.                         "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref23"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref23" class="rightTabRefNumLink">23</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit23" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00227"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">House, R. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Maitra, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jin, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lozano, J. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Somerville, J. W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rees, N. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Naylor, A. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Duda, L. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Massel, F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chadwick, A. E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Schmitt, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Roberts, M. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">What Triggers Oxygen Loss in Oxygen Redox Cathode Materials?</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>31</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">3293</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3300</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00227</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit23R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">23</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">What Triggers Oxygen Loss in Oxygen Redox Cathode Materials?</span></div><div class="casAuthors">House, Robert A.; Maitra, Urmimala; Jin, Liyu; Lozano, Juan G.; Somerville, James W.; Rees, Nicholas H.; Naylor, Andrew J.; Duda, Laurent C.; Massel, Felix; Chadwick, Alan V.; Ramos, Silvia; Pickup, David M.; McNally, Daniel E.; Lu, Xingye; Schmitt, Thorsten; Roberts, Matthew R.; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">31</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3293-3300</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">It is possible to increase the charge capacity of transition-metal (TM) oxide cathodes in alkali-ion batteries by invoking redox reactions on the oxygen.  However, oxygen loss often occurs.  To explore what affects oxygen loss in oxygen redox materials, we have two analogous Na-ion cathodes, P2-Na0.67Mg0.28Mn0.72O2 and P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2 are compared.  On charging to 4.5 V, &gt; 0.4e- are removed from the oxide ions of these materials, but neither compd. exhibits oxygen loss.  Li is retained in P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2 but displaced from the TM to the alkali metal layers, showing that vacancies in the TM layers, which also occur in other oxygen redox compds. that exhibit oxygen loss such as Li[Li0.2Ni0.2Mn0.6]O2, are not a trigger for oxygen loss.  On charging at 5 V, P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2 exhibits oxygen loss, whereas P2-Na0.67Mg0.28Mn0.72O2 does not.  Under these conditions, both Na+ and Li+ are removed from P2-Na0.78Li0.25Mn0.75O2, resulting in underbonded oxygen (fewer than 3 cations coordinating oxygen) and surface-localized O loss.  In contrast, for P2-Na0.67Mg0.28Mn0.72O2, oxygen remains coordinated by at least 2 Mn4+ and 1 Mg2+ ions, stabilizing the oxygen and avoiding oxygen loss.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref24"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref24" class="rightTabRefNumLink">24</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit24" data-doi="10.1039/c6ee01750a"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Robert Armstrong, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Singh, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Structurally Stable Mg-Doped P2-Na 2/3 Mn 1–y Mg y O 2 Sodium-Ion Battery Cathodes with High Rate Performance: Insights from Electrochemical, NMR and Diffraction Studies</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>9</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">3240</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3251</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c6ee01750a</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit24R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">24</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Structurally stable Mg-doped P2-Na2/3Mn1-yMgyO2 sodium-ion battery cathodes with high rate performance: insights from electrochemical, NMR and diffraction studies</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Clement, Raphaele J.; Billaud, Juliette; Robert Armstrong, A.; Singh, Gurpreet; Rojo, Teofilo; Bruce, Peter G.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">9</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">10</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3240-3251</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Sodium-ion batteries are a more sustainable alternative to the existing lithium-ion technol. and could alleviate some of the stress on the global lithium market as a result of the growing elec. car and portable electronics industries.  Fundamental research focused on understanding the structural and electronic processes occurring on electrochem. cycling is key to devising rechargeable batteries with improved performance.  We present an in-depth investigation of the effect of Mg doping on the electrochem. performance and structural stability of Na2/3MnO2 with a P2 layer stacking by comparing three compns.: Na2/3Mn1-yMgyO2 (y = 0.0, 0.05, 0.1).  We show that Mg substitution leads to smoother electrochem., with fewer distinct electrochem. processes, improved rate performance and better capacity retention.  These observations are attributed to the more gradual structural changes upon charge and discharge, as obsd. with synchrotron, powder X-ray, and neutron diffraction.  Mg doping reduces the no. of Mn3+ Jahn-Teller centers and delays the high voltage phase transition occurring in P2-Na2/3MnO2.  The local structure is investigated using 23Na solid-state NMR (ssNMR) spectroscopy.  The ssNMR data provide direct evidence for fewer oxygen layer shearing events, leading to a stabilized P2 phase, and an enhanced Na-ion mobility up to 3.8 V vs.  Na+/Na upon Mg doping.  The 5% Mg-doped phase exhibits one of the best rate performances reported to date for sodium-ion cathodes with a P2 structure, with a reversible capacity of 106 mA h g-1 at the very high discharge rate of 5000 mA g-1.  In addn., its structure is highly reversible and stable cycling is obtained between 1.5 and 4.0 V vs.  Na+/Na, with a capacity of approx. 140 mA h g-1 retained after 50 cycles at a rate of 1000 mA g-1.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref25"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref25" class="rightTabRefNumLink">25</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit25" data-doi="10.1039/c4ee00465e"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Singh, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armstrong, A. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gonzalo, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Roddatis, V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armand, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rojo, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Na 0.67 Mn 1–x Mg x O 2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2): A High Capacity Cathode for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>7</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1387</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1391</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c4ee00465e</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit25R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">25</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Na0.67Mn1-xMgxO2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2): a high capacity cathode for sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Billaud, Juliette; Singh, Gurpreet; Armstrong, A. Robert; Gonzalo, Elena; Roddatis, Vladimir; Armand, Michel; Rojo, Teofilo; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">7</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1387-1391</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Earth-abundant Na0.67[Mn1-xMgx]O2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2) cathode materials with the P2 structure have been synthesized as pos. electrodes for sodium-ion batteries.  Na0.67MnO2 exhibits a capacity of 175 mA h g-1 with good capacity retention.  A Mg content of 5% is sufficient to smooth the charge/discharge profiles without affecting the capacity, while further increasing the Mg content improves the cycling stability, but at the expense of a lower discharge capacity (∼150 mA h g-1 for Na0.67Mn0.8Mg0.2O2).  It was obsd. that the cooling process during synthesis, as well as Mg content, have an influence on the structure.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref26"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref26" class="rightTabRefNumLink">26</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit26" data-doi="10.1021/ja509704t"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Armstrong, A. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Canales-Vázquez, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rozier, P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A High-Performance Cathode for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>136</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">17243</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">17248</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja509704t</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit26R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">26</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">β-NaMnO2: A High-Performance Cathode for Sodium-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Billaud, Juliette; Clement, Raphaele J.; Armstrong, A. Robert; Canales-Vazquez, Jesus; Rozier, Patrick; Grey, Clare P.; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">136</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">49</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">17243-17248</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">There is much interest in Na-ion batteries for grid storage because of the lower projected cost compared with Li-ion.  Identifying Earth-abundant, low-cost, and safe materials that can function as intercalation cathodes in Na-ion batteries is an important challenge facing the field.  Here such a material, β-NaMnO2, is investigated with a different structure from that of NaMnO2 polymorphs and other compds. studied extensively in the past.  It exhibits a high capacity (of ca. 190 mA h g-1 at a rate of C/20), along with a good rate capability (142 mA h g-1 at a rate of 2C) and a good capacity retention (100 mA h g-1after 100 Na extn./insertion cycles at a rate of 2C).  Powder XRD, HRTEM, and 23Na NMR studies revealed that this compd. exhibits a complex structure consisting of intergrown regions of α-NaMnO2 and β-NaMnO2 domains.  The collapse of the long-range structure at low Na content is expected to compromise the reversibility of the Na extn. and insertion processes occurring upon charge and discharge of the cathode material, resp.  Yet stable, reproducible, and reversible Na intercalation is obsd.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref27"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref27" class="rightTabRefNumLink">27</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit27" data-doi="10.1039/c4ta04351k"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yabuuchi, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hara, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kubota, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Paulsen, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kumakura, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Komaba, S.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A New Electrode Material for Rechargeable Sodium Batteries: P2-Type Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 with Anomalously High Reversible Capacity</span>. <i>J. Mater. Chem. A</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>2</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">16851</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">16855</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c4ta04351k</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit27R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">27</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">A new electrode material for rechargeable sodium batteries: P2-type Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 with anomalously high reversible capacity</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Yabuuchi, Naoaki; Hara, Ryo; Kubota, Kei; Paulsen, Jens; Kumakura, Shinichi; Komaba, Shinichi</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Materials Chemistry A: Materials for Energy and Sustainability</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">P2-type Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 is prepd. and electrode performance in Na cells is first provided.  The sample surprisingly delivers a large reversible capacity (220 mA h g-1) even though electrochem. inactive magnesium ions are enriched in the host structure.  This new electrode material is potentially utilized for rechargeable batteries made from only earth-abundant elements.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref28"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref28" class="rightTabRefNumLink">28</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit28" data-doi="10.1038/nchem.2923"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Maitra, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">House, R.
