C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Roberts, M. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Oxygen Redox Chemistry without Excess Alkali-Metal Ions in Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2</span>. <i>Nat. Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>10</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">288</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">295</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/nchem.2923</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit28R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">28</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Oxygen redox chemistry without excess alkali-metal ions in Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Maitra, Urmimala; House, Robert A.; Somerville, James W.; Tapia-Ruiz, Nuria; Lozano, Juan G.; Guerrini, Niccolo; Hao, Rong; Luo, Kun; Jin, Liyu; Perez-Osorio, Miguel A.; Massel, Felix; Pickup, David M.; Ramos, Silvia; Lu, Xingye; McNally, Daniel E.; Chadwick, Alan V.; Giustino, Feliciano; Schmitt, Thorsten; Duda, Laurent C.; Roberts, Matthew R.; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">10</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">288-295</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NCAHBB</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1755-4330</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The search for improved energy-storage materials has revealed Li- and Na-rich intercalation compds. as promising high-capacity cathodes.  They exhibit capacities in excess of what would be expected from alkali-ion removal/reinsertion and charge compensation by transition-metal (TM) ions.  The addnl. capacity is provided through charge compensation by oxygen redox chem. and some oxygen loss.  It has been reported previously that oxygen redox occurs in O 2p orbitals that interact with alkali ions in the TM and alkali-ion layers (i.e., oxygen redox occurs in compds. contg. Li+-O(2p)-Li+ interactions).  Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 exhibits an excess capacity and here we show that this is caused by oxygen redox, even though Mg2+ resides in the TM layers rather than alkali-metal (AM) ions, which demonstrates that excess AM ions are not required to activate oxygen redox.  We also show that, unlike the alkali-rich compds., Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2 does not lose oxygen.  The extn. of alkali ions from the alkali and TM layers in the alkali-rich compds. results in severely underbonded oxygen, which promotes oxygen loss, whereas Mg2+ remains in Na2/3[Mg0.28Mn0.72]O2, which stabilizes oxygen.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref29"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref29" class="rightTabRefNumLink">29</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit29" data-doi="10.1021/ic5017802"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Mortemard
De Boisse, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Carlier, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Guignard, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bourgeois, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Delmas, C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">P2-NaxMn1/2Fe1/2O2 Phase Used as Positive Electrode in Na Batteries: Structural Changes Induced by the Electrochemical (De)Intercalation Process</span>. <i>Inorg. Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2014</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>53</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">11197</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">11205</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ic5017802</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit29R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">29</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">P2-NaxMn1/2Fe1/2O2 Phase Used as Positive Electrode in Na Batteries: Structural Changes Induced by the Electrochemical (De)intercalation Process</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Mortemard de Boisse, Benoit; Carlier, Dany; Guignard, Marie; Bourgeois, Lydie; Delmas, Claude</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Inorganic Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2014</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">53</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">20</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">11197-11205</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">INOCAJ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0020-1669</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The electrochem. properties of the P2-type NaxMn1/2Fe1/2O2 (x = 0.62) phase used as a pos. electrode in Na batteries were tested in various voltage ranges at C/20.  Even if the highest capacity was obtained for the 1st cycles between 1.5 and 4.3 V, the best capacity after 50 cycles was obtained while cycling between 1.5 and 4.0 V (120 mAh g-1).  The structural changes occurring in the material during the (de)intercalation were studied by operando in situ x-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) and ex situ synchrotron XRPD.  A phase with an orthorhombic P'2-type structure is formed for x ≈ 1, due to the cooperative Jahn-Teller effect of the Mn3+ ions.  P2 structure type stacking is obsd. for 0.35 &lt; x &lt; 0.82, while &gt;4.0 V, a new phase appears.  A full indexation of the XRPD pattern of this latter phase was not possible because of the broadening of the diffraction peaks.  However, a much shorter interslab distance was found that may imply a gliding of the MO2 slab occurring at high voltage.  Raman spectroscopy was used as a local probe and showed that in this new phase the MO2 layers are maintained, but the phase exhibits a strong degree of disorder.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref30"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref30" class="rightTabRefNumLink">30</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit30" data-doi="10.1039/c8ee02991a"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Somerville, J. W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sobkowiak, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tapia-Ruiz, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Billaud, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lozano, J. G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">House, R. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gallington, L. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ericsson, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Häggström, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Roberts, M. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Maitra, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Nature of the “Z”-Phase in Layered Na-Ion Battery Cathodes</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">2223</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2232</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c8ee02991a</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit30R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">30</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Nature of the "Z"-phase in layered Na-ion battery cathodes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Somerville, James W.; Sobkowiak, Adam; Tapia-Ruiz, Nuria; Billaud, Juliette; Lozano, Juan G.; House, Robert A.; Gallington, Leighanne C.; Ericsson, Tore; Haggstrom, Lennart; Roberts, Matthew R.; Maitra, Urmimala; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2223-2232</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Layered sodium transition metal oxides with the P2 structure, e.g.  Na2/3[Ni1/3Mn2/3]O2, are regarded as candidates for Na-ion battery cathodes.  On charging, extn. of Na destabilizes the P2 phase (ABBA oxide ion stacking) in which Na+ is in trigonal prismatic coordination, resulting in layer gliding and formation of an O2 phase (ABAC stacking) with octahedral coordination.  However, many related compds. do not exhibit such a simple P2 to O2 transition but rather form a so called "Z"-phase.  Substituting Ni by Fe in Na2/3[Ni1/3Mn2/3]O2 is attractive as it reduces cost.  The Fe contg. compds., such as Na2/3[Ni1/6Mn1/2Fe1/3]O2, form a "Z"-phase when charged above 4.1 V vs.  Na+/Na.  By combining ex situ and operando X-ray diffraction with scanning transmission electron microscopy and simulated diffraction patterns, we demonstrate that the "Z"-phase is most accurately described as a continuously changing intergrowth structure which evolves from P2 to O2 through the OP4 structure as an intermediate.  On charging, Na+ removal results in O-type stacking faults within the P2 structure which increase in proportion.  At 50% O-type stacking faults, the ordered OP4 phase forms and on further charging more O-type stacking faults are formed progressing towards a pure O2 structure.  This gives the superficial appearance of a solid soln.  Furthermore, in contrast to some previous studies, we did not detect Fe migration at any state-of-charge using 57Fe-Mossbauer spectroscopy.  It was, however, found that the Fe-substitution serves to disrupt cation ordering in the material.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref31"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref31" class="rightTabRefNumLink">31</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit31" data-doi="10.1107/s0365110x67000234"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rietveld, H. M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Line Profiles of Neutron Powder-Diffraction Peaks for Structure Refinement</span>. <i>Acta Crystallogr.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1967</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>22</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">151</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">152</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0365110x67000234</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit31R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">31</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Line profiles of neutron powder-diffraction peaks for structure refinement</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Rietveld, H. M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Acta Crystallographica</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1967</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">22</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">151-2</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACCRA9</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0365-110X</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">A structure refinement procedure is described, which obtains a least-sqs. fit between the calcd. and observed intensities measured at equal angular intervals on a neutron powder-diffractometer.  The structure parameters are significantly more reliable than those detd. by a method with the use of the integrated intensities of overlapping peaks.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref32"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref32" class="rightTabRefNumLink">32</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit32" data-doi="10.1107/s0021889869006558"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rietveld, H. M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A Profile Refinement Method for Nuclear and Magnetic Structures</span>. <i>J. Appl. Crystallogr.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1969</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>2</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">65</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">71</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0021889869006558</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit32R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">32</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Profile refinement method for nuclear and magnetic structures</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Rietveld, H. M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Applied Crystallography</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1969</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">2</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">Pt. 2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">65-71</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACGAR</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0021-8898</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">A structural refinement method for neutron diffraction is presented which makes direct use of the profile intensities obtained from the powder diagram.  It is applicable to nuclear structures and to magnetic structures which can be described on the nuclear unit cell or a multiple thereof.  Equations for the measured profiles to be used in the least sqs. treatment are cor. for asymmetry and preferred orientation; the angular dependence of the half widths of the peaks is given by the formula of Caglioti, et al. (1958).  The magnetic contribution to the profile equation is expressed by calcg. only one av. cross section for each set of equiv. reflections.  It is possible to introduce constraint functions, linear or quadratic, between parameters used in the least sqs. treatment.  Results of the use of this method are given for a series of compds.  In all instances it has proved superior to any other method involving integrated neutron powder intensities, single or overlapping.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref33"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref33" class="rightTabRefNumLink">33</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit33"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Coelho, A.</span></span> <i>TOPAS-Academic: General Profile and Structure Analysis Software for Powder Diffraction Data</i>: <span class="NLM_publisher-loc">Brisbane, Australia</span>, <span class="NLM_year">2007</span>.</span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref34"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref34" class="rightTabRefNumLink">34</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit34" data-doi="10.1107/s1600576718000183"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Coelho, A. A.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">TOPAS and TOPAS-Academic : An Optimization Program Integrating Computer Algebra and Crystallographic Objects Written in C++</span>. <i>J. Appl. Crystallogr.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>51</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">210</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">218</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s1600576718000183</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit34R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">34</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">TOPAS and TOPAS-Academic: an optimization program integrating computer algebra and crystallographic objects written in C++</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Coelho, Alan A.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Applied Crystallography</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">51</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">210-218</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACGAR</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1600-5767</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">International Union of Crystallography</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">TOPAS and its academic variant TOPAS-Academic are nonlinear least-squares optimization programs written in the C++ programming language.  This paper describes their functionality and architecture.  The latter is of benefit to developers seeking to reduce development time.  TOPAS allows linear and nonlinear constraints through the use of computer algebra, with parameter dependencies, required for parameter derivs., automatically detd.  In addn., the objective function can include restraints and penalties, which again are defined using computer algebra.  Of importance is a conjugate gradient soln. routine with bounding constraints which guide refinements to convergence.  Much of the functionality of TOPAS is achieved through the use of generic functionality; for example, flexible peak-shape generation allows neutron time-of-flight (TOF) peak shapes to be described using generic functions.  The kernel of TOPAS can be run from the command line for batch mode operation or from a closely integrated graphical user interface.  The functionality of TOPAS includes peak fitting, Pawley and Le Bail refinement, Rietveld refinement, single-crystal refinement, pair distribution function refinement, magnetic structures, const. wavelength neutron refinement, TOF refinement, stacking-fault anal., Laue refinement, indexing, charge flipping, and structure soln. through simulated annealing.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref35"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref35" class="rightTabRefNumLink">35</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit35" data-doi="10.1107/s0909049505012719"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ravel, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Newville, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">ATHENA, ARTEMIS, HEPHAESTUS: Data Analysis for X-Ray Absorption Spectroscopy Using IFEFFIT</span>. <i>J. Synchrotron Radiat.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2005</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>12</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">537</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">541</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0909049505012719</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit35R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">35</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">ATHENA, ARTEMIS, HEPHAESTUS: data analysis for x-ray absorption spectroscopy using IFEFFIT</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Ravel, B.; Newville, M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Synchrotron Radiation</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2005</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">12</span>

        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0909-0495</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Blackwell Publishing Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A software package for the anal. of x-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) data is presented.  This package is based on the IFEFFIT library of numerical and XAS algorithms and is written in the Perl programming language using the Perl/Tk graphics toolkit.  The programs described here are: (i) ATHENA, a program for XAS data processing, (ii) ARTEMIS, a program for EXAFS data anal. using theor. stds. from FEFF and (iii) HEPHAESTUS, a collection of beamline utilities based on tables of at. absorption data.  These programs enable high-quality data anal. that is accessible to novices while still powerful enough to meet the demands of an expert practitioner.  The programs run on all major computer platforms and are freely available under the terms of a free software license.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref36"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref36" class="rightTabRefNumLink">36</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit36" data-doi="10.1107/s0909049500016964"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Newville, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">IFEFFIT: Interactive XAFS Analysis and FEFF Fitting</span>. <i>J. Synchrotron Radiat.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2001</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>8</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">322</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">324</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0909049500016964</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit36R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">36</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">IFEFFIT: interactive XAFS analysis and FEFF fitting</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Newville, Matthew</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Synchrotron Radiation</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2001</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">8</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">322-324</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JSYRES</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0909-0495</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Munksgaard International Publishers Ltd.</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">IFEFFIT, an interactive program and scriptable library of XAFS algorithms is presented.  The core algorithms of AUTOBK and FEFFIT were combined with general data manipulation and interactive graphics into a single package.  IFEFFIT comes with a command-line program that can be run either interactively or in batch-mode.  It also provides a library of functions that can be used easily from C or Fortran, as well as high level scripting languages such as Tcl, Perl and Python.  Using this library, a Graphical User Interface for rapid 'online' data anal. is demonstrated.  IFEFFIT is freely available with an Open Source license.  Outside use, development, and contributions are encouraged.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref37"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref37" class="rightTabRefNumLink">37</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit37"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wasylishen, R.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">Ashbrook, S.</span>; <span class="NLM_string-name">WimperisVega, S.                         "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref38"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref38" class="rightTabRefNumLink">38</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit38" data-doi="10.1021/ja209600m"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hung, I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhou, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pourpoint, F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C.             (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The use of a magic-angle turning and phase-adjusted spinning sideband NMR expt. to resolve and quantify the individual local environments in the high field 7Li and 31P NMR spectra of paramagnetic Li-ion battery materials is demonstrated.  The use of short radio frequency pulses provides an excitation bandwidth that is sufficient to cover shift anisotropy of &gt;1 MHz in breadth, allowing isotropic and anisotropic components to be resolved.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref39"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref39" class="rightTabRefNumLink">39</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit39" data-doi="10.1021/ja306876u"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pell, A. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Middlemiss, D. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Strobridge, F. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Miller, J. K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Whittingham, M. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Emsley, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pintacuda, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Spin-Transfer Pathways in Paramagnetic Lithium Transition-Metal Phosphates from Combined Broadband Isotropic Solid-State MAS NMR Spectroscopy and DFT Calculations</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2012</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>134</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">17178</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">17185</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja306876u</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit39R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">39</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Spin-Transfer Pathways in Paramagnetic Lithium Transition-Metal Phosphates from Combined Broadband Isotropic Solid-State MAS NMR Spectroscopy and DFT Calculations</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Clement, Raphaele J.; Pell, Andrew J.; Middlemiss, Derek S.; Strobridge, Fiona C.; Miller, Joel K.; Whittingham, M. Stanley; Emsley, Lyndon; Grey, Clare P.; Pintacuda, Guido</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2012</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">134</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">41</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">17178-17185</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Substituted lithium transition-metal (TM) phosphate LiFexMn1-xPO4 materials with olivine-type structures are among the most promising next generation lithium ion battery cathodes.  However, a complete at.-level description of the structure of such phases is not yet available.  Here, a combined exptl. and theor. approach to the detailed assignment of the 31P NMR spectra of the LiFexMn1-xPO4 (x = 0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1) pure and mixed TM phosphates is developed and applied.  Key to the present work is the development of a new NMR expt. enabling the characterization of complex paramagnetic materials via the complete sepn. of the individual isotropic chem. shifts, along with solid-state hybrid DFT calcns. providing the sep. hyperfine contributions of all distinct Mn-O-P and Fe-O-P bond pathways.  The NMR expt., referred to as aMAT, makes use of short high-powered adiabatic pulses (SHAPs), which can achieve 100% inversion over a range of isotropic shifts ∼1 MHz and with anisotropies &gt;100 kHz.  In addn. to complete spectral assignments of the mixed phases, the present study provides a detailed insight into the differences in electronic structure driving the variations in hyperfine parameters across the range of materials.  A simple model delimiting the effects of distortions due to Mn/Fe substitution is also proposed and applied.  The combined approach has clear future applications to TM-bearing battery cathode phases in particular and for the understanding of complex paramagnetic phases in general.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref40"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref40" class="rightTabRefNumLink">40</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit40" data-doi="10.1021/cm400201t"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Middlemiss, D. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ilott, A. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Strobridge, F. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Density Functional Theory-Based Bond Pathway Decompositions of Hyperfine Shifts: Equipping Solid-State NMR to Characterize Atomic Environments in Paramagnetic Materials</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2013</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>25</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1723</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1734</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/cm400201t</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit40R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">40</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Density Functional Theory-Based Bond Pathway Decompositions of Hyperfine Shifts: Equipping Solid-State NMR to Characterize Atomic Environments in Paramagnetic Materials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Middlemiss, Derek S.; Ilott, Andrew J.; Clement, Raphaele J.; Strobridge, Fiona C.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2013</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">25</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1723-1734</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Solid-state NMR of paramagnetic samples has the potential to provide a detailed insight into the environments and processes occurring in a wide range of technol.-relevant phases, but the acquisition and interpretation of spectra is typically not straightforward.  Structural complexity and/or the occurrence of charge or orbital ordering further compd. such difficulties.  In response to such challenges, the present article outlines how the total Fermi contact (FC) shifts of NMR obsd. centers (OCs) may be decompd. into sets of pairwise metal-OC bond pathway contributions via solid-state hybrid d. functional theory calcns.  A generally applicable spin flipping approach is outlined wherein bond pathway contributions were obtained by the reversal of spin moments at selected metal sites.  The applications of such pathway contributions in interpreting the NMR spectra of structurally and electronically complex phases are demonstrated in a range of paramagnetic Li-ion battery pos. electrodes comprising layered LiNiO2, LiNi0.125Co0.875O2, and LiCr0.125Co0.875O2 oxides; and olivine-type LiMPO4 and MPO4 (M = Mn, Fe, and Co) phosphates.  The FC NMR shifts of all 6/7Li and 31P sites are decompd., providing unambiguous NMR-based proof of the existence of local Ni3+-centered Jahn-Teller distortions in LiNiO2 and LiNi0.125Co0.875O2, and showing that the presence of M2+/M3+ solid solns. and/or M/M' isovalent transition metal (TM) mixts. in the olivine-type electrodes should lead to broad and potentially interpretable NMR spectra.  Clear evidence for the presence of a dynamic Jahn-Teller distortion was obtained for LiNixCo1-xO2.  The results emphasize the utility of solid-state NMR in application to TM-contg. battery materials and to paramagnetic samples in general.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref41"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref41" class="rightTabRefNumLink">41</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit41" data-doi="10.1021/ja102678r"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Middlemiss, D. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chernova, N. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhu, B. Y. X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Masquelier, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Linking Local Environments and Hyperfine Shifts: A Combined Experimental and Theoretical 31 P and 7 Li Solid-State NMR Study of Paramagnetic Fe(III) Phosphates</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2010</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>132</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">16825</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">16840</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/ja102678r</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit41R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">41</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Linking Local Environments and Hyperfine Shifts: A Combined Experimental and Theoretical 31P and 7Li Solid-State NMR Study of Paramagnetic Fe(III) Phosphates</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kim, Jong-Sik; Middlemiss, Derek S.; Chernova, Natasha A.; Zhu, Ben Y.-X.; Masquelier, Christian; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2010</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">132</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">47</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">16825-16840</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Iron phosphates (FePO4) are among the most promising candidate materials for advanced Li-ion battery cathodes.  This work reports upon a combined NMR exptl. and periodic d. functional theory (DFT) computational study of the environments and electronic structures occurring in a range of paramagnetic Fe(III) phosphates comprising FePO4 (heterosite), monoclinic Li3Fe2(PO4)3 (anti-NASICON A type), rhombohedral Li3Fe2(PO4)3 (NASICON B type), LiFeP2O7, orthorhombic FePO4·2H2O (strengite), monoclinic FePO4·2H2O (phosphosiderite), and the dehydrated forms of the latter two phases.  Many of these materials serve as model compds. relevant to battery chem.  The 31P spin-echo mapping and 7Li magic angle spinning NMR techniques yield the hyperfine shifts of the species of interest, complemented by periodic hybrid functional DFT calcns. of the resp. hyperfine and quadrupolar tensors.  A Curie-Weiss-based magnetic model scaling the DFT-calcd. hyperfine parameters from the ferromagnetic into the exptl. relevant paramagnetic state is derived and applied, providing quant. finite temp. values for each phase.  The sensitivity of the hyperfine parameters to the compn. of the DFT exchange functional was characterized by the application of hybrid Hamiltonians contg. admixts. 0%, 20%, and 35% of Fock exchange.  Good agreement between exptl. and calcd. values was obtained, provided that the residual magnetic couplings persisting in the paramagnetic state are included.  The potential applications of a similar combined exptl. and theor. NMR approach to a wider range of cathode materials are discussed.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref42"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref42" class="rightTabRefNumLink">42</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit42" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b00856"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kim, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ilott, A. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Middlemiss, D. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chernova, N. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pinney, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Morgan, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">2H and 27Al Solid-State NMR Study of the Local Environments in Al-Doped 2-Line Ferrihydrite, Goethite, and Lepidocrocite</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>27</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">3966</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3978</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b00856</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit42R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">42</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">2H and 27Al Solid-State NMR Study of the Local Environments in Al-Doped 2-Line Ferrihydrite, Goethite, and Lepidocrocite</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kim, Jongsik; Ilott, Andrew J.; Middlemiss, Derek S.; Chernova, Natasha A.; Pinney, Nathan; Morgan, Dane; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">27</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">11</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">3966-3978</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Although substitution of aluminum into iron oxides and oxyhydroxides has been extensively studied, it is difficult to obtain accurate incorporation levels.  Assessing the distribution of dopants within these materials has proven esp. challenging because bulk anal. techniques cannot typically det. whether dopants are substituted directly into the bulk iron oxide or oxyhydroxide phase or if they form sep., minor phase impurities.  These differences have important implications for the chem. of these iron-contg. materials, which are ubiquitous in the environment.  In this work, 27Al and 2H NMR expts. are performed on series of Al-substituted goethite, lepidocrocite, and 2-line ferrihydrite in order to develop an NMR method to track Al substitution.  The extent of Al substitution into the structural frameworks of each compd. is quantified by comparing quant. 27Al MAS NMR results with those from elemental anal.  Magnetic measurements are performed for the goethite series to compare with NMR measurements.  Static 27Al spin-echo mapping expts. are used to probe the local environments around the Al substituents, providing clear evidence that they are incorporated into the bulk iron phases.  Predictions of the 2H and 27Al NMR hyperfine contact shifts in Al-doped goethite and lepidocrocite, obtained from a combined first-principles and empirical magnetic scaling approach, give further insight into the distribution of the dopants within these phases.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref43"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref43" class="rightTabRefNumLink">43</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit43" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.47.558"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kresse, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hafner, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Ab Initio Molecular Dynamics for Liquid Metals</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1993</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>47</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">558</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">561</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.47.558</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit43R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">43</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Ab initio molecular dynamics of liquid metals</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kresse, G.; Hafner, J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B:  Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1993</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">47</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">558-61</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">The authors present ab initio quantum-mech. mol.-dynamics calcns. based on the calcn. of the electronic ground state and of the Hellmann-Feynman forces in the local-d. approxn. at each mol.-dynamics step.  This is possible using conjugate-gradient techniques for energy minimization, and predicting the wave functions for new ionic positions using sub-space alignment.  This approach avoids the instabilities inherent in quantum-mech. mol.-dynamics calcns. for metals based on the use of a factitious Newtonian dynamics for the electronic degrees of freedom.  This method gives perfect control of the adiabaticity and allows one to perform simulations over several picoseconds.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref44"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref44" class="rightTabRefNumLink">44</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit44" data-doi="10.1016/0927-0256(96)00008-0"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kresse, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Furthmüller, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Efficiency of Ab-Initio Total Energy Calculations for Metals and Semiconductors Using a Plane-Wave Basis Set</span>. <i>Comput. Mater. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1996</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>6</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">15</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">50</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1016/0927-0256(96)00008-0</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit44R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">44</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Efficiency of ab-initio total energy calculations for metals and semiconductors using a plane-wave basis set</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kresse, G.; Furthmuller, J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Computational Materials Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1996</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">6</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">15-50</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMMSEM</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0927-0256</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The authors present a detailed description and comparison of algorithms for performing ab-initio quantum-mech. calcns. using pseudopotentials and a plane-wave basis set.  The authors will discuss: (a) partial occupancies within the framework of the linear tetrahedron method and the finite temp. d.-functional theory, (b) iterative methods for the diagonalization of the Kohn-Sham Hamiltonian and a discussion of an efficient iterative method based on the ideas of Pulay's residual minimization, which is close to an order N2atoms scaling even for relatively large systems, (c) efficient Broyden-like and Pulay-like mixing methods for the charge d. including a new special preconditioning optimized for a plane-wave basis set, (d) conjugate gradient methods for minimizing the electronic free energy with respect to all degrees of freedom simultaneously.  The authors have implemented these algorithms within a powerful package called VAMP (Vienna ab-initio mol.-dynamics package).  The program and the techniques have been used successfully for a large no. of different systems (liq. and amorphous semiconductors, liq. simple and transition metals, metallic and semi-conducting surfaces, phonons in simple metals, transition metals and semiconductors) and turned out to be very reliable.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref45"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref45" class="rightTabRefNumLink">45</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit45" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.49.14251"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kresse, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hafner, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Ab Initio Molecular-Dynamics Simulation of the Liquid-Metalamorphous- Semiconductor Transition in Germanium</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1994</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>49</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">14251</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">14269</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.49.14251</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit45R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">45</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Ab initio molecular-dynamics simulation of the liquid-metal-amorphous-semiconductor transition in germanium</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kresse, G.; Hafner, J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B:  Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1994</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">49</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">20</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">14251-69</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">The authors present ab initio quantum-mech. mol.-dynamics simulations of the liq.-metal-amorphous-semiconductor transition in Ge.  The simulations are based on (a) finite-temp. d.-functional theory of the 1-electron states, (b) exact energy minimization and hence calcn. of the exact Hellmann-Feynman forces after each mol.-dynamics step using preconditioned conjugate-gradient techniques, (c) accurate nonlocal pseudopotentials, and (d) Nose' dynamics for generating a canonical ensemble.  This method gives perfect control of the adiabaticity of the electron-ion ensemble and allows the authors to perform simulations over &gt;30 ps.  The computer-generated ensemble describes the structural, dynamic, and electronic properties of liq. and amorphous Ge in very good agreement with expt..  The simulation allows the authors to study in detail the changes in the structure-property relation through the metal-semiconductor transition.  The authors report a detailed anal. of the local structural properties and their changes induced by an annealing process.  The geometrical, bounding, and spectral properties of defects in the disordered tetrahedral network are studied and compared with expt.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref46"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref46" class="rightTabRefNumLink">46</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit46" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.50.17953"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Blöchl, P.                 10.1103/physrevb.50.17953</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="

Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1999</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>59</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1758</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1775</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.59.1758</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit47R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">47</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">From ultrasoft pseudopotentials to the projector augmented-wave method</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kresse, G.; Joubert, D.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1999</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">59</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1758-1775</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The formal relationship between ultrasoft (US) Vanderbilt-type pseudopotentials and Blochl's projector augmented wave (PAW) method is derived.  The total energy functional for US pseudopotentials can be obtained by linearization of two terms in a slightly modified PAW total energy functional.  The Hamilton operator, the forces, and the stress tensor are derived for this modified PAW functional.  A simple way to implement the PAW method in existing plane-wave codes supporting US pseudopotentials is pointed out.  In addn., crit. tests are presented to compare the accuracy and efficiency of the PAW and the US pseudopotential method with relaxed-core all-electron methods.  These tests include small mols. (H2, H2O, Li2, N2, F2, BF3, SiF4) and several bulk systems (diamond, Si, V, Li, Ca, CaF2, Fe, Co, Ni).  Particular attention is paid to the bulk properties and magnetic energies of Fe, Co, and Ni.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref48"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref48" class="rightTabRefNumLink">48</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit48" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.44.943"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Anisimov, V. I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zaanen, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Andersen, O. K.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Band Theory and Mott Insulators: Hubbard U Instead of Stoner I</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1991</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>44</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">943</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">954</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.44.943</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit48R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">48</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Band theory and Mott insulators:  Hubbard U instead of Stoner I</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Anisimov, V. I.; Zaanen, Jan; Andersen, Ole K.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B:  Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1991</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">44</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">943-54</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">The authors propose a form for the exchange-correlation potential in local-d. band theory, appropriate to Mott insulators.  The idea is to use the "constrained-local-d.-approxn." Hubbard parameter U as the quantity relating the single-particle potentials-to the magnetic- (and orbital-) order parameters.  The authors' energy functional is that of the local-d. approxn. plus the mean-field approxn. to the remaining part of the U term.  They argue that such a method should make sense, if one accepts the Hubbard model and the success of constrained-local-d.-approxn. parameter calcns.  By using this ab initio scheme, they find that all late-3d-transition-metal monoxides, as well as the parent compds. of the high-Tc compds., are large-gap magnetic insulators of the charge-transfer type.  Further, the method predicts that LiNiO2 is a low-spin ferromagnet and NiS a local-moment p-type metal.  The present version of the scheme fails for the early-3d-transition-metal monoxides and for the late 3d transition metals.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref49"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref49" class="rightTabRefNumLink">49</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit49" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.48.16929"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Anisimov, V. I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Solovyev, I. V.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Korotin, M. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Czyżyk, M. T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sawatzky, G. A.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Density-Functional Theory and NiO Photoemission Spectra</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1993</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>48</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">16929</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">16934</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.48.16929</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit49R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">49</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Density-functional theory and NiO photoemission spectra</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Anisimov, V. I.; Solovyev, I. V.; Korotin, M. A.; Czyzyk, M. T.; Sawatzky, G. A.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B:  Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1993</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">48</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">23</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">16929-34</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">The generalization of the local-d.-approxn. method for the systems with strong Coulomb correlations is proposed, which restores the discontinuity in the one-electron potential as in the exact d. functional.  The method is based on the model-Hamiltonian approach and allows the authors to take into account the nonsphericity of the Coulomb and exchange interactions.  The calcn. scheme could be regarded as a first-principle method due to the absence of adjustable parameters.  The method was applied to the calcn. of the photoemission (x-ray photoemission spectroscopy) and bremsstrahlung isochromat spectra of NiO.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref50"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref50" class="rightTabRefNumLink">50</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit50" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.52.r5467"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Liechtenstein, A. I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Anisimov, V. I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zaanen, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Density-Functional Theory and Strong Interactions: Orbital Ordering in Mott-Hubbard Insulators</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1995</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>52</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">R5467</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.52.r5467</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit50R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">50</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Density-functional theory and strong interactions: orbital ordering in Mott-Hubbard insulators</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Liechtenstein, A. I.; Anisimov, V. I.; Zaanen, J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1995</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">52</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">R5467-R5470</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Evidence is presented that within the d.-functional theory orbital polarization has to be treated on an equal footing with spin polarization and charge d. for strongly interacting electron systems.  Using a basis-set independent generalization of the LDA + U functional, we show that electronic orbital ordering is a necessary condition to obtain the correct crystal structure and parameters of the exchange interaction for the Mott-Hubbard insulator KCuF3.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref51"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref51" class="rightTabRefNumLink">51</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit51" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.70.235121"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhou, F.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Cococcioni, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Marianetti, C. A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Morgan, D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">First-Principles Prediction of Redox Potentials in Transition-Metal Compounds with LDA + U</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2004</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>70</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">235121</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.70.235121</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit51R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">51</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">First-principles prediction of redox potentials in transition-metal compounds with LDA+U</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Zhou, F.; Cococcioni, M.; Marianetti, C. A.; Morgan, D.; Ceder, G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2004</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">70</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">23</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">235121/1-235121/8</span>CODEN:

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">First-principles calcns. within the local d. approxn. (LDA) or generalized gradient approxn. (GGA), though very successful, are known to underestimate redox potentials, such as those at which lithium intercalates in transition metal compds.  We argue that this inaccuracy is related to the lack of cancellation of electron self-interaction errors in LDA/GGA and can be improved by using the DFT + U method with a self-consistent evaluation of the U parameter.  We show that, using this approach, the exptl. lithium intercalation voltages of a no. of transition metal compds., including the olivine LixMPO4 (M = Mn, Fe Co, Ni), layered LixMO2 (x = Co, Ni) and spinel-like LixM2O4 (M = Mn, Co), can be reproduced accurately.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref52"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref52" class="rightTabRefNumLink">52</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit52" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.13.5188"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Monkhorst, H. D.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Density-functional Thermochemistry. III. The Role of Exact Exchange</span>. <i>J. Chem. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1993</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>98</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">5648</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5652</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1063/1.464913</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit54R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">54</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Density-functional thermochemistry. III. The role of exact exchange</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Becke, Axel D.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Chemical Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1993</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">98</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5648-52</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JCPSA6</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0021-9606</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">Despite the remarkable thermochem. accuracy of Kohn-Sham d.-functional theories with gradient corrections for exchange-correlation, the author believes that further improvements are unlikely unless exact-exchange information is considered.  Arguments to support this view are presented, and a semiempirical exchange-correlation functional (contg. local-spin-d., gradient, and exact-exchange terms) is tested for 56 atomization energies, 42 ionization potentials, 8 proton affinities, and 10 total at. energies of first- and second-row systems.  This functional performs better than previous functionals with gradient corrections only, and fits expt. atomization energies with an impressively small av. abs. deviation of 2.4 kcal/mol.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref55"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref55" class="rightTabRefNumLink">55</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit55" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.37.785"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Parr, R. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Development of the Colle-Salvetti Correlation-Energy Formula into a Functional of the Electron Density</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1988</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>37</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">785</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">789</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:

                        rightTab-cas_cit55R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">55</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Development of the Colle-Salvetti correlation-energy formula into a functional of the electron density</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Lee, Chengteh; Yang, Weitao; Parr, Robert G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B:  Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1988</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">37</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">2</span>),

                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">A correlation-energy formula due to R. Colle and D. Salvetti (1975), in which the correlation energy d. is expressed in terms of the electron d. and a Laplacian of the 2nd-order Hartree-Fock d. matrix, is restated as a formula involving the d. and local kinetic-energy d.  On insertion of gradient expansions for the local kinetic-energy d., d.-functional formulas for the correlation energy and correlation potential are then obtained.  Through numerical calcns. on a no. of atoms, pos. ions, and mols., of both open- and closed-shell type, it is demonstrated that these formulas, like the original Colle-Salvetti formulas, give correlation energies within a few percent.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref56"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref56" class="rightTabRefNumLink">56</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit56" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.55.16122"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Catti, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sandrone, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dovesi, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Periodic Unrestricted Hartree-Fock Study of Corundumlike Ti2O3 and V2O3</span>. <i>Phys.                 10.1103/physrevb.55.16122</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref57"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref57" class="rightTabRefNumLink">57</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit57" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.49.14179"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Catti, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Valerio, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dovesi, R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Causà, M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Quantum-Mechanical Calculation of the Solid-State Equilibrium MgO+α-Al2O3 ⇄ MgAl2O4 (Spinel) versus Pressure</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1994</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>49</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">14179</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">14187</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.49.14179</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit57R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">57</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Quantum-mechanical calculation of the solid-state equilibrium MgO + α-Al2O3↹MgAl2O4 (spinel) versus pressure</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Catti, M.; Valerio, G.; Dovesi, R.; Causa, M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B:  Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1994</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">49</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">20</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">14179-87</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0163-1829</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">The ground-state crystal energies of cubic MgAl2O4 (spinel) and MgO (periclase) and of rhombohedral α-Al2O3 (corundum) were calcd. at different vols., relaxing the corresponding structures, by all-electron period Hartree-Fock methods (CRYSTAL program).  Basis sets of contracted Gaussian-type functions are employed for the 18 at. (including d) orbitals representing each of the Mg, Al, and O atoms.  Mulliken net at. charges zMg = 1.86|e| (MgO), zAl = 2.30|e| (α-Al2O3), zMg = 1.74|e|, and zAl = 2.24|e| (spinel) are obtained.  The elastic bulk modulus, the Murnaghan equation of state p (V) at the athermal limit, the Mg-O and Al-O bond compressibilities, and the binding energy were derived for each phase (and the elastic consts. C11 and C12 for spinel only).  Comparison with existing exptl. data is discussed.  The enthalpy change for spinel decompn. into the simple oxides was computed as a function of pressure, including a correction for the electron correlation energy based on local-d.-functional theory.  A decompn. pressure of 11 GPa at T = 0 K is predicted, against values of 8 and 13 GPa derived from exptl. thermodn. data and from direct compression expts., resp.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref58"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref58" class="rightTabRefNumLink">58</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit58" data-doi="10.1016/0022-3697(96)00034-0"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Catti, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sandrone, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Valerio, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dovesi, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Electronic, Magnetic and Crystal Structure of Cr2O3 by Theoretical Methods</span>. <i>J.                 10.1016/0022-3697(96)00034-0</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit58R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">58</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Electronic, magnetic and crystal structure of Cr2O3 by theoretical methods</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Catti, M.; Sandrone, G.; Valerio, G.; Dovesi, R.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physics and Chemistry of Solids</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1996</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">57</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">11</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1735-1741</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCSAW</span>;

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Elsevier</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The periodic UHF method has been adopted to calc. the ground-state spin-polarized wave function and total energy of rhombohedral Cr2O3 (corundum-type structure).  Contracted Gaussian-type functions represent the AOs of Cr and O atoms.  The least-energy structural configuration as a function of pressure has been derived, as well as elastic properties and equation-of-state parameters.  Results agree satisfactorily with exptl. data.  The relative stability of the antiferromagnetic and ferromagnetic spin arrangements in investigated.  D. of electronic states, Mulliken population data and charge and spin d. maps locate Cr2O3 at the borderline between Mott-Hubbard and charge-transfer insulators.  Important differences appear in the covalent character of the chem. bond and in the spin polarization of the anions, when compared to Fe2O3.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref59"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref59" class="rightTabRefNumLink">59</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit59" data-doi="10.1063/1.463096"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Schäfer, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Horn, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ahlrichs, R.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Fully Optimized Contracted Gaussian Basis Sets for Atoms Li to Kr</span>. <i>J. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A Systematic Study of 25 Mg NMR in Paramagnetic Transition Metal Oxides: Applications to Mg-Ion Battery Materials</span>. <i>Phys. Chem.
