                10.1039/c6cp06338a</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit61R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">61</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">A systematic study of 25Mg NMR in paramagnetic transition metal oxides: applications to Mg-ion battery materials</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Lee, Jeongjae; Seymour, Ieuan D.; Pell, Andrew J.; Dutton, Sian E.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Chemistry Chemical Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2017</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">19</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">613-625</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PPCPFQ</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1463-9076</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Rechargeable battery systems based on Mg-ion chemistries are generating significant interest as potential alternatives to Li-ion batteries.  Despite the wealth of local structural information that could potentially be gained from NMR (NMR) expts. of Mg-ion battery materials, systematic 25Mg solid-state NMR studies have been scarce due to the low natural abundance, low gyromagnetic ratio, and significant quadrupole moment of 25Mg (I = 5/2).  This work reports a combined exptl. 25Mg NMR and first principles d. functional theory (DFT) study of paramagnetic Mg transition metal oxide systems Mg6MnO8 and MgCr2O4 that serve as model systems for Mg-ion battery cathode materials.  Magnetic parameters, hyperfine shifts and quadrupolar parameters were calcd. ab initio using hybrid DFT and compared to the exptl. values obtained from NMR and magnetic measurements.  We show that the rotor assisted population transfer (RAPT) pulse sequence can be used to enhance the signal-to-noise ratio in paramagnetic 25Mg spectra without distortions in the spinning sideband manifold.  In addn., the value of the predicted quadrupolar coupling const. of Mg6MnO8 was confirmed using the RAPT pulse sequence.  We further apply the same methodol. to study the NMR spectra of spinel compds. MgV2O4 and MgMn2O4, candidate cathode materials for Mg-ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref62"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref62" class="rightTabRefNumLink">62</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit62" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b05307"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Seymour, I. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wales, D. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Preventing Structural Rearrangements on Battery Cycling: A First-Principles Investigation of the Effect of Dopants on the Migration Barriers in Layered Li 0.5 MnO 2</span>. <i>J. Phys. Chem. C</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>120</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">19521</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">19530</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.jpcc.6b05307</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit62R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">62</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Preventing Structural Rearrangements on Battery Cycling: A First-Principles Investigation of the Effect of Dopants on the Migration Barriers in Layered Li0.5MnO2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Seymour, Ieuan D.; Wales, David J.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry C</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">120</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">35</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">19521-19530</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JPCCCK</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1932-7447</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Layered LiMnO2 is a potential Li ion cathode material that is known to undergo a layered to spinel transformation upon delithiation, as a result of Mn migration.  A common strategy to improve the structural stability of LiMnO2 has been to replace Mn with a range of metal dopants, although the mechanism by which each dopant stabilizes the structure is not well understood.  In this work we characterize ion-migration barriers using hybrid eigenvector-following (EF) and d. functional theory to study how trivalent dopants (Al3+, Cr3+, Fe3+, Ga3+, Sc3+, and In3+) affect Mn migration during the initial stage of the layered to spinel transformation in Li0.5MnO2.  We demonstrate that dopants with small ionic radii, such as Al3+ and Cr3+, can increase the barrier for migration, but only when they are located in the first cation coordination sphere of Mn.  We also demonstrate how the hybrid EF approach can be used to study the migration barriers of dopant species within the structure of Li0.5MnO2 efficiently.  The transition state searching methodol. described in this work will be useful for studying the effects of dopants on structural transformation mechanisms in a wide range of technol. interesting energy materials.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref63"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref63" class="rightTabRefNumLink">63</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit63" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b01674"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Seymour, I. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chakraborty, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Middlemiss, D. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wales, D. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grey, C. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Mapping Structural Changes in Electrode Materials: Application of the Hybrid Eigenvector-Following Density Functional Theory (DFT) Method to Layered Li 0.5 MnO 2</span>. <i>Chem. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>27</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">5550</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">5561</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.5b01674</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit63R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">63</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Mapping Structural Changes in Electrode Materials: Application of the Hybrid Eigenvector-Following Density Functional Theory (DFT) Method to Layered Li0.5MnO2</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Seymour, Ieuan D.; Chakraborty, Sudip; Middlemiss, Derek S.; Wales, David J.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">27</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">16</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">5550-5561</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The migration mechanism assocd. with the initial layered-to-spinel transformation of partially delithiated layered LiMnO2 was studied using hybrid eigenvector-following coupled with d. functional theory.  The initial part of the transformation mechanism of Li0.5MnO2 involves the migration of Li into both octahedral and tetrahedral local min. within the layered structure.  The next stage of the transformation process involves the migration of Mn and was found to occur through several local min., including an intermediate square pyramidal MnO5 configuration and an independent Mn3+ to Mn2+ charge-transfer process.  The migration pathways were found to be significantly affected by the size of the supercell used and the inclusion of a Hubbard U parameter in the DFT functional.  The transition state searching methodol. described should be useful for studying the structural rearrangements that can occur in electrode materials during battery cycling, and more generally, ionic and electronic transport phenomena in a wide range of energy materials.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref64"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref64" class="rightTabRefNumLink">64</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit64" data-doi="10.1021/ct5008718"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chill, S.                 10.1021/ct5008718</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A set of benchmark systems is defined to compare different computational approaches for characterizing local min., transition states, and pathways in at., mol., and condensed matter systems.  Comparisons between several commonly used methods are presented.  The strengths and weaknesses are discussed, as well as implementation details that are important for achieving good performance.  All of the benchmarks and methods are provided in an online database to make the implementation details available and the results reproducible.  While this paper provides a snapshot of the benchmark results, the online framework is structured to be dynamic and incorporate new methods and codes as they are developed.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref65"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref65" class="rightTabRefNumLink">65</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit65" data-doi="10.1016/s0009-2614(01)00334-7"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kumeda, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wales, D.         </div><div class="casAbstract">Hybrid eigenvector-following (EF) using variational eigenvector refinement and tangent space minimization are combined with plane-wave d.-functional calcns. to characterize rearrangements of C10H10 and a variety of defect migration processes in cryst. silicon.  For silicon we compare local and 'non-local' d. functionals and supercells contg. 64±1 and 216±1 atoms. J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Defect Migration in Crystalline Silicon</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1999</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>59</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">3969</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">3980</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.59.3969</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="

        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1999</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">59</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">6</span>),

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A no. of vacancy and interstitial defect migration mechanisms were characterized for cryst. Si using supercells contg. 64 and 216 atoms and a tight-binding approach.  The authors study various defect configurations corresponding to min. and the pathways that connect them.  A modified eigenvector-following approach was used to locate true transition states.  The authors exploit the fact that only one Hessian eigenvector is needed to define the uphill search direction and use conjugate gradient minimization in the tangent space to produce a hybrid algorithm.  Two implementations of this approach are considered, the 1st where 2nd derivs. are available but full diagonalization of the Hessian would be the most time-consuming step, and the 2nd where only 1st derivs. of the energy are known.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref67"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref67" class="rightTabRefNumLink">67</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit67" data-doi="10.1063/1.3382344"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Grimme, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Antony, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ehrlich, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Krieg, H.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">A Consistent and Accurate Ab Initio Parametrization of Density Functional Dispersion Correction (DFT-D) for the 94 Elements H-Pu</span>. <i>J. Chem. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2010</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>132</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">154104</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1063/1.3382344</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit67R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">67</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">A consistent and accurate ab initio parametrization of density functional dispersion correction (DFT-D) for the 94 elements H-Pu</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Grimme, Stefan; Antony, Jens; Ehrlich, Stephan; Krieg, Helge</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Chemical Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2010</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">132</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">15</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">154104/1-154104/19</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JCPSA6</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0021-9606</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Institute of Physics</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The method of dispersion correction as an add-on to std. Kohn-Sham d. functional theory (DFT-D) has been refined regarding higher accuracy, broader range of applicability, and less empiricism.  The main new ingredients are atom-pairwise specific dispersion coeffs. and cutoff radii that are both computed from first principles.  The coeffs. for new eighth-order dispersion terms are computed using established recursion relations.  System (geometry) dependent information is used for the first time in a DFT-D type approach by employing the new concept of fractional coordination nos. (CN).  They are used to interpolate between dispersion coeffs. of atoms in different chem. environments.  The method only requires adjustment of two global parameters for each d. functional, is asymptotically exact for a gas of weakly interacting neutral atoms, and easily allows the computation of at. forces.  Three-body nonadditivity terms are considered.  The method has been assessed on std. benchmark sets for inter- and intramol. noncovalent interactions with a particular emphasis on a consistent description of light and heavy element systems.  The mean abs. deviations for the S22 benchmark set of noncovalent interactions for 11 std. d. functionals decrease by 15%-40% compared to the previous (already accurate) DFT-D version.  Spectacular improvements are found for a tripeptide-folding model and all tested metallic systems.  The rectification of the long-range behavior and the use of more accurate C6 coeffs. also lead to a much better description of large (infinite) systems as shown for graphene sheets and the adsorption of benzene on an Ag(111) surface.  For graphene it is found that the inclusion of three-body terms substantially (by about 10%) weakens the interlayer binding.  We propose the revised DFT-D method as a general tool for the computation of the dispersion energy in mols. and solids of any kind with DFT and related (low-cost) electronic structure methods for large systems.  (c) 2010 American Institute of Physics.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref68"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref68" class="rightTabRefNumLink">68</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit68" data-doi="10.1103/physrevlett.92.246401"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dion, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rydberg, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Schröder, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Langreth, D. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lundqvist, B. I.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Van Der Waals Density Functional for General Geometries</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2004</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>92</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">246401</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevlett.92.246401</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit68R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">68</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Van der Waals Density Functional for General Geometries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Dion, M.; Rydberg, H.; Schroeder, E.; Langreth, D. C.; Lundqvist, B. I.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2004</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">92</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">24</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">246401/1-246401/4</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRLTAO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0031-9007</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A scheme within d. functional theory is proposed that provides a practical way to generalize to unrestricted geometries the method applied with some success to layered geometries [H. Rydberg et al., Phys. Rev. Lett. 91, 126402 (2003)].  It includes van der Waals forces in a seamless fashion.  By expansion to second order in a carefully chosen quantity contained in the long-range part of the correlation functional, the nonlocal correlations are expressed in terms of a d.-d. interaction formula.  It contains a relatively simple parametrized kernel, with parameters detd. by the local d. and its gradient.  The proposed functional is applied to rare gas and benzene dimers, where it is shown to give a realistic description.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref69"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref69" class="rightTabRefNumLink">69</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit69" data-doi="10.1103/physrevlett.103.096102"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Román-Pérez, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Soler, J. M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Efficient Implementation of a van Der Waals Density Functional: Application to Double-Wall Carbon Nanotubes</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2009</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>103</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">096102</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevlett.103.096102</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit69R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">69</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Efficient Implementation of a van der Waals Density Functional: Application to Double-Wall Carbon Nanotubes</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Roman-Perez, Guillermo; Soler, Jose M.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2009</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">103</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">096102/1-096102/4</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRLTAO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0031-9007</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We present an efficient implementation of the van der Waals d. functional of Dion et al., which expresses the nonlocal correlation energy as a double spatial integral.  We factorize the integration kernel and use fast Fourier transforms to evaluate the self-consistent potential, total energy, and at. forces, in O(NlogN) operations.  The resulting overhead, for medium and large systems, is a small fraction of the total computational cost, representing a dramatic speedup over the O(N2) evaluation of the double integral.  This opens the realm of first-principles simulations to the large systems of interest in soft matter and biomol. problems.  We apply the method to calc. the binding energies and the barriers for relative translation and rotation in double-wall carbon nanotubes.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref70"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref70" class="rightTabRefNumLink">70</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit70" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.82.081101"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lee, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Murray, É. D.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kong, L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Lundqvist, B. I.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Langreth, D. C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Higher-Accuracy van Der Waals Density Functional</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2010</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>82</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">081101</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.82.081101</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit70R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">70</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Higher-accuracy van der Waals density functional</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Lee, Kyuho; Murray, Eamonn D.; Kong, Lingzhu; Lundqvist, Bengt I.; Langreth, David C.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2010</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">82</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">081101/1-081101/4</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We propose a second version of the van der Waals d. functional of Dion et al. [Phys. Rev. Lett. 92, 246401 (2004)], employing a more accurate semilocal exchange functional and the use of a large-N asymptote gradient correction in detg. the vdW kernel.  The predicted binding energy, equil. sepn., and potential-energy curve shape are close to those of accurate quantum chem. calcns. on 22 duplexes.  We anticipate the enabling of chem. accurate calcns. in sparse materials of importance for condensed matter, surface, chem., and biol. physics.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref71"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref71" class="rightTabRefNumLink">71</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit71" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.83.195131"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Klimeš, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bowler, D. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Michaelides, A.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Van Der Waals Density Functionals Applied to Solids</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2011</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>83</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">195131</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.83.195131</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit71R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">71</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Van der Waals density functionals applied to solids</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Klimes, Jiri; Bowler, David R.; Michaelides, Angelos</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2011</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">83</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">19</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">195131/1-195131/13</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1098-0121</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The van der Waals d. functional (vdW-DF) of M. Dion et al. [Phys. Rev. Lett. 92, 246401 (2004)] is a promising approach for including dispersion in approx. d. functional theory exchange-correlation functionals.  Indeed, an improved description of systems held by dispersion forces has been demonstrated in the literature.  However, despite many applications, std. general tests on a broad range of materials including traditional "hard" matter such as metals, ionic compds., and insulators are lacking.  Such tests are important not least because many of the applications of the vdW-DF method focus on the adsorption of atoms and mols. on the surfaces of solids.  Here we calc. the lattice consts., bulk moduli, and atomization energies for a range of solids using the original vdW-DF and several of its offspring.  We find that the original vdW-DF overestimates lattice consts. in a similar manner to how it overestimates binding distances for gas-phase dimers.  However, some of the modified vdW functionals lead to av. errors which are similar to those of PBE or better.  Likewise, atomization energies that are slightly better than from PBE are obtained from the modified vdW-DFs.  Although the tests reported here are for hard solids, not normally materials for which dispersion forces are thought to be important, we find a systematic improvement in cohesive properties for the alkali metals and alkali halides when nonlocal correlations are accounted for.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref72"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref72" class="rightTabRefNumLink">72</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit72" data-doi="10.1103/PhysRevLett.115.036402"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ruzsinszky, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perdew, J. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Strongly Constrained and Appropriately Normed Semilocal Density Functional</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. Lett.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2015</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>115</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">036402</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/PhysRevLett.115.036402</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit72R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">72</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Strongly constrained and appropriately normed semilocal density functional</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Sun, Jianwei; Ruzsinszky, Adrienn; Perdew, John P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review Letters</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2015</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">115</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">3</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">036402/1-036402/6</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRLTAO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0031-9007</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The ground-state energy, electron d., and related properties of ordinary matter can be computed efficiently when the exchange-correlation energy as a functional of the d. is approximated semilocally.  We propose the first meta-generalized-gradient approxn. (meta-GGA) that is fully constrained, obeying all 17 known exact constraints that a meta-GGA can.  It is also exact or nearly exact for a set of "appropriate norms," including rare-gas atoms and nonbonded interactions.  This strongly constrained and appropriately normed meta-GGA achieves remarkable accuracy for systems where the exact exchange-correlation hole is localized near its electron, and esp. for lattice consts. and weak interactions.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref73"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref73" class="rightTabRefNumLink">73</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit73" data-doi="10.1038/nchem.2535"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Remsing, R. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zhang, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ruzsinszky, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Peng, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, Z.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Paul, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Waghmare, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Wu, X.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Klein, M. L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perdew, J. P.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Accurate First-Principles Structures and Energies of Diversely Bonded Systems from an Efficient Density Functional</span>. <i>Nat. Chem.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>8</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">831</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">836</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/nchem.2535</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit73R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">73</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Accurate first-principles structures and energies of diversely bonded systems from an efficient density functional</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Sun, Jianwei; Remsing, Richard C.; Zhang, Yubo; Sun, Zhaoru; Ruzsinszky, Adrienn; Peng, Haowei; Yang, Zenghui; Paul, Arpita; Waghmare, Umesh; Wu, Xifan; Klein, Michael L.; Perdew, John P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Chemistry</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">8</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">831-836</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NCAHBB</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1755-4330</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Publishing Group</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">One atom or mol. binds to another through various types of bond, the strengths of which range from several meV to several eV.  Although some computational methods can provide accurate descriptions of all bond types, those methods are not efficient enough for many studies (for example, large systems, ab initio mol. dynamics and high-throughput searches for functional materials).  Here, we show that the recently developed nonempirical strongly constrained and appropriately normed (SCAN) meta-generalized gradient approxn. (meta-GGA) within the d. functional theory framework predicts accurate geometries and energies of diversely bonded mols. and materials (including covalent, metallic, ionic, hydrogen and van der Waals bonds).  This represents a significant improvement at comparable efficiency over its predecessors, the GGAs that currently dominate materials computation.  Often, SCAN matches or improves on the accuracy of a computationally expensive hybrid functional, at almost-GGA cost.  SCAN is therefore expected to have a broad impact on chem. and materials science.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref74"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref74" class="rightTabRefNumLink">74</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit74" data-doi="10.1103/physrevx.6.041005"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Peng, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Yang, Z. H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Perdew, J. P.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sun, J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Versatile van Der Waals Density Functional Based on a Meta-Generalized Gradient Approximation</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. X</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>6</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">041005</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevx.6.041005</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit74R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">74</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Versatile van der Waals density functional based on a meta-generalized gradient approximation</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Peng, Haowei; Yang, Zeng-Hui; Perdew, John P.; Sun, Jianwei</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review X</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">6</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">041005/1-041005/15</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRXHAE</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2160-3308</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A "best-of-both-worlds" van der Waals (vdW) d. functional is constructed, seamlessly supplementing the strongly constrained and appropriately normed (SCAN) meta-generalized gradient approxn. for short- and intermediate-range interactions with the long-range vdW interaction from rVV10, the revised Vydrov-van Voorhis nonlocal correlation functional.  The resultant SCAN+rVV10 is the only vdW d. functional to date that yields excellent interlayer binding energies and spacings, as well as intralayer lattice consts. in 28 layered materials.  Its versatility for various kinds of bonding is further demonstrated by its good performance for 22 interactions between mols.; the cohesive energies and lattice consts. of 50 solids; the adsorption energy and distance of a benzene mol. on coinage-metal surfaces; the binding energy curves for graphene on Cu(111), Ni(111), and Co(0001) surfaces; and the rare-gas solids.  We argue that a good semilocal approxn. should (as SCAN does) capture the intermediate-range vdW through its exchange term.We have found an effective range of the vdW interaction between 8 and 16 Å for systems considered here, suggesting that this interaction is negligibly small at the larger distances where it reaches its asymptotic power-law decay.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref75"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref75" class="rightTabRefNumLink">75</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit75" data-doi="10.1039/c7ee02995k"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tapia-Ruiz, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dose, W. M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Sharma, N.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Chen, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Heath, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Somerville, J. W.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Maitra, U.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Islam, M. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Bruce, P. G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">High Voltage Structural Evolution and Enhanced Na-Ion Diffusion in P2-Na2/3Ni1/3-: XMgxMn2/3O2(0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2) Cathodes from Diffraction, Electrochemical and Ab Initio Studies</span>. <i>Energy Environ. Sci.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2018</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>11</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">1470</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">1479</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1039/c7ee02995k</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit75R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">75</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">High voltage structural evolution and enhanced Na-ion diffusion in P2-Na2/3Ni1/3-xMgxMn2/3O2 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.2) cathodes from diffraction, electrochemical and ab initio studies</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Tapia-Ruiz, Nuria; Dose, Wesley M.; Sharma, Neeraj; Chen, Hungru; Heath, Jennifer; Somerville, James W.; Maitra, Urmimala; Islam, M. Saiful; Bruce, Peter G.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Energy &amp; Environmental Science</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2018</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">11</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">6</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">1470-1479</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">EESNBY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1754-5706</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">We have presented a detailed investigation of the effects of Mg substitution on the structure, electrochem. performance and Na-ion diffusion in high voltage P2-type Na2/3Ni1/3-xMgxMn2/3O2 (0 &lt; x &lt; 0.2) cathode materials for Na-ion batteries.  Structural anal. using neutron diffraction showed that Mg2+ substitutes at Ni2+ sites from ordered [(Ni2+/Mn4+)O6] honeycomb units along the ab-plane, leading to an AB-type structure that can be indexed using the P63 space group.  Within the sodium layers, high Mg-substitution levels (i.e. x = 0.2) caused a disruption in the typical Na zig-zag ordering obsd. in the undoped material, leading to a more disordered Na distribution in the layers.  Load curves of the x = 0.1 and 0.2 materials show smooth electrochem., indicative of a solid-soln. process.  Furthermore, DFT calcns. showed an increase in Na-ion diffusivity for the Mg-substituted samples.  Enhanced cycling stability was also obsd. in these materials; structural anal. using high-resoln. in operando synchrotron X-ray diffraction show that such an improved electrochem. performance is caused by the suppression of the O2 phase and switch to the formation of an OP4 phase.  Ab initio studies support our exptl. evidence showing that the OP4 phase (cf. O2) is the most thermodynamically stable phase at high voltages for Mg-substituted compds.  Finally, we have provided evidence using diffraction for the x = 1/2 and x = 1/3 intermediate Na+-vacancy ordered phases in P2-Na2/3Ni1/3Mn2/3O2.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref76"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref76" class="rightTabRefNumLink">76</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit76" data-doi="10.1021/acs.jpcc.8b05537"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gutierrez, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dose, W.                         rightTab-cas_cit76R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">76</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">On Disrupting the Na+-Ion/Vacancy Ordering in P2-Type Sodium-Manganese-Nickel Oxide Cathodes for Na+-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Gutierrez, Arturo; Dose, Wesley M.; Borkiewicz, Olaf; Guo, Fangmin; Avdeev, Maxim; Kim, Soojeong; Fister, Timothy T.; Ren, Yang; Bareno, Javier; Johnson, Christopher S.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of Physical Chemistry C</span>

            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">A study of the electrochem. and structural properties of layered P2-Na0.62Mn0.75Ni0.25O2 is presented.  The effect of changing the Mn/Ni ratio (3:1) from what is found in Na0.67Mn0.67Ni0.33O2 (2:1) and consequently the introduction of a 3rd metal center (Mn3+) was studied.  X-ray powder diffraction (in situ and ex situ) revealed the lack of Na+-ion/vacancy ordering at the relevant Na contents (x = 0.33, 0.5, and 0.67).  Mn3+ in Na0.62Mn0.75Ni0.25O2 introduces defects into the Ni-Mn interplane charge order that in turn disrupts the ordering within the Na-plane.  The material underwent P2-O2 and P2-P2' phase transitions at high (4.2 V) and low (∼1.85 V) voltages, resp.  The material was tested at several different voltage ranges to understand the effect of the phase transitions on the capacity retention.  The inclusion of both phase transitions demonstrated comparable cycling performance to when both phase transitions were excluded.  Last, excellent rate performance was demonstrated between 4.3 and 1.5 V with a specific capacity of 120 mA h/g delivered at 500 mA/g c.d.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref77"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref77" class="rightTabRefNumLink">77</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit77" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.77.224111"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hinuma, Y.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meng, Y.         </div><div class="casAbstract">Temp.-concn. phase diagrams for NaxCoO2 (0.5 ≤ x≤1) are obtained by combining d. functional theory (DFT) in the generalized gradient approxn. (GGA) and in the GGA with Hubbard U correction (GGA + U) with the cluster expansion and Monte Carlo simulation technique.  In the GGA, holes are delocalized over the Co layer, while in GGA + U the charges on the Co layer completely localize, forming distinct Co3+ and Co4+ cations.  The leading interactions in GGA are long-range in-plane electrostatics and relaxation effects, whereas in GGA + U Co-Co interactions dominate.  Comparison of ground states, c-lattice parameter, and Na1/Na2 ratio with exptl. results consistently suggests that GGA is a better approxn. for 0.5 ≤ x≤0.8.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref78"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref78" class="rightTabRefNumLink">78</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit78" data-doi="10.1063/1.2839292"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Meng, Y.         </div><div class="casAbstract">Extensive exptl. work has been carried out to characterize the stable Na-vacancy ordering patterns at various compns. of layered NaxCoO2.  However, contradictions and debates prevail in the literature, particularly at high Na concns. x &gt; 0.5.  Understanding of the exotic electronic properties in this system requires a thorough understanding of the Na-vacancy structural orderings.  Using d. functional theory in the generalized gradient approxn. (GGA), combined with a cluster expansion structure prediction algorithm we have found an intricate set of Na-vacancy ordered ground states in NaxCoO2 (0.5 ≤ x ≤ 1).  We demonstrate a newly predicted ordering pattern between 0.67 ≤ x ≤ 0.71.  By comparing the first principles electronic structure methods within the GGA and GGA + U (Hubbard U correction) approxns., we demonstrate that at certain Na concn. the stable ordering is affected by charge localization on the Co layer through coupling between the Na and Co lattices.         </div><div class="casAbstract">A combination of operando X-ray diffraction, pair distribution function (PDF) anal. coupled with electrochem. measurements and M.ovrddot.ossbauer spectroscopy elucidates the nature of the phase transitions induced by insertion and extn. of sodium ions in P2-Na0.67[NiyMn0.5+yFe0.5-2y]O2 (y = 0, 0.10, 0.15).  When phase transitions are avoided, the optimal cathode material - P2-Na0.67Fe0.2Mn0.65Ni0.15O2 - delivers 25% more energy than the unsubstituted material, sustaining high specific energy (350 Wh kg-1) at moderate rates and maintains 80% of the original energy d. after 150 cycles - a significant improvement in performance vs. the unsubstituted analog.  The crystal structure of the high voltage phase is solved for the first time by X-ray PDF anal. of P2-Na0.67-zFe0.5Mn0.5O2 (where z ∼ 0.5), revealing that migration of the transition metals - particularly Fe3+ - into tetrahedral sites in the interlayer space occurs at high potential.  This results in new short range order between two adjacent layers.  Although the transition metal migration is reversible as proven by electrochem. performance, it induces a large disfavorable cell polarization.  The deleterious high voltage transition is mitigated by substitution of Fe3+ by Mn4+/Ni2+, giving rise to better cycling performance.  Moreover, as demonstrated by 57Fe M.ovrddot.ossbauer spectroscopy, the much lower ratio of Fe4+O6 to Fe3+O6 obsd. systematically across the range of Ni content - compared to the values expected from a purely ionic model - suggests redox activity involves the O-2p orbitals owing to their overlap with the transition metal-3d orbitals.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref80"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref80" class="rightTabRefNumLink">80</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit80" data-doi="10.1039/c6ta09601h"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Clément, R.             (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Royal Society of Chemistry</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Structural processes occurring upon electrochem. cycling in P2-Nax[LiyNizMn1-y-z]O2 (x, y, z ≤ 1) cathode materials are investigated using 23Na and 7Li solid-state NMR (ssNMR).  The interpretation of the complex paramagnetic NMR data obtained for various electrochem.-cycled NaxNi1/3Mn2/3O2 and NaxLi0.12Ni0.22Mn0.66O2 samples is assisted by state-of-the-art hybrid Hartree-Fock/d. functional theory calcns.  Two Na crystallog. environments are present in P2-Nax[LiyNizMn1-y-z]O2 compds., yet a single 23Na NMR signal is obsd. with a shift in-between those computed for edge- and face-centered prismatic sites, indicating that Na-ion motion between sites in the P2 layers results in an av. signal.  This is the first time that exptl. and theor. evidence are provided for fast Na-ion motion (on the timescale of the NMR expts.) in the interlayer space in P2-type NaxTMO2 materials.  A full assignment of the 7Li NMR data confirms that Li substitution delays the P2 to O2 phase transformation taking place in NaxNi1/3Mn2/3O2 over the range 1/3 ≥ xNa ≥ 0. 23Na ssNMR data demonstrate that NaxNi1/3Mn2/3O2 samples charged to ≥3.7 V are extremely moisture sensitive once they are removed from the cell, water mols. being readily intercalated within the P2 layers leading to an addnl. Na signal between 400 and 250 ppm.  By contrast, the lithiated material NaxLi0.12Ni0.22Mn0.66O2 shows no sign of hydration until it is charged to ≥4.4 V.  Since both TMO2 layer glides and water intercalation become increasingly favorable as more vacancies are present in the Na layers, the higher stability of the Li-doped P2 phase at high voltage can be accounted for by its higher Na content at all stages of cycling.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref81"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref81" class="rightTabRefNumLink">81</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit81" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00140"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Märker, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Reeves, P. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>31</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">2545</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">2554</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00140</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit81R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">81</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Evolution of Structure and Lithium Dynamics in LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) Cathodes during Electrochemical Cycling</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Marker, Katharina; Reeves, Philip J.; Xu, Chao; Griffith, Kent J.; Grey, Clare P.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Chemistry of Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">31</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">7</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">2545-2554</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">CMATEX</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0897-4756</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The nickel-rich layered oxide LiNi0.8Mn0.1Co0.1O2 (NMC811) is a promising future cathode material for lithium-ion batteries in elec. vehicles due to its high specific energy d.  However, it exhibits fast voltage and capacity fading.  In this article, electrochem., operando synchrotron X-ray diffraction (XRD), and ex situ solid-state NMR spectroscopy are combined to provide new insights into the structural changes and lithium dynamics of NMC811 during electrochem. charge and discharge, which are essential for a better understanding of its fast degrdn.  The evolution of the interlayer spacing is tracked by XRD, showing that it gradually increases upon delithiation before collapsing at high state-of-charge (SOC).  Importantly, no two-phase O3 → O1 transition is obsd. at high SOC, demonstrating that this cannot be a major cause of degrdn.  A strong increase of Li dynamics accompanies the increase of the interlayer spacing, which is shown by 7Li NMR and electrochem. characterization.  At high SOC, Li mobility drops considerably, and Li/vacancy ordering can be obsd. by NMR.  A detailed anal. of 7Li NMR spectra at different SOC is provided, demonstrating how Li NMR can be used to ext. information on the dynamics of such challenging paramagnetic samples with several hundred different local Li environments.  The insights on the evolution of structure and dynamics of NMC811 will further the understanding of its cycling behavior and contribute to the efforts of mitigating its performance fade.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref82"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref82" class="rightTabRefNumLink">82</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit82"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Levitt, M. H.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Motional Lineshapes and Two-Site Exchange</span>. In  <i>Spin Dynamics</i>; <span class="NLM_publisher-name">John Wiley &amp; Sons Ltd.</span>: <span class="NLM_publisher-loc">Southampton</span>, <span class="NLM_year">2007</span>, pp  <span class="NLM_fpage">516</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">527</span>.</span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref83"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref83" class="rightTabRefNumLink">83</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit83"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">O’Neill, H. S. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Navrotsky, A.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Simple Spinels: Crystallographic Parameters, Cation Radii, Lattice Energies, and Cation Distribution</span>. <i>Am. Mineral.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1983</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>68</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">181</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">194</span></span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit83R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">83</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Simple spinels:  crystallographic parameters, cation radii, lattice energies, and cation distribution</span></div><div class="casAuthors">O'Neill, Hugh S. C.; Navrotsky, Alexandra</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">American Mineralogist</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">1983</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">68</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">1-2</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">181-94</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">AMMIAY</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0003-004X</span>.
    </div><div class="casAbstract">Electrostatic lattice energy calcns. and consideration of the structure of the spinel group of minerals show that the size of a cation is important in detg. its site preference.  In oxide species contg. 2+ and 3+ ions (2-3 spinels), there is a tendency for the larger ion to prefer the tetrahedral site; the reverse holds for 2-4 spinels.  A set of cation radii optimized to best fit spinel lattice parameters is presented.  Based on lattice energy calcns., the enthalpy change accompanying cation disordering is not a linear function of the degree of cation disorder, but a quadratic function in which the 2 parameters are approx. equal in magnitude and opposite in sign.  Most published data on the change of cation arrangement with temp. fit a thermodn. model with this non-linear change in enthalpy, but those for Fe3O4 may require an addnl. non-configurational entropy as well, and the data for MgAl2O4 cannot be described adequately by any simple model.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref84"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref84" class="rightTabRefNumLink">84</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit84" data-doi="10.1107/s0567739476001551"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Shannon, R. D.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Revised Effective Ionic Radii and Systematic Studies of Interatomic Distances in Halides and Chalcogenides</span>. <i>Acta Crystallogr., Sect. A: Cryst. Phys., Diffr., Theor. Gen. Crystallogr.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">1976</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>32</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">751</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">767</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s0567739476001551</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord empty" id="
                            rightTab-cas_R
                        "><div class="casContent">There is no corresponding record for this reference.</div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref85"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref85" class="rightTabRefNumLink">85</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit85" data-doi="10.1103/physrevb.74.094105"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Kang, K.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Ceder, G.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Factors That Affect Li Mobility in Layered Lithium Transition Metal Oxides</span>. <i>Phys. Rev. B: Condens. Matter Mater. Phys.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2006</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>74</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">094105</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1103/physrevb.74.094105</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit85R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">85</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Factors that affect Li mobility in layered lithium transition metal oxides</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Kang, Kisuk; Ceder, Gerbrand</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Physical Review B: Condensed Matter and Materials Physics</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2006</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">74</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">9</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">094105/1-094105/7</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">PRBMDO</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">1098-0121</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Physical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The diffusion const. of Li in electrode materials is a key aspect of the rate capability of rechargeable Li batteries.  The factors that affect Li mobility in layered Li transition metal oxides are systematically studied in this paper by first-principles calcns.  In close packed oxides octahedral ions diffuse by migrating through intermediate tetrahedral sites.  The activation barrier for Li hopping is strongly affected by the size of the tetrahedral site and the electrostatic interaction between Li+ in that site and the cation in the octahedron that shares a face with it.  The size of the tetrahedral site is detd. by the c-lattice parameter which has a remarkably strong effect on the activation barrier for Li migration.  The effect of other factors such as cation mixing and doping with nontransition metal ions can be interpreted quant. in terms of the size and electrostatic effect.  A general strategy to design high rate electrode materials is discussed.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref86"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref86" class="rightTabRefNumLink">86</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit86" data-doi="10.1107/s2052520616008507"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Gagné, O. C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hawthorne, F. C.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Bond-Length Distributions for Ions Bonded to Oxygen: Alkali and Alkaline-Earth Metals</span>. <i>Acta Crystallogr., Sect. B: Struct. Sci., Cryst. Eng. Mater.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2016</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>72</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">602</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">625</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1107/s2052520616008507</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit86R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">86</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Bond-length distributions for ions bonded to oxygen: alkali and alkaline-earth metals</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Gagne, Olivier Charles; Hawthorne, Frank Christopher</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Acta Crystallographica, Section B: Structural Science, Crystal Engineering and Materials</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2016</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">72</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">4</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">602-625</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">ACSBDA</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2052-5206</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">International Union of Crystallography</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Bond-length distributions have been examd. for 55 configurations of alkali-metal ions and 29 configurations of alk.-earth-metal ions bonded to oxygen, for 4859 coordination polyhedra and 38 594 bond distances (alkali metals), and for 3038 coordination polyhedra and 24 487 bond distances (alk.-earth metals).  Bond lengths generally show a pos. skewed Gaussian distribution that originates from the variation in Born repulsion and Coulomb attraction as a function of interat. distance.  The skewness and kurtosis of these distributions generally decrease with increasing coordination no. of the central cation, a result of decreasing Born repulsion with increasing coordination no.  We confirm the following min. coordination nos.: [3]Li+, [3]Na+, [4]K+, [4]Rb+, [6]Cs+, [3]Be2+, [4]Mg2+, [6]Ca2+, [6]Sr2+ and [6]Ba2+, but note that some reported examples are the result of extensive dynamic and/or positional short-range disorder and are not ordered arrangements.  Some distributions of bond lengths are distinctly multi-modal.  This is commonly due to the occurrence of large nos. of structure refinements of a particular structure type in which a particular cation is always present, leading to an over-representation of a specific range of bond lengths.  Outliers in the distributions of mean bond lengths are often assocd. with anomalous values of at. displacement of the constituent cations and/or anions.  For a sample of [6]Na+, the ratio Ueq(Na)/Ueq(bonded anions) is partially correlated with 〈[6]Na+-O2-〉 (R2 = 0.57), suggesting that the mean bond length is correlated with vibrational/displacement characteristics of the constituent ions for a fixed coordination no.  Mean bond lengths also show a weak correlation with bond-length distortion from the mean value in general, although some coordination nos. show the widest variation in mean bond length for zero distortion, e.g.  Li+ in [4]- and [6]-coordination, Na+ in [4]- and [6]-coordination.  For alkali-metal and alk.-earth-metal ions, there is a pos. correlation between cation coordination no. and the grand mean incident bond-valence sum at the central cation, the values varying from 0.84 v.u. for [5]K+ to 1.06 v.u. for [8]Li+, and from 1.76 v.u. for [7]Ba2+ to 2.10 v.u. for [12]Sr2+.  Bond-valence arguments suggest coordination nos. higher than [12] for K+, Rb+, Cs+ and Ba2+.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref87"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref87" class="rightTabRefNumLink">87</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit87" data-doi="10.1038/s41560-019-0410-6"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Assat, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Glazier, S. L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Delacourt, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tarascon, J.-M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Probing the Thermal Effects of Voltage Hysteresis in Anionic Redox-Based Lithium-Rich Cathodes Using Isothermal Calorimetry</span>. <i>Nat. Energy</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>4</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">647</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">656</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1038/s41560-019-0410-6</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit87R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">87</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Probing the thermal effects of voltage hysteresis in anionic redox-based lithium-rich cathodes using isothermal calorimetry</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Assat, Gaurav; Glazier, Stephen L.; Delacourt, Charles; Tarascon, Jean-Marie</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Nature Energy</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">4</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">8</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">647-656</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">NEANFD</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">2058-7546</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">Nature Research</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">The commercialization of high-energy batteries with lithium-rich cathode materials exhibiting combined cationic/anionic redox processes awaits the elimination of certain practical bottlenecks.  Among these, large voltage hysteresis remains the most obscure from a fundamental thermochem. perspective.  Here, we study this issue by directly measuring, via isothermal calorimetry, the heat generated by Li/Li2Ru0.75Sn0.25O3 (Li/LRSO) cells during various cycling conditions, with LRSO being a 'model' Li-rich layered cathode.  We show how this heat thermodynamically relates to the lost elec. work that is crucial for practical applications.  We further reveal that anionic redox on charging and discharging adopts different metastable paths having non-identical enthalpy potentials, such that the overall Li content no longer remains the unique reaction coordinate, unlike in fully path-reversible cationic redox.  We elucidate how quasi-static voltage hysteresis is related to heat dissipated due to non-equil. entropy prodn.  Overall, this study establishes the great benefits of isothermal calorimetry for enabling energy-efficient electrode materials in next-generation batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref88"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref88" class="rightTabRefNumLink">88</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit88" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.8b13633"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Taylor, Z. E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Pitcher, M. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Thomas, W. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dyer, M. S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Collins, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Zanella, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Johnson, T.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Day, S.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tang, C.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Dhanak, V. R.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Claridge, J. B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hardwick, L. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rosseinsky, M. J.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Stabilization of O.O Bonds by d 0 Cations in Li 4+x Ni 1-x WO 6 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.25) Rock Salt Oxides as the Origin of Large Voltage Hysteresis</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>141</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">7333</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">7346</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.8b13633</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit88R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">88</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Stabilization of O-O Bonds by d0 Cations in Li4+xNi1-xWO6 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.25) Rock Salt Oxides as the Origin of Large Voltage Hysteresis</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Taylor, Zoe N.; Perez, Arnaud J.; Coca-Clemente, Jose A.; Braga, Filipe; Drewett, Nicholas E.; Pitcher, Michael J.; Thomas, William J.; Dyer, Matthew S.; Collins, Christopher; Zanella, Marco; Johnson, Timothy; Day, Sarah; Tang, Chiu; Dhanak, Vinod R.; Claridge, John B.; Hardwick, Laurence J.; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">141</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">18</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">7333-7346</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Multinary lithium oxides with the rock salt structure are of technol. importance as cathode materials in rechargeable lithium ion batteries.  Current state-of-the-art cathodes such as LiNi1/3Mn1/3Co1/3O2 rely on redox cycling of earth-abundant transition-metal cations to provide charge capacity.  Recently, the possibility of using the oxide anion as a redox center in Li-rich rock salt oxides has been established as a new paradigm in the design of cathode materials with enhanced capacities (&gt; 200 mAh/g).  To increase the lithium content and access electrons from oxygen-derived states, these materials typically require transition metals in high oxidn. states, which can be easily achieved using d0 cations.  However, Li-rich rock salt oxides with high valent d0 cations such as Nb5+ and Mo6+ show strikingly high voltage hysteresis between charge and discharge, the origin of which is uninvestigated.  In this work, a series of Li-rich compds., Li4+xNi1-xWO6 (0 ≤ x ≤ 0.25) are studied by adopting two new and distinct cation-ordered variants of the rock salt structure.  The Li4.15Ni0.85WO6 (x = 0.15) phase has a large reversible capacity of 200 mAh/g, without accessing the Ni3+/Ni4+ redox couple, implying that more than two-thirds of the capacity is due to anionic redox, with good cyclability.  The presence of the 5d0 W6+ cation affords extensive (&gt; 2 V) voltage hysteresis assocd. with the anionic redox.  The exptl. evidence is presented for the formation of strongly stabilized localized O-O single bonds that explain the energy penalty required to reduce the material upon discharge.  The high valent d0 cation assocs. localized anion-anion bonding with the anion redox capacity.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref89"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref89" class="rightTabRefNumLink">89</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit89" data-doi="10.1021/jacs.8b11413"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Jacquet, Q.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Iadecola, A.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Saubanère, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Li, H.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Berg, E. J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Rousse, G.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Cabana, J.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Doublet, M.-L.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tarascon, J.-M.</span></span> <span> </span><span class="NLM_article-title">Charge Transfer Band Gap as an Indicator of Hysteresis in Li-Disordered Rock Salt Cathodes for Li-Ion Batteries</span>. <i>J. Am. Chem. Soc.</i>  <span class="NLM_year" style="font-weight: bold;">2019</span>,  <span class="NLM_volume"><i>141</i></span>,  <span class="NLM_fpage">11452</span>– <span class="NLM_lpage">11464</span>, <span class="refDoi">&nbsp;DOI:
                10.1021/jacs.8b11413</span> </span><div class=" links-group getFTR"><div class="getFTR__content getFTR__placeholder"></div><div class="casRecord" id="
                        rightTab-cas_cit89R"><div class="casContent"><span class="casTitleNuber">89</span><div class="casTitle"><span class="NLM_cas:atitle">Charge Transfer Band Gap as an Indicator of Hysteresis in Li-Disordered Rock Salt Cathodes for Li-Ion Batteries</span></div><div class="casAuthors">Jacquet, Quentin; Iadecola, Antonella; Saubanere, Matthieu; Li, Haifeng; Berg, Erik. J.; Rousse, Gwenaelle; Cabana, Jordi; Doublet, Marie-Liesse; Tarascon, Jean-Marie</div><div class="citationInfo"><span class="NLM_cas:title">Journal of the American Chemical Society</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:date">2019</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:volume">141</span>
        (<span class="NLM_cas:issue">29</span>),
    <span class="NLM_cas:pages">11452-11464</span>CODEN:
                <span class="NLM_cas:coden">JACSAT</span>;
        ISSN:<span class="NLM_cas:issn">0002-7863</span>.
    
            (<span class="NLM_cas:orgname">American Chemical Society</span>)
        </div><div class="casAbstract">Disordered rock salt cathodes showing both anionic and cationic redox are being extensively studied for their very high energy storage capacity.  Mn-based disordered rock salt compds. show much higher energy efficiency compared to the Ni-based materials as a result of the different voltage hysteresis, 0.5 and 2 V, resp.  To understand the origin of this difference, the design is reported of two model compds., Li1.3Ni0.27Ta0.43O2 and Li1.3Mn0.4Ta0.3O2, and their charge compensation mechanism is studied through the uptake and removal of Li via an arsenal of anal. techniques.  It is show that the different voltage hysteresis with Ni or Mn substitution is due to the different redn. potential for anionic redox.  The finding is rationalized by DFT calcns. and this phenomenon is proposed to be nested in the smaller charge transfer band gap of the Ni-based compds. compared to that of the Mn ones.  Altogether, these findings provide vital guidelines for designing high-capacity disordered rock salt cathode materials based on anionic redox activity for the next generation of Li ion batteries.</div></div></div></div></div></div></li><li id="rightTab-ref90"><div class="reference"><strong class="refLabel"><a href="#ref90" class="rightTabRefNumLink">90</a></strong><div class="NLM_citation references__item" id="rightTab-cit90" data-doi="10.1021/acs.chemmater.9b00772"><span><span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Song, B.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Tang, M.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Hu, E.</span></span>; <span class="NLM_contrib-group"><span class="NLM_string-name">Borkiewicz, O.
